column12: figures show";"Official data shows coal use fell in 2015 across a wide range of measures as world’s largest polluter continues its transition to clean energy";"Coal-burning in China is in significant decline
column13: according to official figures released on Tuesday
column14: signalling a major turnaround for the world’s biggest polluter.

column1: The new data is good news for the fight against climate change but bad for the struggling global coal industry.

China saw a huge increase in coal-burning for power and industry in the last two decades but has suffered serious air pollution as a result. However in recent years there has been a surge in low-carbon energy and a slowdown in the economy - GDP growth fell in 2015 to its lowest in 25 years - as China moves away from manufacturing.
The result is that global carbon emissions are set to continue the fall seen in 2015 for the first time outside of worldwide recessions
column2: potentially for many years.

column1: “This trend may continue for 3-5 years or even longer
column2: ” said Li Junfeng
column3: director general at the National Climate Change Strategy Research and International Cooperation Centre
column4: a thinktank close to China’s government. “Today’s figures are sending the strong signal of the clear acceleration of China’s energy transition. I think thermal [coal] power generation will continue to drop with an annual speed of 2-4% and the non-fossil power generation will stay in a high growth rate of 20%.”

column1: Tim Buckley
column2: at the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis
column3: said: “The implications of these changes are huge. China’s total emissions are on track to peak potentially a decade earlier than their official target of no later than 2030.

column1: “This comes at the same time that the US has confirmed a 10% year-on-year decline in coal consumption in 2015
column2: plus a three-year moratorium of new federal coal mine leases. That the largest economies globally are moving rapidly in concert to exceed the Paris [climate change] agreement sets a very positive scene for 2016.”

column1: China’s coal use has fallen in 2015 across a wide range of measures and its national carbon emissions are likely to have fallen by about 3% as a result. There was a 3.5% drop in coal production
column2: coal-fired electricity generation fell 2.8% and overall power generation dropped 0.2%
column3: the first fall in 50 years. There were similar decreases in coal-intensive heavy industry such as iron
column4: steel and cement.

column1: Other recent developments were coal imports to China plummeting by 35% year-on-year in December 2015 and the government’s ban on new coal mines for three years.
In contrast
column2: renewables investment in China hit an all-time high in 2015 at $110bn. Overall low-carbon electricity generation - hydro
column3: wind
column4: nuclear and solar - increased more than 20% in 2015.

column1: “The growth of non-fossil-fuel power generation in China in the past few years is the largest deployment of renewable energy in history
column2: ” said Greenpeace’s Lauri Myllyvirta. “This has enabled China to cover a 20% increase in power demand from 2011 to 2015 with clean energy while reducing coal use in the power sector
column3: an astounding achievement.”

column1: Benjamin Sporton
column2: chief executive at the World Coal Association
column3: said: “The cyclical slowdown in economic growth in China is affecting all energy and commodity markets
column4: including coal. Long-term forecasts however show that coal will remain the backbone of the Chinese electricity mix for decades to come and that China will remain the world’s largest producer and consumer of coal.”

column1: He said the International Energy Agency expects coal demand in south-east Asia to grow at 4.6% a year through to 2040.
“Rather than focussing on short-term fluctuations and wishing coal away

column3: ” Sporton said.

column1: But Li said: “Coal production and consumption [in China] has entered into a turning point since 2014. Even if it bounces back in the future
column2: it will not be big bounce.”

column1: A series of major coal companies have gone bankrupt in recent years

column19: Global economy";"19";"1452714600000";"1518631996000";"0";"53";"The Guardian view on the economic and environmental impact of falling oil prices | Editorial";"Editorial: The economic implications of the tumbling cost of crude are momentous but mixed. For the environment
column21: it should at least mean that more fossil fuels stay in the ground";"A decade ago
column22: British civil servants were packed off on a training day about
column24: future-proofing UK plc. The idea was to game the mid-century economy on a range of feasible assumptions
column25: one of which concerned the oil price. There was an “expected case” for 2050 of $45 a barrel
column26: a “best case” of $35 and a “worst case” of $55. So much for the bureaucratic imagination. Over the short years since
column27: the price has twice been more than double the so-called worst case
column28: and then twice also come skidding down by two-thirds.

column1: We are currently in the midst of a great oil collapse
column2: with prices sinking to within touching distance of $30 on Tuesday afternoon
column3: 73% down on 18 months ago. As with every climb up and every slip down the greasy price pole
column4: analysts are scrambling around to figure out whether the change will endure. Nobody can know
column5: but when financial sentiment swings
column6: some always conclude that it will soon swing even harder. The RBS note for investors which this week unleashed a note of panic by advising them to “sell everything” mentioned the possibility of $16 a barrel
column7: a number with little obvious basis apart from being half the current price.

column1: But there are solid reasons why the world has now convinced itself that oil is worth much less than before. On one side of the ledger there is supply
column2: not only of oil itself
column3: but also of the other fossil fuels which can often substitute for it
column4: notably gas
column5: which is more abundant than anyone would have imagined a few years ago
column6: courtesy of the fracking boom. On the demand side
column7: things have been developing even more rapidly
column8: with a serious slowdown in the resource-intensive emerging economies
column9: above all debt-laden China. The fracking revolution will not be reversed
column10: and it increasingly looks like the Chinese flu will be hard to shake. All of which suggests that low oil prices could be here for a while.

column1: So is this a good thing or not? The potentially profound geopolitical consequences are considered in today’s other editorial. Economically
column2: the standard western assumption is that cheap oil is a boon. Certainly
column3: price spikes have arrived shortly before recessions
column4: as in 1973
column5: 1979-80 and 1990. But cheap oil can be a consequence as well as a cause of economic weakness
column7: when it became a mere symptom of the great recession. The best that can be said of cheap oil today is that the global slowdown would be sharper without it.

column1: What of the environmental effect? Here
column2: although the story is complex
column3: there is more reason for optimism. Start with the premise of the Guardian’s Keep it in the Ground campaign
column4: that the only way to avoid catastrophic climate change is to leave the bulk of the world’s remaining fossil fuels where they are. Cheap oil encourages waste; worse
column5: it discourages investment in a more efficient “energy infrastructure”. Renewables
column6: as well as upgrades to clean up fossil fuel power stations
column7: yield less return. Drivers feel less pressed to trade in their SUV for a G-Wiz
column8: and car manufacturers are less inclined to concentrate R&D on fuel economy.

column1: But cheap oil also discourages investment in fossil fuel extraction. Already
column2: this week has seen BP scale back its North Sea operation. Indeed
column3: one reason why the Saudis are prepared to endure $30 a barrel is because they hope it will discourage American frackers from switching their focus from gas to oil
column4: and making investments that – once the capital is sunk – become too costly to abandon. If “keeping it in the ground” is indeed the priority
column5: this is the worst outcome of all; by discouraging it
column6: cheap oil is a force to the good.

column1: Bargain-basement energy should also be the spur for far-sighted politicians to act on carbon pricing and other regulations and taxes that can’t be done when prices are high. In Paris last month
column2: world leaders wrote post-dated cheques to the planet. Cheap oil is the opportunity to make a down payment."

column1: The annual assessment of risks conducted by the WEF before its annual meeting in Davos on 20-23 January showed that global warming had catapulted its way to the top of the list of concerns.

column4: food shortages

column1: On Thursday

column1: The five activists – Michael LaPointe
column2: Patrick Mazza
column3: Jackie Minchew

column1: The defendants – who have been dubbed the “Delta Five” by their supporters – admit they knowingly broke the law in stopping the train. Their unique legal argument
column2: known as a “necessity defense”
column3: is that their actions were a moral imperative because not breaking the law would result in catastrophic harm to the planet.

column1: Though the necessity defense was used successfully by climate change activists in England in 2008
column2: it has yet to be allowed and tested in a trial in the United States.

column1: That changed last Thursday when Snohomish County judge Anthony E Howard reversed his own ruling to permit the activists’ lawyers to present the necessity defense after hearing oral arguments from MJ McCallum and Evelyn Chuang.
Arguing for the necessity defense was a “Hail Mary pass”
column2: said McCallum
column3: and one that
column4: improbably
column5: met its mark.

column1: Whether the jury is allowed to consider that evidence in their deliberations remains uncertain. After the defense testimony concludes on Thursday
column2: the judge will determine how to instruct the jury. It’s then that he will decide whether he’s heard a strong enough case to allow the six-member jury to take the threat of climate change into account in rendering their verdict.

column1: Outside the courtroom on Wednesday
column2: sheriff’s deputies pushed through the narrow corridor
column3: escorting handcuffed men in variations on the Pacific north-west uniform of jeans
column4: flannel
column5: and rain gear
column8: and documentary film-makers jockeying for seats inside.

column1: Inside the courtroom
column2: the counsel table in Judge Howard’s six-sided courtroom was excessively crowded with five defendants
column3: four defense attorneys
column4: and prosecutor Adam Sturdivant
column5: who was pushed to the far left end with little space to rest his yellow legal pad and copies of the 2016 Washington Court Rules and Courtroom Handbook on Washington Evidence.

column1: It’s an apt metaphor for the trial itself
column2: in which the everyday machinery of the municipal criminal justice system has been shoved aside for loftier arguments about justice and democracy.

column1: Having opened the door to testimony from climate scientists
column2: Judge Howard also appeared inclined to allow expansive testimony from the defendants. He has permitted each defendant to testify to their personal history as activists
column3: mapping their development from idealistic voters to frustrated believers in the necessity of civil disobedience.

column1: “It felt like projects were being rubber-stamped no matter what we did
column2: ” Brockway said of her years spent writing letters to officials and testifying at hearings on environmental issues. “Before I switched to direct action
column3: I felt I worked within the system as much as I could.”

column1: That the defendants exhausted all the legal means of political persuasion available to US citizens in order to achieve their goals is a key factor of the necessity defense
column2: McCallum explained. The defendants must show that they reasonably believed their actions were necessary
column3: that the harm they sought to prevent was greater than the harm of breaking the law
column4: that they didn’t create the laws they broke
column5: and that they had no reasonable legal alternative.

column1: By eliciting testimony that the activists had no reasonable legal alternative to prevent the catastrophic effects of climate change
column2: the defense team is building a depressing but compelling argument against the efficacy of American democracy and government.

column1: “The reality of climate urgency will force judges and juries to rethink what is ‘reasonable’
column2: because the process of law is so slow
column3: ” said Mary Wood
column4: a professor of environmental law at the University of Oregon. “As scientists urge immediate action to slash carbon emissions
column5: many drawn-out political and legal processes that may have been ‘reasonable’ to pursue two decades ago now extend beyond the short window of time left available to act.”

column1: In the face of these lofty arguments
column2: the prosecutor was stuck on the defensive. In the cross examination
column3: Sturdivant (who declined to speak with the Guardian) asked Gammon whether there was any scientific evidence that illegal protest was more effective than legal protest and asked Brockway whether her arrest had succeeded in drawing a response from Washington’s governor
column4: Jay Inslee. Both Gammon and Brockway answered no.

column1: As for Millar
column2: who testified at length to the threat of trains carrying crude oil that are “too long
column3: too heavy
column4: and going too fast”
column5: Sturdivant had no questions at all.

column1: Tim DeChristopher
column2: a 34-year-old climate activist and the closest thing the Snohomish County south district court has had to a celebrity this week
column3: views this trial as “the culmination of seven years of his life”. When DeChristopher enters into a conversation
column4: other activists drift in his direction
column5: just to listen to what he is saying.

column1: Standing outside the court room during a lunch recess
column2: DeChristopher recalls reading about the successful necessity defense in England. In 2008
column3: a jury acquitted six Greenpeace protesters who argued their occupation and damage to a Kingsnorth coal-fired power station in Kent was justified by the threat of climate change.

column1: Inspired by that case
column2: DeChristopher decided to test his own luck. In December 2008
column3: he infiltrated a Bureau of Land Management auction
column4: bidding on and winning the right to drill on land with no intention of following through with the $1.8m payment. But a judge refused to allow DeChristopher to mount a necessity defense. He was found guilty of defrauding the government in 2011 and eventually served 21 months in jail.

column2: DeChristopher helped organize another protest designed to test the necessity defense – this time with two activists using their lobster boat to block the delivery of coal to a New England power plant. The judge in the case decided to allow the defense
column3: but at the last minute
column4: the prosecutor decided to drop the charges
column5: stating that he agreed with the defendants and could not argue against the urgency of climate change.

column1: DeChristopher says that the Delta Five train protest was designed to bring about a trial such as this one
column2: and he hopes the third time is the charm. He compares the climate movement’s legal strategy to the civil rights and women’s suffrage movements.

column1: “The legal structure was not designed to address the rights of those people
column2: ” he says
column3: until it was forced to change through acts of civil disobedience. “I believe we’re in the same situation. Our legal system was not designed to protect the rights of future generations.”

column4: Climate change";"4";"1452788885000";"1518628785000";"0";"26";"Mass deaths of Alaska seabirds linked to starvation as scientists race to find clues";"Experts have seen die-offs before in Anchorage but some wonder if climate change is to blame for the number of dying murres pushed inland";"The strange sight of dead seabirds black against the white snows of winter far from their natural habitat has become an all too common occurrence these days along a wilderness snowmobile trail that runs for hundreds of miles into the wild north of Alaska’s largest city.

column1: Worse than the dead birds
column2: though
column3: are the birds seen swimming in the rare pockets of open water along the fast-flowing Susitna and Yentna rivers. These are starving animals still struggling to live
column4: and yet doomed to die prematurely.

column1: Wildlife scientists say the dead and dying birds – 18in tall common murres – are only a few among what might be as many as 100
column2: 000 or more of their species losing the battle to survive in the storm-pounded North Pacific Ocean.

column1: Since late summer
column2: thousands of murres have washed up dead on beaches along the Gulf of Alaska after apparently dying at sea. Others were strong enough to get airborne in fall or winter only to be swept inland as seasonal storms roiled the offshore waters.

column1: An estimated 8
column2: 000 dead murres showed up on the beaches near Whittier
column3: an isolated community of only about 220 people 60 miles south-east of here. Thousands more were found dead near Homer
column4: a popular summer tourist destination 125 miles to the south that is home to about 5
column5: 000 year-round residents.

column1: As yet
column2: no has any clue as to exactly how many carcasses litter the remote and little visited beaches along the hundreds of miles of undeveloped coast that rims the Alaska gulf
column3: according to John Piatt at the Alaska Science Center of the US Geological Survey. The full death count might never be known.

column1: Piatt has spent almost 30 years studying Alaska murres and other seabirds. He has seen big die-offs before. He and other researchers estimated 120
column2: 000 murres died of starvation in the winter of 1993. About 185
column3: 000 were calculated to have perished after being smeared with a mousse-like emulsion of water and oil that spewed out of Prince William Sound and rampaged north across the gulf after the Exxon Valdez oil tanker spilled 11m gallons of crude oil in1989.

column1: What has been different this time is the number of dying murres pushed inland by an oscillating jet stream that has played havoc with Alaska weather for the past two winters. Some blame climate change
column2: but climate experts say it is hard determine whether Alaska is witnessing a long-term shift or only a strange
column3: short-term anomaly in a region where the weather is notoriously unpredictable.

column1: Whichever the case
column2: winds that normally blow west to east across the Pacific have been eddying into a south to north pattern as the atmosphere swirls like a whirlpool in a river. Starving murres still strong enough to get airborne have found themselves caught in warm
column3: moist winds of up to 100mph roaring north out of the gulf into the heart of the 49th state.

column1: Thousands
column2: possibly tens of thousands
column3: of the birds rode these winds until they faded only to find themselves stranded and awaiting death far from their natural habitat. Some birds were pushed over the towering Alaska Range mountains into the bitterly cold Alaska interior hundreds of miles from the sea.

column1: Most
column2: however
column3: came to earth near this city or just to the north in the Matanuska-Susitna Valley. Urban Alaskans rallied to save those found on or adjacent to the state’s few roadways.

column1: The Bird Treatment and Learning Center here has taken in 411 murres since October
column2: said director Guy Runco. In a normal year
column3: the center handles 600 to 700 birds of all species. One or two of them might be murres. “It’s really strange
column4: ’’ Runco said.

column1: Rehabilitating malnourished murres has taxed the center’s finance and its staff of volunteers
column2: and there’s no telling if saving the murres has had any environmental value. Released back into the wild fat and well fed
column3: they could just end up starving again.

column1: Murres need to eat about a fiftieth of their body weight in small fish per day to survive. Piatt and other scientists said the birds are obviously having problems finding enough food. The causes could be a decline in forage fish or simply a shift in where the forage fish feed.
Some have pondered climate change there
column2: too. The forage fish thrive in cold water
column3: and the water in the gulf has been unusually warm this year. It could be the fish declined because of this – or that they moved away from the normal feeding grounds of the murre as they sought cooler waters.

column1: The murre die-off
column2: though dramatic
column3: is not thought to be any threat to the species as a whole given that there are an estimated 2.8 million breeding murres in 230 nesting colonies in Alaska. There are also animals that have benefited from the tragedy of the murres.

column1: “The eagles are eating well
column2: ’’ Runco said. Alaska’s bald eagles are notoriously efficient scavengers. So
column3: too
column4: the state’s ravens
column5: magpies

column1: Jean Gabryszak
column2: whose family runs the remote Yentna Station Roadhouse
column3: said: “The ravens are all fat and happy.’’"

column5: Greenhouse gas emissions";"5";"1452789167000";"1518629255000";"0";"246";"Climate change 'made record UK rainfall in December more likely'";"Study finds global warming made Britain 50-75% more likely to receive catastrophic rainfall that caused floods
column6: but natural variation also played a role";"Climate change made the UK’s record December rainfall
column9: a preliminary scientific investigation has found.

column1: “Greenhouse gas emissions are loading the weather dice towards these warmer
column2: wetter winters
column3: ” said Friederike Otto
column4: scientific coordinator of the climateprediction.net project
column5: which harnessed the collective power of roughly 70
column6: 000 home computers to run thousands of climate models extremely quickly.

column1: The results
column2: which were analysed at the University of Oxford and the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute
column3: showed natural variation was equally influential in stocking the storms with rain and hurling them at northern Britain.

column1: “Chance still played a large role in December’s weather
column2: ” said Otto
column3: pointing to an abnormally large difference in water temperature in the east and west Atlantic. She said the possible contribution of the massive Pacific El Niño was still uncertain.

column1: Throughout the last month of 2015
column2: a succession of brutal storms - Desmond
column3: Eva and Frank - struck the UK. Farmland and towns in Cumbria
column4: Lancashire
column5: Yorkshire and Scotland were submerged in deadly and heartbreaking floods.

column1: It was the wettest December since records began 105 years before. At the same time
column2: the UK average temperature was 8C
column3: 4.1C above normal. The previous warmest December was in 1934 and was 6C on average.

column1: Some of the rainfall can be explained by what is known as the thermodynamic effect. Warm air can carry more water
column2: which means precipitation events become larger and more frequent in a warmed climate. But this had only increased the risk of such a wet December by around 7%.

column1: The study
column2: which was released publicly before being submitted to a scientific journal
column3: simulated a world in which the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere had not occurred and found that in the real world Britain was 50-70% more likely to receive the catastrophic rainfall levels of last month.

column1: Otto postulated that disturbances of atmospheric pressure systems
column2: caused by warming
column3: was responsible for much of the increased risk. But this analysis had not yet been conducted.

column1: The Met Office’s Peter Stott
column2: who was not involved in the study
column3: said it added further credence to the long-held prediction that climate change would bring wetter conditions to some parts of the globe and could be seen as broadly indicative of the role of climate change in the December floods.

column1: “That is robust
column2: ” he said. He said the use of home computers to simultaneously run thousands of experiments dramatically increased the turn around of research
column3: but he cautioned they were not powerful enough to run the most up to date global climate models.

column1: “I think the uncertainty is potentially larger than the 50-75% [indicated in the study]
column2: ” he said. “We are looking at very extreme parts of the calculations and it’s hard to be precise when we are talking about rare events like this.”

column1: Nick Reynard
column2: lead natural hazard scientist at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology
column3: said the picture was further complicated trying to link increased rainfall to flooding.

column1: He said rainfall was known to be generally increasing in the UK
column2: but at the same time “there is little compelling evidence for any upward trend in long records of flood magnitude or frequency”. This counter-intuitive finding was due to the differing ways particular catchments respond to heavy rain; some are known to be highly resistant to large events.

column1: The links between extreme weather and climate change are now widely reported in academic papers. So perhaps more remarkable than the findings themselves
column2: is the speed at which scientists are able to draw links between events. In the past
column3: this work has taken months
column4: even years. Thursday’s preliminary study has been released before the waters have even receded and is one of the fastest such analyses ever conducted.

column1: Scientists told the Age newspaper in Australia last year that they were trying to adapt their responses to events in order to fit with the media cycle. Stott said the inclination to release preliminary results was understandable.
“The media
column2: and people generally
column3: are asking these questions as the flooding is happening or in the immediate aftermath. But we shouldn’t forget that as we seek to have the right policies and advise government about how best to protect ourselves from flooding
column4: for that we need a carefully considered scientific analysis. You’ve got to be careful of over-interpreting very rapid studies
column5: ” he said.

column1: Richard Black
column2: the director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit thinktank said the emergence of attribution science - our ability to find the fingerprints of climate change in individual weather events - was “one of the most exciting developments in the climate change field”.

column1: “Only a few years ago scientists had to make do with saying things like ’this or that weather event is consistent with what we’d expect’ - but now
column2: increasingly
column3: it’s possible to determine whether climate change is increasing the risks of particular weather events
column4: and by how much
column5: ” he said.

column1: “That in turn gives policymakers the economic rationale they need to justify emission reduction programmes
column2: as well as increasing the chances of legal action in future if decision-makers don’t act on the science.”"

column1: Hurricane Alex’s maximum sustained winds were near 85mph (140kmh) and residents of Portugal’s mid-Atlantic Azores islands were warned to expect waves up to 60ft (18 metres) high and wind gusts up to 100mph.
The islands’ Civil Protection Service issued a weather red alert
column2: the highest of four warnings that indicates extreme risk
column3: for five of the archipelago’s nine islands.

column1: The US National Hurricane Center (NHC) in Miami said in a Facebook post there hadn’t been a hurricane present during the month of January since 1955
column2: when Alice formed in late December 1954 and continued into the next month.

column1: The hurricane was centred about 350 miles south of Faial Island in the central Azores and was moving north-north-east at about 22mph. Alex was expected to move near or over parts of the Azores on Friday
column2: the NHC said.

column1: The Azores government on Thursday advised kindergartens to stay closed and told residents to ensure drainage systems were not blocked.
The archipelago
column2: which has a population of about 250
column4: has been threatened by hurricanes before
column5: but they usually lose their strength as they move into colder northern water.

column1: Alex formed only days after a rare event in the Pacific. An El Niño-related tropical storm formed south-west of Hawaii last week. Tropical Storm Pali
column2: only the third such system to develop in January in more than 40 years
column3: had weakened to a depression by Thursday and was expected to dissipate in the next day or so. It never made landfall.

column1: Alex’s formation
column2: however
column3: had nothing to do with El Niño
column4: said Mike Halpert
column5: the deputy director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center in the US.

column1: The NOAA researcher Jim Kossin said the water in which Alex formed was about 1.7C to 2.2C (3F to 4F) warmer than normal

column1: Speaking at a Guardian Sustainable Business debate on the role of business in tackling climate change

column3: herself an outspoken advocate on the issue

column5: I’ve had conversations with CEOs of major corporates in Europe and they just say

column1: One month on from a landmark climate change deal at UN talks in Paris
column2: Garrett-Cox hopes this will be the tipping point for businesses waking up to climate change. Ikea’s sustainability chief Steve Howard agreed
column3: saying 2016 presents the corporate world with “an unprecedented opportunity” to reinvent its business models in line with the challenge.

column1: However
column2: speaking at the event
column3: the UK’s only Green party MP Caroline Lucas said the government was making this transition more difficult: “This is a government that doesn’t like scrutiny ... and that’s part of the whole way it’s going about its green policies.”

column1: The UK government has been widely criticised since its election in May for making a series of changes to environmental policy such as scrapping subsidies for onshore wind
column2: ending the green deal scheme that helps homeowners insulate their homes and cutting support for the solar industry
column3: which has since seen a number of firms going into liquidation.

column1: “What this government is doing in the name of being business friendly is constantly moving the goalposts so that no one knows where it’s going to be safe to invest
column2: ” she said. “The green economy is actually one of the best places to invest for jobs
column3: to enable us to get out of the economic crisis we face as well as to keep emissions down.”

column1: And moving to a green economy means rethinking consumption patterns
column2: especially in the west
column3: according to Howard . “If we look on a global basis
column4: in the west we have probably hit peak stuff. We talk about peak oil. I’d say we’ve hit peak red meat
column5: peak sugar
column6: peak stuff … peak home furnishings. If you look on a global basis
column7: most people are still poor and most people actually haven’t got to sufficiency yet. There is a global growth opportunity ... but it’s a distribution issue.”

column1: Ikea has hit the headlines for introducing a raft of environmental policies in the last year. It has pledged to invest €1bn (£755m) in renewable energy and measures to help poorer communities deal with the impacts of climate change; announced that 100% of the energy used to power its shops and factories will come from clean sources by 2020; and phased out all non-LED lightbulbs from its stores.
Leading climate change scientist Kevin Anderson
column2: from the Tyndall Centre for Climate Research
column3: was more sceptical and said the idea that the green economy would enable people in the west to consume more was irreconcilable with international climate change commitments.

column1: “At a global level – if you want to see any level of equity around the globe – the idea that people like us can consume and see improvements in material wellbeing is to me not compatible with what the science is telling us about climate change … there are real problems if we try to tell people that
column2: actually
column3: if we’re really clever in the wealthy parts of the world that we can have our cake and eat it. That misunderstands the severity of the challenge we’re facing.”

column1: Anderson said that in the future it could be necessary to introduce a shorter working week
column2: he added.

column1: “Under the current model you need growth because there is a pursuit of productivity
column2: which people always say is a good thing. If we have an increase in productivity that means you have fewer people producing the same number of goods. If you want to then maintain employment you have to maintain growth to have the same number of people employed
column3: ” he said.

column1: “So you have to start unpicking all these pieces and saying
column2: ‘Well what would that mean for our society?’ There are different reasons why we might be looking at a world where we have to work fewer hours. We consume fewer goods but we have a higher quality of life in that time that we have available.”

Politicians need to spell out how science will inform their decisions";"Musician Billy Bragg and President Barack Obama would probably enjoy a beer together. “Cynicism is our great enemy
column9: ” said Bragg in a 2010 interview. “If we
column11: can’t overcome our cynicism
column12: then there really is no hope. We just might as well pack up and go home.”

column1: Tuesday night
column2: in his final State of the Union address
column3: Obama spent the majority of his time detailing his legacy and his vision for the nation. The clarion call came towards the end:

column1: It’s easier to be cynical; to accept that change isn’t possible
column2: and politics is hopeless
column3: and to believe that our voices and actions don’t matter. But if we give up now
column4: then we forsake a better future. Those with money and power will gain greater control over the decisions that could send a young soldier to war
column5: or allow another economic disaster
column6: or roll back the equal rights and voting rights that generations of Americans have fought
column9: there will be voices urging us to fall back into tribes
column10: to scapegoat fellow citizens who don’t look like us
column11: or pray like us
column13: or share the same background.

column1: They’re both right. Cynicism creates a toxic environment that makes change and community less possible. We hear it from elected officials who say we can’t grow the economy while protecting the environment. We hear it from those who base their decisions regarding refugees on fear
column2: not data.

column1: The biggest danger
column2: however
column3: comes from our own resignation. We see the deck stacked against us and we give up. We begin to see all government officials and business leaders as part of the same rigged game. We disengage. Nobody wants to be a chump.

column1: So how do we avoid a descent into cynicism? The President’s address offers a few more clues:
Most of all
column2: democracy breaks down when the average person feels their voice doesn’t matter; that the system is rigged in favor of the rich or the powerful or some narrow interest.

column1: Obama alluded several times to reducing money in politics. Money doesn’t necessarily buy votes
column2: but it does buy outsized access to shape the agenda. And as more and more dollars flow into the political system
column3: it has become considerably harder to track where the money is coming from.

column1: Campaign finance reform
column2: however
column3: is not the sole provenance of Congress. There is a step that the President can take right now to create more transparency and accountability: issue an executive order to require federal contractors to disclose their political spending. This move is supported by scores of Democratic legislators. Why won’t he act?

column1: Sixty years ago
column2: when the Russians beat us into space
column3: we didn’t deny Sputnik was up there. We didn’t argue about the science
column4: or shrink our research and development budget. We built a space program almost overnight
column5: and twelve years later
column6: we were walking on the moon.

column1: In the wake of the historic Paris climate agreement The Guardian’s Fiona Harvey called “the world’s greatest diplomatic success
column2: ” governments and companies worldwide are moving forward with plans to cut carbon emissions and move toward more sustainable energy sources.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Congress seems to be moving in the opposite direction. House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith recently attacked the integrity of government climate change scientists
column3: suggesting their research on the surface temperature record was fraudulent. The chairman subpoenaed scientists’ deliberative correspondence
column4: and suggested that the journal Science had some kind of hidden agenda for publishing the peer-reviewed research. He has since temporarily suspended some of his demands. People within Chairman Smith’s party should push back against this behavior
column5: and the Obama administration should continue implement its Climate Action Plan.

column1: Democracy grinds to a halt without a willingness to compromise; or when even basic facts are contested
column2: and we listen only to those who agree with us.

column1: We need presidential candidates to talk more about how science will inform their decisions
column2: and whom they will trust for information. Recently
column3: a group of kids filmed a public service announcement detailing the science-based issues that they want the candidates to address: drinking water
column4: vaccinations
column5: honeybees

column1: The organization that sponsored that announcement
column2: Science Debate
column3: is trying to get the candidates to address these kinds of issues
column4: and the chair of Science Debate
column5: Shawn Otto
column6: has blogged about the initiative at the Guardian Environment blog. The video is worth a watch. And then it’s worth heading over to Science Debate’s website to endorse their effort.

column1: Much of what President Obama said concerns the relationship between evidence and democracy. Societies function better when they can unite around a common knowledge base. We should all reject the path of cynicism and the notion that we should stop using our voices to restore science to its rightful place in society.
Michael Halpern (@halpsci) is manager of strategy and innovation for the Center for Science and Democracy at the Union of Concerned Scientists."

column6: the furthest environmentalists have gone in US using ‘necessity’ defense";"Five environmental activists who failed to convince a court that their attempt to block crude oil trains near Seattle was a legally justifiable act of civil disobedience on Friday were nonetheless praised by a judge as “part of the solution” to climate change.

column1: On Friday
column2: the campaigners were convicted in a court in suburban Seattle of misdemeanor trespassing relating to a September 2014 protest in which they blocked railway tracks used by crude oil trains in Everett
column3: Washington.

column1: They were acquitted of a second count of misdemeanor obstructing a train.
The so-called “Delta 5” – Michael LaPointe
column2: Patrick Mazza
column3: Jackie Minchew
column4: Elizabeth Spoerri and Abigail Brockway – had hoped that their trial would mark the first time that a US jury was allowed to consider the “necessity defense” in a case of climate activism.

column1: The defendants intended to argue that their acts
column2: though illegal
column3: were necessary to prevent the greater harm of catastrophic climate change.

column1: But after allowing two days of expert testimony on topics ranging from the Paris climate talks to railway safety standards and the health impacts of particulate matter
column2: Judge Anthony E Howard ruled that the defense had failed to present sufficient evidence to show that the defendants had “no reasonable legal alternative” to trespassing on a private rail yard and blocking trains.

column1: The case is a blow to environmental campaigners but marks the furthest defendants have managed to go in an American courtroom using the so-called “necessity” defense that argues such actions are justified to combat catastrophic climate change.
The activists progressed unusually far because Howard allowed them to call expert witnesses to testify to the harms of climate change
column2: even though he later felt compelled to instruct the jury to disregard their evidence. The judge appeared to do so reluctantly
column3: expressing some sympathy for the activists in a court on Thursday.

column1: “Frankly the court is convinced that the defendants are far from the problem and are part of the solution to the problem of climate change
column2: ” Howard said from the bench. But
column3: he added: “I am bound by legal precedent
column4: no matter what my personal beliefs might be.”

column1: That precedent
column2: including a per se ban on necessity defenses in cases of indirect civil disobedience by the ninth circuit court of appeals
column3: is overwhelmingly against the idea that such an argument should be available to defendants. After his ruling
column4: the judge directed the jury to disregard the expert testimony on climate change
column5: public health
column6: and the dangers of transporting crude oil by train.

column1: In an act of judicial consolation
column2: Howard added that he hoped the defendants
column3: whom he described as “tireless advocates of the kind that we need more of in this society”
column4: would find “some value in having been able to present their beliefs in a public forum”. He also allowed an extra 10 minutes for lunch on Thursday
column5: in recognition of the fact that he had “just crushed your hopes and dreams”.

column1: Though the necessity defense dominated the proceedings in the courtroom
column2: it is something of a legal oddity that MJ McCallum
column3: Bridge Joyce and Evelyn Chuang – three of the four lawyers on the defense team – recalled learning about in law school through a case of sailors lost at sea who resorted to cannibalism when one of their fellow castaways died of natural causes. (The defendants in Regina v Dudley and Stephens were found guilty when they admitted that they actually murdered the child they ate
column4: but trust a defense team to put a different spin on it.)

column1: Robert Goldsmith was the sole attorney on the defense team to have argued for necessity
column2: which he did successfully
column3: once
column4: in the 1979 case of 20 protesters who blocked the entrance to the Zion nuclear power plant in Waukegan
column5: Illinois.

column1: Despite the odds
column2: however
column3: the necessity defense remains the holy grail for some climate activists.

column1: “We’re going to keep working with folks to keep pushing these defenses
column2: ” said Tim DeChristopher
column3: a climate activist who served 21 months behind bars for a civil disobedience action after a judge refused his attempt to employ the necessity defense.

column1: DeChristopher’s organization
column2: Climate Disobedience Center
column3: is supporting the efforts of another group that was arrested attempting to block a fracked natural gas pipeline in Westchester County
column4: New York. According to DeChristopher
column5: the protesters will try the necessity defense during a bench trial today

column1: The defense has been used successfully in the UK
column2: where a jury acquitted six Greenpeace protesters in 2008 after they argued their occupation and damage to a Kingsnorth coal-fired power station in Kent was justified by the threat of climate change.

column1: Beyond the necessity defense
column2: some climate activists are looking at other strategies in the US to challenge the limitations of statutory law and push for urgent governmental action to limit climate change.

column1: “Our legal principles have to account for the clear
column2: imminent danger perpetrated by the fossil fuel industry
column3: ” said Mary Wood
column4: a professor of environmental law at the University of Oregon.

column1: Wood is an advocate for applying “public trust doctrine” to climate change
column2: arguing that a government has a fundamental responsibility to preserve crucial resources like the land
column3: water
column4: and air that “predates statutory law”.

column1: Michael Foster
column2: who attended the Delta Five trial each day
column3: works with Seattle youth who adopted Wood’s theory and sued the Washington state government for failing to adequately protect the environment for their generation.

column1: “The system is broken enough that we have to pursue every other avenue
column2: ” Foster said.

column1: In December
column2: a judge issued a ruling in the case
column3: which Foster described as “kickass poetry about the constitutional rights of these kids to air
column4: land
column5: and water”.

column1: Though the loss of the necessity defense in this case was a disappointment
column2: DeChristopher remains hopeful that the law will be pushed to take a different view of climate change civil disobedience.

column1: “We understand that precedent is not in our favor
column2: ” he said
column3: “but we also understand that people’s consciences are hard to oppress.” "

column14: says International Renewable Energy Agency";"

column1: Countries can deliver on the promises of the historic Paris climate change agreement by rapid scaling up wind and solar power to 36% of the global energy mix by 2030
column2: an international energy gathering will be told on Saturday.

column1: The International Renewable Energy Agency (Irena) meeting in Abu Dhabi – the first major global gathering since Paris – is seen as an important test of countries’ readiness to put those plans into action.
Nearly 200 countries agreed to keep warming below 2C
column2: and work towards a 1.5C limit
column3: during the Paris climate negotiations last month. Some 187 put forward plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

column1: Now comes the hard part
column2: government officials admit: making good on those promises by translating emissions cutting targets into policies
column3: and expanding access to clean energy technologies.

column1: Irena said those goals were within reach – if countries move fast. Scaling up renewable energy to 36% of the global energy mix by 2030 would provide about half of the emissions reductions needed to hold warming to 2C. Energy efficiency could make up the rest.
“The Paris agreement set a long-term vision for the deep reduction of global emissions and the need to decarbonise the energy sector
column2: ” Adnan Amin
column3: Irena’s director general said in a prepared statement. “The Irena assembly must now take the next steps and establish a blueprint for action to meet our climate goals and set the world on a path to a sustainable energy future.”

column1: In an effort to spur countries to action
column2: an Irena report released on Saturday found doubling the share of renewables by 2030 would increase global GDP by up to 1.1% or about $1.3tn
column3: and provide jobs for more than 24 million in the renewable sector.

column1: The United Nations climate chief
column2: Christiana Figueres
column3: has said repeatedly she was looking to the Paris agreement to send a clear signal to the business community of a shift away from a fossil-fuel driven economy.

column1: Some of those changes are already underway. Global clean energy investment attracted a record $329bn last year
column2: according to a report released on Thursday by Bloomberg New Energy Finance.

column1: The report noted the rise in clean energy investment came despite the drop in oil prices.
Irena officials said they hoped that the Paris climate accord would add momentum to the shift.
“We are not seeing climate change action as a cost
column2: but starting to see it in terms of opportunities
column3: ” said Angela Kallhauge
column4: Irena’s climate change officer. "

column9: showing that ‘if we want to do something we can’";"The Paris climate agreement kindled “a huge flame of hope”
column10: establishing a new model of 21st-century diplomacy
column11: the woman behind the deal has declared.

column1: In her first public reflections on the climate accord signed in December
column2: Christiana Figueres
column3: the UN climate change official
column4: said that after two decades of meandering negotiations
column5: countries had at last discovered their “higher purpose” and risen to the challenge of dealing with global warming.

column1: The Paris agreement
column2: in which 195 countries committed to limiting the temperature increase to well below 2C
column3: set a new standard for dealing with complex global problems
column4: she said.

column1: “Climate change is a very
column2: very good example of how we are moving to a completely new social contract from the last century
column3: ” Figueres told the Guardian at a conference hosted by the International Renewable Energy Agency (Irena) in Abu Dhabi. “The social contract that is going to underpin the 21st century has at least five very
column4: very different ways of dealing with challenges and very different ways of delivering solutions.

column1: “To have Paris is a huge flame of hope. We can really take some confidence from there that if we decide we want to do something
column2: then we can
column3: ” said Figueres
column4: who will step down this summer after guiding the negotiations for six years. “We are not bound by situations we are confronted with. We can rise above them. It’s fantastic.”

column1: A number of key players in the Paris climate deal attended the annual Irena conference at the weekend.

More than 80 countries committed in their climate plans in Paris to expand their use of solar and wind power as a way of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. These countries are now looking for financing and technological assistance to make the switch to cleaner energy sources.
Figueres said countries had overcome multiple faultlines to arrive at a deal in Paris – the divide between rich and poor countries
column2: between the public and private sector
column3: between different regions.

column1: Unlike other negotiations
column2: the Paris climate talks involved governments
column3: business leaders and campaign groups. A number of foreign policy experts have held up Paris as a new model for diplomacy
column4: and commentators have praised the French hosts for skilfully guiding the talks to a successful resolution. “It is the way that we are going to operate increasingly in the 21st century
column5: ” Figueres said.

column1: The agreement abandoned the idea of a traditional international treaty with clear rules and fixed obligations
column2: in recognition that the US would never sign on to an agreement that needed approval from a Republican-controlled Senate.

column1: Instead
column2: the agreement relied on countries to come forward with plans for cutting greenhouse gas emissions and then to review those plans at regular intervals to make even deeper cuts.

column1: Anne-Marie Slaughter
column2: a former US Department of State official and president of the New America Foundation
column3: wrote of the deal in December: “By the standards of a traditional treaty
column4: it falls woefully short. Yet its deficits in this regard are its greatest strengths as a model for effective global governance in the 21st century. The Paris agreement is a sprawling
column5: rolling
column6: overlapping set of national commitments brought about by a broad conglomeration of parties and stakeholders. It is not law. It is a bold move toward public problem-solving on a global scale. And it is the only approach that could work.”

column1: But there have also been a number of high-profile critics of the Paris agreement. James Hansen
column2: the climate scientist
column3: dismissed the agreement as a fraud. Bernie Sanders
column4: the Democratic presidential contender
column5: said the deal went nowhere near far enough.

column1: Figueres said the 31-page agreement had exceeded her expectations. “The surprise for me was actually the clarity of the text and the way in which governments worked with each other to get to common ideas
column2: ” she said. “In previous negotiations
column3: people have got so caught up with the wording itself – this comma
column4: that comma
column5: that verb – that they tripped over themselves and were not able to reach for the stars. In this case they first reached for the stars and then thought: how do we express that?”

column1: She said Paris was the first time in six such climate meetings that she never had a moment when she feared it would all end in a collapse.
“At every other one there was at least one moment in which I thought we are going to lose this whole thing
column2: ” she said. “This was the first time in which it was so evident that there was overwhelming
column3: not just political will
column4: but political determination to actually come to an agreement.”

column1: And not just an agreement for the sake of it
column2: she said. “The overriding current was getting to an agreement that they could all be proud of. It wasn’t just for a photo.”

column1: • Suzanne Goldenberg’s trip to the conference in Abu Dhabi was funded by Irena
column2: the International Renewable Energy Agency."

column7: Politics";"7";"1453126888000";"1518629253000";"0";"200";"Ted Cruz fact check: which temperature data are the best? | Dana Nuccitelli";"Dana Nuccitelli: Ted Cruz’s claim that satellite data are “the best” is unjustified and false";"Satellites don’t measure the Earth’s temperature. Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) and his fellow climate contrarians love the satellite data
column8: but as Carl Mears of the Remote Sensing Systems (RSS) satellite dataset and Ben Santer recently wrote

column1: they are not thermometers in space. The satellite [temperature] data ... were obtained from so-called Microwave Sounding Units (MSUs)
column2: which measure the microwave emissions of oxygen molecules from broad atmospheric layers. Converting this information to estimates of temperature trends has substantial uncertainties.

column1: Scientists process the raw microwave data
column2: applying a model to make numerous adjustments in order to come up with a synthetic estimate of the atmospheric temperature. Climate scientists have identified many errors in the model
column3: and so it’s undergone several major revisions. It’s a complicated process for many reasons discussed in greater detail in this new Skeptical Science myth rebuttal
column4: and by Mears and Santer.

column1: For example
column2: satellites have a limited lifetime and are replaced (so far there have been 10 different satellites with MSUs); the MSU instruments change - they now use advanced MSUs (AMSUs); their orbits drift and decay due to friction; clouds get in the way; they have to isolate the data from the different layers of the atmosphere
column3: etc.

column1: In a recent Senate hearing
column2: Ted Cruz and one of his witnesses
column3: Judith Curry
column4: claimed “the satellite data are the best data we have.” Most experts disagree.

column1: At first blush the claim sounds plausible. After all
column2: satellites are high tech! But how do we decide which data are “the best”? That’s a subjective question
column3: but we can apply some objective criteria to answer it.

column1: For example
column2: as humans
column3: we might consider the temperature where we live (at the Earth’s surface) the most important. Satellites estimate the temperature of the atmosphere
column4: most of which is above us. In fact
column5: as John Christy
column6: who runs the University of Alabama at Huntsville (UAH) satellite dataset recently said

column1: the main product we use now for greenhouse model validation is the temperature of the Mid-Troposphere
The mid-troposphere is the atmospheric layer from about 25
column3: 000 feet
column4: or about 8–15km in altitude. For perspective
column5: the highest point on the Earth’s surface is on Mount Everest at 29
column7: and the highest elevation city in the world is La Rinconada
column11: surface temperature data would be “the best;” better than satellite data because they’re more relevant to people.

column1: Maybe we value the data with the least uncertainty. Because of all the processing
column2: adjustments
column3: and modeling involved in creating the synthetic temperature data
column4: satellite trends have far greater uncertainty than the surface temperature datasets. By this criterion
column5: surface temperature data would again be “the best;” about five times better than satellite data.

column1: Or perhaps we think it’s important that different groups processing the same raw data in different ways arrive at consistent final temperature estimates. This is true for surface temperature data
column2: which are analyzed by NASA
column3: NOAA
column4: the Met Office
column5: Berkeley Earth
column8: and others. These groups all arrive at consistent end results.

column1: On the other hand
column2: different groups processing the same raw satellite data arrive at very different estimates of the warming trend in the atmosphere. By this criterion
column3: again
column4: surface temperatures beat satellites. As Carl Mears has said

column1: I consider [surface temperature datasets] to be more reliable than satellite datasets (they certainly agree with each other better than the various satellite datasets do!).

Maybe we consider it important to measure how much humans are warming the entire planet. Only about 2% of the heat trapped by increased greenhouse effect goes into warming the atmosphere; over 90% goes into warming the oceans. By that criterion
column2: ocean heat content data would be “the best;” far better than satellite data.

column1: One benefit noted by proponents of the satellite data is that it’s validated by weather balloons directly measuring the temperature of the atmosphere. The problem is
column2: the weather balloons indicate that the lower atmosphere has continued to warm in recent years
column3: diverging from the satellite synthetic temperature estimates. That’s not much of an argument in favor of the satellite data.

column1: In fact
column2: the weather balloon data debunks the “no significant warming since 1998” myth that motivates contrarians like Cruz to cherry pick the satellite data in the first place. It’s also worth noting this myth is based on über cherry picking.

column1: So
column2: the surface temperature data are “best” if you value the least uncertain temperature measurements
column3: of the part of the planet where people live
column4: with consistent results among different groups. The ocean heat data content are “best” if you want the most comprehensive measurement of the warming of the Earth.

column1: The satellite data are best … if you want the data that show the least warming.
As Carl Mears notes starting at the 7:35 mark in the above video
Look at all the different datasets. You don’t want to trust only the satellite temperatures
column2: you want to look at the surface temperatures and that sort of thing.

column1: Every other data source paints a consistent picture of global warming – surface thermometers
column2: weather balloons
column3: ocean buoys
column4: and even natural thermometers like rising sea levels
column5: melting land and sea ice
column6: and shifting seasons and species habitats. Even the satellites show a long-term warming trend in the atmosphere.

column1: There is a great irony here. Climate contrarians decry necessary adjustments to raw surface temperature data (even though the adjustments reduce the warming trend)
column2: and have even launched inquiries
column3: accusing scientists of conspiring to manipulate the surface temperature data. Yet they have no qualms with the more numerous and complex adjustments made the satellite data. Contrarians claim that models are worthless
column4: and yet unwaveringly trust the models used to turn microwave detections into synthetic temperature estimates.

column1: There’s excessive “skepticism” applied to the surface temperature data and a serious lack of skepticism of the satellite data. There’s a term that describes this behavior: ‘confirmation bias.’ The data that conflict with contrarian worldviews are rejected
column2: while those that conform to their preconceived biases are accepted.

column1: In the end
column2: Ted Cruz’s claim is rated false by every objective measure."

column9: World news";"9";"1453134603000";"1523728700000";"0";"7";"Will a 'grand bargain' solve the humanitarian funding crisis?";"A new report offers solutions to the growing gap between humanitarian needs and available resources - but can they be put into practice?";"The aptly titled report
column10: Too important to fail from the High Level Panel on Humanitarian Financing was launched in Dubai yesterday. Does it offer viable solutions to the widening gap between humanitarian needs and available resources? Is the “grand bargain” it offers enough to transform a struggling aid system?

column1: All eyes are on humanitarian financing in 2016. The World Humanitarian Summit in May is fast approaching and the launch of the report comes against a backdrop of the displacement of millions of people in Syria
column2: Yemen
column3: South Sudan
column4: Iraq and other disaster and conflict-affected countries. Their suffering reminds us of the need to get this right fast.

column1: The report contains many good ideas; the strongest and most exciting are those that speak to audiences beyond the usual humanitarian crowd. For example
column2: giving middle-income countries access to grants and low-income loans to finance large-scale refugee hosting
column3: working with the insurance industry to adapt its risk-financing strategies to humanitarian situations
column4: and tapping into the billions of dollars generated each year through Islamic social finance.

column1: Few of the initiatives suggested are new – nor does the panel claim they are. Many have been discussed at length by other groups
column2: and already piloted and reviewed in some cases. But seen together for the first time
column3: and presented as compellingly as they are in the report
column4: they have the potential to expand the responsibility to act beyond the narrow confines of the humanitarian community. The recommendations use finance as a driving force to enrich the aid ecosystem and push for institutional changes to bridge the humanitarian and development divide. This challenge is more pertinent than ever today given the increasingly protracted nature of crises around the world.

column1: The “grand bargain” comes at the end of the report and may leave many readers asking whether the deal is radical enough. It proposes that the major donors and largest humanitarian organisations commit to make their spending more flexible
column2: efficient
column3: transparent and effective. The bargain is aimed in particular at the five largest government donors of humanitarian assistance
column4: those that supplied over 60% of the international humanitarian resources in 2014; and the six UN agencies that spent nearly half of it.

column1: The logic is that if the giants can get it right
column2: other donors and aid organisations will follow. But starting here does risk establishing the terms of the bargain in favour of these powerful few and thereby entrenching the concentration of funds even further
column3: rather than encouraging a more diverse and equitable distribution of resources as recommended elsewhere in the report.

column1: There is also the question of those without a seat at the bargaining table. The Gulf states and other emerging donors are clearly a central part of the financing solution. The choice of Dubai for the report launch yesterday reminds us of how important they are. The report is unclear however whether Gulf states are invited to negotiate the terms of the bargain
column2: or to be bound by it. The same goes for international
column3: national and local NGOs – vital links in the chain between UN agencies and crisis-affected populations – who are already asking what their role is in the bargaining process.

column1: The specific components of the bargain also appear to fall short of the panel’s ambition to ensure that resources are found to meet the needs of those most likely to be left behind. We don’t just need more joint assessments between a few big humanitarian agencies
column2: we need a radical rethink of what we know about what makes people vulnerable to crisis in the first place and how to match their needs with the right resources. On transparency
column3: the grand bargain may do something to improve reporting of international humanitarian assistance by a few
column4: but we should aim for more. A bigger vision is required
column5: in which all resources
column6: beyond just international humanitarian resources can be counted.

column1: Turning the grand bargain into a big deal will clearly be a challenge. Vested interests
column2: competition for scarce resources
column3: and the humanitarian-development divide are as old as aid itself. What’s different now
column4: perhaps
column5: is the window of opportunity that the World Humanitarian Summit has created. Responsibility for taking the panel’s recommendations forward now passes from the hands of technical experts to those of the political and financial decision-makers who will be represented en masse in Istanbul in May. This combined with the scale of the problem
column6: and the reputation and clout of the panel members themselves as they go out and canvass support
column7: may be the tipping point that we’ve all been waiting for.

column1: The grand bargain will be a central topic of numerous global-level humanitarian meetings in the coming months. Even more interesting will be to see whether the panel’s recommendations get picked up outside of the humanitarian calendar. Will other actors agree that this is too important to ignore
column2: and that they too have a stake in addressing the humanitarian financing gap? If the answer is yes
column3: then the grand bargain may turn out to be a big deal after all.

column1: Charlotte Lattimer is senior policy and engagement adviser at Development Initiatives.
Join our community of development professionals and humanitarians. Follow @GuardianGDP on Twitter. "

column24: plus the usual smattering of celebrities – including Leonardo DiCaprio – are heading to Davos
column25: the Swiss Alpine resort where the World Economic Forum’s annual conference begins on Tuesday evening. The ensuing four days of debate will focus on the following themes:

column1: The relentless rise of automation and ever more intelligent machines will be a key issue at the WEF.
The official theme of the 2016 meeting is “mastering the fourth industrial revolution”. That
column2: in WEF-speak
column3: means the “fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines between the physical
column4: digital and biological spheres”.

column1: For some Davos attendees
column2: this means business opportunities. Top executives such as Satya Nadella of Microsoft and Facebook’s Sheryl Sandberg will debate how the new industrial revolution could improve industry and society.

column1: But Davos will also look at the threat to white collar jobs
column2: asking if the changes are “failing the middle classes”. Another question is whether we are heading towards “a world without work” – a serious issue given that some experts reckon one in two jobs could eventually be taken by intelligent automation.

column1: More than 7m jobs are at risk in the world’s largest economies over the next five years
column2: according to a WEF report published on Monday
column3: with women losing out more than men as they are less likely to be working in areas where the adoption of new technology will create jobs.

column1: And if the daily trudge through icy Davos does not provide enough shivers
column2: attendees will be told the implications of smart machines going to war. Sir Roger Carr
column3: the chairman of defence giant BAE Systems
column4: will discuss whether robots will become soldiers and generals
column5: along with experts such as Prof Alan Winfield of the University of the West of England.

column1: World leaders and the heads of humanitarian agencies will debate how to address the growing migration crisis and better integrate refugees into the communities who shelter them.
Queen Rania of Jordon will discuss the Middle East turmoil driving millions overseas
column2: as desperate people continue to risk the winter cold and storms by crossing the Mediterranean. The leaders of Iraq and Tunisia are also attending.

column1: The EU foreign affairs chief
column2: Federica Mogherini
column3: and the French minister Emmanuel Macron are to consider whether Europe has been pushed to a tipping point by the crisis and discuss recent terrorist attacks.

column1: John Kerry
column2: the US secretary of state
column3: is giving a keynote speech. Last year
column4: he delivered an electrifying talk on the need to tackle violent extremism and the “monsters” of Islamic State.

column1: But it is not just talk. Delegates can choose to be jolted out of their comfortable existence by spending an hour experiencing a day in the life of a refugee. This has become a regular event at Davos
column2: with some people being moved to tears by a taste of the trauma felt by displaced people. Some former refugees are also on hand to share their stories.

column1: Angela Merkel won’t be signing up
column2: though. With criticism over her refugee policies rising by the day
column3: the chancellor is skipping this year’s event. So Germany’s president
column4: Joachim Gauck
column5: will be carrying the black

column1: The stock market rout of 2016 has already made a small dent in the large fortunes of the Davos elite. So there will be plenty of nervous chatter about whether we are heading into a new crash – and whether it can be fended off.
The big worry
column2: of course
column3: is China
column4: with its slowing economy and swelling credit levels. One of the Chinese government’s top market regulators
column5: Fang Xinghai

column9: Tony Abbott";"9";"1453191551000";"1520960837000";"0";"204";"Outgoing chief scientist Ian Chubb says tougher greenhouse gas targets inevitable";"Chubb also says hostility towards climate science may be easing but scientists still have a duty to offer unflinching advice";"Australia’s chief scientist through the bitter “climate wars” has some advice for scientists denigrated and disparaged by those who do not like their evidence-based advice: “don’t flinch”.

column1: And as he prepares to leave the job on Friday
column2: Ian Chubb has some unflinching parting advice – Australia will inevitably have to adopt tougher greenhouse gas reduction targets.

column1: Chubb is also on the board of the independent Climate Change Authority
column2: which the Abbott government unsuccessfully sought to abolish
column3: and he is convinced Australia will eventually have to adopt targets similar to those advocated by the CCA.

column1: The CCA found Australia should be cutting emissions by between 40 and 60% by 2030
column2: measured against 2000 levels. Measured the same way the target announced by Tony Abbott and then adopted by Malcolm Turnbull equates to a cut of between 19 and 22%.

column1: “That was solid work and I stand by those recommended targets
column2: ” Chubb said in an interview with Guardian Australia.

column1: He said the continuing process set up under the Paris international climate agreement
column2: struck late last year
column3: and Australia’s particular susceptibility to the effects of global warming
column4: meant “we will have to reconsider our target
column5: I cannot see how we could possibly not”.

column1: The Turnbull government has not ruled out increasing its targets as a result of the five-yearly reviews required under the Paris deal but has said it has no plans to do so.
Chubb recalls that he had “a lot of pushback” during the first few months of the Abbott government
column2: “the emails from the usual suspects
column3: people like Maurice Newman [who headed Abbott’s business advisory committee] who continue to believe [climate change] is all some vast conspiracy involving thousands of scientists around the world”.

column1: In 2014 Chubb suggested Newman should “stick to economics rather than “trawl the internet” for papers questioning the overwhelming scientific opinion on global warming.
But Chubb said his conversations with the former prime minister himself had always been “rational and reasonable.”

“I was surprised at some of Tony Abbott’s public comments about climate change and some of his government’s initial responses and policies ... because [Abbott] and I talked about climate change quite rationally and reasonably
column2: ” Chubb said.

column1: “He didn’t necessarily agree with me
column2: we tried to persuade one another
column3: but his questions were primarily about the modelling and the sensitivity of the climate to CO2 and how to build policy around the range of the projections.”

column1: He also referred to a controversy over claims of threats against climate scientists at the Australian National University
column2: where he had been chancellor.

column1: “I was also questioned in the early stages because there was a suggestion that some scientists at the ANU had received death threats
column2: ” Chubb said.

column1: “I never said there had [been] death threats but their offices were open to the street and I thought it sensible to move them to offices accessed with a swipe card. The Australian newspaper spent a long time running FOIs [freedom of information requests] on that. I think they wanted to prove that I’d somehow timed the release of the information for a particular purpose
column2: which was of course ludicrous.”

column1: But Chubb says the antagonism towards climate science was easing.
“The debate here and overseas is much more sensible now
column2: the sheer weight of scientific evidence is having a bearing
column3: ” he said.

column1: He said he had also been deeply disappointed by the science funding cuts announced in Abbott’s first budget but was happy that the last budget and the recent innovation statement had seen some “selective reinvestment”.
Chubb will be succeeded by Dr Alan Finkel
column2: an engineer and former neuroscience research fellow who has served as the chancellor of Monash University since 2008. Chubb has been chief scientist since 2011.

column1: Catriona Jackson
column2: the chief executive officer of Science and Technology Australia
column3: thanked Chubb for his advocacy.

column1: “There have been some difficult times for science and scientists in the past decade from virulent well-organised climate scepticism to a lack of interest in science
column2: ” she said. “The fact that that has turned around in Australia is very significantly attributable to Ian Chubb and his relentless energy.”

column1: The industry minister

column3: congratulated him on his “excellent term”.
