column6: Greenhouse gas emissions";"6";"1453240800000";"1526040719000";"0";"13";"How big cities are finding innovative ways to nudge people to ditch cars";"Governments and public agencies are increasingly partnering with the private sector in the fight against climate change";"Home to more than half of the planet’s 7 billion people and a large portion of its 1.2bn cars
column7: cities face a huge challenge as the world strives to meet the Paris climate goal of limiting global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels. Cutting emissions in cities is critical: they make up only 2% of the world’s total land area
column8: but produce up to 70% of its climate emissions from human activity
column9: according to a 2011 United Nations report.

column1: As they work to reduce emissions
column2: governments and public agencies – which often lack the resources to tackle the weighty global warming problem alone – are increasingly looking to the private sector for help
column3: says Robert Puentes
column4: a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution’s Metropolitan Policy Program thinktank.

column1: “Tackling climate change – particularly from a transportation perspective – will require these kinds of partnerships largely because traditional governments and public agencies are underperforming
column2: ” Puentes said. “The public sector often does not have the capacity or expertise to design
column3: finance
column4: execute and sustain policies that work
column5: so these partnerships are helping fill the vacuum with a new kind of problem solving.”

column1: In one of the most recent examples
column2: the C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group
column3: a consortium of the world’s largest cities
column4: has enlisted an unusual partner to help reduce tailpipe emissions: MasterCard. It’s one of the largest public-private partnerships aimed at fighting climate change so far.

column1: The consortium – which includes more than 80 cities around the world
column2: including London
column3: Bangkok
column4: Cape Town
column5: New York and San Francisco – says its members collectively emit over 300m tons of carbon dioxide per year from transportation alone
column6: or close to Poland’s total emissions from fossil fuels.

column1: The partnership
column2: announced last month
column3: will set up what’s called a mobility management network
column4: which will connect city staff members to each other and to experts to come up with ideas to nudge people to use public transportation more often.

column1: “These types of measures are all relatively low-cost
column2: compared to investing in a new transport infrastructure
column3: and are therefore of interest to a number of cities
column4: ” says Gunjan Parik
column5: director of C40’s Transportation Initiative. “They also allow money to flow back into city coffers to deliver further improvements to public transit.”

column1: Through face-to-face workshops and other events
column2: as well as virtually through webinars
column3: phone calls and a private online forum
column4: cities and transportation experts will have ample opportunities to share their knowledge and brainstorm for answers on topics including parking
column5: ticketing
column6: congestion and integrating different modes of transportation.

column1: MasterCard is working with cities to enable commuters to pay for bus and subway fares more easily
column2: instead of needing to buy tickets in a separate step or having to carry cash or exact change. In London
column3: for example
column4: the company has helped create a system in which riders can use contactless bank cards or mobile phones to pay for fares.

column1: “Around 85% of the world’s transactions are still done in cash
column2: which not only weighs as an inconvenience and a cost on our economies
column3: but also facilitates crime
column4: ” says Hany Fam
column5: president of MasterCard Enterprise Partnerships. A study by Tuft University found that using cash costs American society about $200bn per year
column6: from fees paid for using ATMs to lost tax revenues from unreported transactions.

column1: C40 officials said their approach to solving transportation problems has achieved success in other initiatives. San Francisco created SFpark programme
column2: which adjusts meter and garage pricing according to demand
column3: helps drivers find available parking spaces quickly and reduces air pollution and congestion in the process. Milan’s Area C programme
column4: which requires each vehicle that enters the city center on weekdays to pay a roughly €5 ($5.46) congestion charge
column5: reduced the number of cars entering the restricted area by nearly one third this year compared to 2011

column1: According to Fam
column2: the success of the initiative with MasterCard will be measured over the next three years by looking at the number of lessons shared and adopted between cities and assessing how much these sustainable transportation projects contribute to the reduction of carbon emissions in cities.

column1: “The biggest thing we can do to truly make a difference in terms of emissions is to get people out of single occupancy vehicles and using whatever combination of bike sharing
column2: walking
column3: shuttles and so on
column4: ” said Sharon Feigon
column5: executive director of the Shared Use Mobility Center
column7: public interest organization which advocates for car- and bike-sharing. “All of these modes together are enormously more efficient than the private automobile.”

column1: While new payment systems can greatly improve the public transportation system
column2: they alone aren’t enough to nudge people to forego driving or owning cars. Finding the right strategies to encourage people to take buses and trains is a big challenge. It remains to be seen whether simpler payments and better communication will make a significant difference.

column1: “Information and technology transfer is very important in the adoption of shared mobility concepts
column2: ” said Susan Shaheen
column3: adjunct professor and co-director of the Transportation Sustainability Research Center at the University of California
column4: Berkeley.

column1: “It’s going to take many different strategies to accomplish these goals
column2: and we need a vast set of transportation options.”"

column12: Davos 2016";"12";"1453266009000";"1518628769000";"0";"58";"Climate change fails to top list of threats for business leaders at Davos";"Geopolitical uncertainty
column13: over-regulation and cyber attacks among biggest threats to business
column14: according to survey of CEOs published at Davos";"The high profile UN summit on climate change in Paris appears to have had little impact on the decision making and worries of global business leaders.

column1: Despite concerns about its impact on extreme weather events
column2: such as recent flooding in the UK
column3: climate change failed to register near the top of the list of business threats
column4: according to a survey of 1
column5: 400 CEOs from around the world compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) and published at Davos this week.

column1: Instead
column2: over-regulation was listed as the biggest threat to business (by 79% of CEOs)
column3: followed by geopolitical uncertainty (74%) and other key threats including cyber attacks (61%).

column1: In contrast
column2: climate change and environmental damage was mentioned as a threat to business growth by just 50% of CEOs.

column1: The findings were similar to a separate survey of 13
column2: 000 business leaders produced by the World Economic Forum (WEF). It also found a relative absence of concern about climate change and environmental risk amongst business leaders.

column1: Business leaders from developed countries listed fiscal crisis and cyber-attacks as their biggest concerns
column2: while in emerging and developing economies the biggest concern was unemployment
column3: underemployment and energy price shocks. “No executive considers failure of climate mitigation and adaptation as the number one risk for doing business in his/her country
column4: ” states the report.

column1: By contrast
column2: a wider survey of economists
column3: academics and civil society also produced by the WEF listed climate change as the biggest potential threat to the global economy in 2016. A failure of climate change mitigation and adaptation was seen as likely to have a bigger impact than the spread of weapons of mass destruction
column4: water crises
column5: mass involuntary migration and a severe energy price shock.

column1: PwC suggested that contrary to its findings CEOs were concerned about the impact of climate change. “We don’t believe a low score in one question reflects overall thinking and action on it
column2: ” a spokesperson told the Guardian. “A quarter of all CEOs included ‘reduced environmental impacts’ in the three outcomes that should be joint government and business priorities in the countries in which they are based... and they are showing greater understanding of environmental impacts in their business and supply chain.”

column1: PwC said the results from this year’s survey also revealed a higher level of concern of climate change amongst CEOs than they did after the UN summit on climate change in Copenhagen in 2009 (50% vs 37%)."

5cc18e1ca2c3615169989ec0;"article";"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jan/20/heathrow-third-runway-protesters-trial-freedom-fighters";"George Monbiot";"1";"Opinion";"Heathrow third runway
column2: Heathrow airport

column10: UK news";"10";"1453273211000";"1518628768000";"0";"200";"Heathrow ‘hooligans’ are our modern day freedom fighters | George Monbiot";"The trial of 13 climate protesters is not really about aviation
column11: it highlights a glaring democratic deficit";"They have been reviled as vandals
column12: hooligans and lunatics. But to me
column13: these people are heroes. The 13 women and men on trial this week for cutting through the perimeter fence around Heathrow airport and chaining themselves together on a runway were excoriated by police
column14: passengers and politicians. (One of the defendants in the case is a member of the cooperative society that rents my house.) If convicted
column15: they all face a possible prison sentence. But there are two trials here: the legal proceedings in a local magistrates court
column16: and a test of something much bigger.

column1: Aviation enjoys some astonishing exemptions from the civilising rules that constrain other sectors. Other industries must limit the noise they make; but aircraft
column2: thanks to an obscure clause in the 1949 Civil Aviation Act
column3: are exempt. Other industries pay duty on the fuel they use; but even when air passenger duty is subtracted
column4: aviation’s various tax holidays amount to a subsidy of some £7bn a year
column5: forgone by the Treasury. Some industries must limit the air pollution they produce; but while in principle airports are subject to pollution laws
column6: in practice they have been allowed to breach them routinely for years. (In this case the legal immunity also seems to extend to motor traffic.)

column1: Most importantly
column2: international flights are free from all climate constraints. They are covered by neither domestic legislation nor international agreements. There are no targets
column3: no timetables
column4: no limits. Airlines operate in a legislative vacuum
column5: a transnational
column7: accountable nowhere and to no one. As a result they threaten everything that was agreed at December’s climate talks in Paris.

column1: Aviation accounts for roughly 6% of the UK’s greenhouse gas emissions
column2: and 2% of the carbon dioxide produced by people globally. But as this industry expands while emissions from other sectors are cut
column3: a study commissioned by the European parliament expects it to produce 22% of the world’s CO2 emissions by 2050
column4: unless there is a sharp change in policy. That’s enough to push us past the thresholds our governments promised to avoid.

column1: At one point the draft Paris agreement contained a paragraph about aviation and shipping (another unregulated industry). By December this paragraph had disappeared
column2: without public explanation or debate. The final agreement simply fails to mention either industry.

column1: Governments left the issue instead to the UN’s International Civil Aviation Organisation
column2: a body whose apparent purpose is not to make progress but to impede it. Dominated by the industry it is supposed to regulate
column3: its work is an exercise in finely calibrated uselessness: it makes just enough noise to create the impression of something being done
column4: without actually changing anything.

column1: It has three main policies. The first is to offset the greenhouse gases planes release by encouraging other sectors to make bigger cuts
column2: in lieu of those that aviation refuses to accept. It’s not just that this policy is likely to be unachievable
column3: as the targets agreed for other sectors in Paris will be tough enough to reach. It is also unjust. Why should this sector
column4: used mostly by the world’s richer people
column5: be allowed to dump its responsibilities on the rest of the economy?

column1: The second is replacing mineral jet fuel with biofuel. Already road fuels made from plants have helped to destroy the forests of Indonesia and west Africa
column2: strip soil off the land
column3: evict local farmers and spread starvation
column4: as plantations of palm oil
column5: maize
column6: sugar cane and other crops grown to feed cars have replaced those grown to feed people. Already
column7: governments envisage covering great tracts of the planet’s surface with energy crops to burn in power stations: a plan that’s as fanciful as it is destructive. Now they want to power planes this way as well? Will any corners of the planet be reserved for food production and wildlife?

column1: The organisation’s third policy is promoting speculative and often unfeasible aviation technologies
column2: that are highly unlikely to materialise. Perhaps we could call them mumbo-jumbo jets.

column1: Because of the physical and technological constraints
column2: the only way in which we can realistically reduce aviation’s greenhouse gases is to fly less. You might not have imagined
column3: in the 21st century
column4: that we would still need to hoist 180lb of human flesh 30
column5: 000 feet into the air every time we want a conversation. I’ve been limiting my own flights to one return ticket every three years. Yes
column6: it has sometimes cost me opportunities and income
column7: but this restraint has made me no less happy or fulfilled. If we can only challenge our sense of entitlement
column8: I believe we inflict no damage on our lives by taking to the air less often.

column1: But rather than seeking to manage demand
column2: our government
column3: like most others
column4: aims only to meet its own inflated forecasts. It claims that the 219m passenger journeys through the UK’s airports in 2011 will rise to 445m by 2050
column5: and it hopes to build enough capacity to accommodate them. In doing so
column6: it vitiates every promise it has made about preventing climate breakdown.

column1: Last month the government delayed its decision on a third runway at Heathrow
column2: ostensibly because of concerns about local pollution (though the real reason was to avoid sabotaging the Conservative candidate’s campaign to become London mayor). But this represents no change in policy: Cameron intends to build the new capacity somewhere
column3: even if it’s not in west London.

column1: Each of aviation’s exemptions is a democratic deficit: a failure to hold the industry responsible for the harms it causes. So what are citizens to do
column2: where the writ of government does not run? Sit back and watch? By doing so
column3: we commit a disservice to democracy. A breach of the contract between state and citizens becomes normalised and ratified by our inaction.

column1: Two verdicts will emerge from this trial. One will concern the legal status of what the protesters did
column2: and there is no way of knowing what it will be. The other will concern the moral status. I suspect that if they are locked up then history will pass the same verdict upon them as it has passed upon suffragettes
column3: Chartists
column4: the pioneers of trade unionism
column5: and civil and gay rights activists. Vilified
column7: but – in the court of public opinion – ultimately vindicated: this is what happens to the heroes of democracy."

column11: Climate change";"11";"1453279634000";"1518628768000";"0";"200";"Leonardo DiCaprio savages corporate greed of big oil: 'Enough is enough'";"Solution to climate change is to keep fossil fuels in the ground
column12: Hollywood star tells World Economic Forum in Davos";"Leonardo DiCaprio has launched a ferocious attack on the greed of the world’s energy industry at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

column1: DiCaprio used an awards ceremony to demand more action on climate change
column2: decrying those who deny it is a problem. And he insisted fossil fuels must be kept in the ground – backing a campaign launched by the Guardian last year.

column1: After picking up a crystal award for his work on environmentalism
column2: the actor explained he had seen the devastation caused by climate change firsthand
column3: from melting glaciers in the Arctic to farmers whose crops had been washed away.

column1: DiCaprio is tipped for Oscar success this year for his role in the bleak and gritty drama The Revenant. And he gave energy bosses a similar savaging.
In front of world leaders
column2: business chiefs and campaigners
column3: DiCaprio said:

column1: We simply cannot afford to allow the corporate greed of the coal
column2: oil and gas industries to determine the future of humanity. Those entities with a financial interest in preserving this destructive system have denied
column3: and even covered up the evidence of our changing climate.

column1: Enough is enough. You know better. The world knows better. History will place the blame for this devastation squarely at their feet.”
The solution to limiting global warming
column2: he added
column3: is to leave oil
column4: gas and coal reserves alone:

column1: Our planet cannot be saved unless we leave fossil fuels in the ground where they belong. Twenty years ago
column2: we described this problem as an addiction. Today
column3: we possess the means to end this reliance.”

column1: DiCaprio also announced that his foundation was making $15m of fresh grants to support environmental protection. That includes funding to protect 6.5 million acres of rainforest on Sumatra from the “invasive and destructive practices” of the palm oil industry.
DiCaprio was one of four winners of a Crystal award at WEF this year. The fund also recognised Chinese actor Yao Chen for her work raising public awareness of the refugee
column2: artist Olafur Eliasson
column3: and musician will.i.am for his i.am angel Foundation
column4: which tries to keep young underprivileged young people in education
column5: and out of trouble.

column1: Accepting his award
column2: will.i.am joked he had grown up near gangs
column3: but had kept out of them as he was more scared of his mother than the gang leaders. His dream is that a child in one of America’s poorest regions could become the next tech pioneer."

column8: Science";"8";"1453287607000";"1518631741000";"0";"200";"A striking resemblance between testimony for Peabody Coal and for Ted Cruz | John Abraham";"John Abraham: Contrarian witnesses made many of the same arguments in a court case for the world’s largest private-sector coal company as they did in Ted Cruz’s senate hearing";"In a recent congressional hearing
column9: Ted Cruz (one of the leading candidates for the Republican presidential nomination) first asked us to follow the science
column10: and then misused and abused the very science he reportedly admires. The contrarian scientists that were invited to testify are members of a shrinking tribe that every year has to work harder to deny the clear evidence of a human-caused warming world.

column1: Those scientists were William Happer
column2: Judith Curry
column3: and John Christy. They argued that the Earth isn’t warming (or has slowed its warming) or that satellite temperature measurements are the best way to measure the Earth’s temperatures. In fact
column4: satellites don’t measure temperature at all
column5: but these witnesses didn’t mention that fact.

column1: Additionally
column2: the satellite measurements that they showed are from the middle of the troposphere
column3: high in the atmosphere (not at the surface). Finally
column4: the contrarians declined to emphasize that the synthetic satellite temperature data have been wrong for years. The upper part of the atmosphere (stratosphere) is cooling as a result of the increased greenhouse gases while the lower layer (the troposphere) is warming. If any measurements of the stratosphere bleed into the measurements of the troposphere
column5: it can cause a cooling bias.

column1: I had the (dis)pleasure of testifying at a hearing in Minnesota where William Happer also testified. He
column2: Roy Spencer
column3: and Richard Lindzen all made errors in their testimony that were repeated at the Cruz congressional hearing. At the Minnesota hearing
column4: these contrarians were representing Peabody Energy – the world’s largest private sector coal company.

column1: They focused on high-altitude temperatures in the tropical part of the globe (near the equator) rather than temperatures at the surface or in the oceans. But it gets even worse – they combined two sets of satellite data into a single curve when in reality
column2: satellite temperature measurements differ by as much as a factor of four depending on whose data you use!

column1: The figure below is nearly identical to Figure 9 Exhibit 2 in Richard Lindzen’s direct testimony
column2: and similar to Figure 3 in Exhibit 2 to Roy Spencer’s Direct Testimony. You can see the schedule for the testimony here and access the filed court documents. My rebuttal testimony is available here and my surrebuttal is here. Climate scientist Andrew Dessler also testified at the hearing and his reports can be found here and here.

column1: As I wrote last year and submitted in my court filings
column2: the table below shows the huge spread amongst various satellite measurements. Why didn’t the contrarians point this out? Why do they only use the coldest two datasets? Why didn’t Roy Spencer tell the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission that his work has been found to be wrong multiple times?

column1: Why does this Peabody Coal case in Minnesota matter? Well
column2: the same arguments were made by Ted Cruz and his contrarian witnesses in December in Washington DC. You can watch the video here. You can read John Christy’s testimony here. You can read Judith Curry’s written testimony here. The similarity between this group of contrarian documents is shocking. It is almost as if portions of their testimony were cut and paste.

column1: I am not really surprised the Ted Cruz would question climate science. And I am not surprised the well-known contrarians Judith Curry
column2: John Christy
column3: William Happer
column4: Roy Spencer
column5: and Richard Lindzen continue to question the mainstream expert consensus. I am not really surprised that some of these scientists are representing fossil fuel companies in litigation or hearings. What I am surprised about is that they are being so selective in presenting data and not telling the full story.

column1: For instance
column2: why don’t Roy Spencer and John Christy tell these judges and panels that they have had to revise their own temperature estimates several times over the past two decades when other scientists identified errors in their model? They originally claimed that the atmosphere was cooling
column3: and now their data shows it is warming.

column1: Why do these contrarians mislead by only showing some groups’ satellite temperature estimates while omitting others? Why do they neglect temperature measurements in the oceans and Earth’s surface where the warming is clear? Why do they falsely claim that there has been a halt or even a slowdown in overall global warming when no such halt or even slowdown has occurred
column2: and in fact the warming is accelerating?

column1: Why do some of these witnesses refer to their own publications after they were shown to be hugely in error
column2: containing undergraduate-level math errors? Why don’t these contrarians and Ted Cruz tell us that the referenced satellite temperature recording team (Remote Sensing Systems) disagree with the way their dataset is being used?

column1: I invite readers to view this great video created by Peter Sinclair which includes interviews from many real experts who discuss this very issue in a clear and understandable way.
It will be interesting to see what the next contrarian argument is. They have retreated to higher and higher elevations in the atmosphere to run away from the reality of global warming. At some point
column2: you’d expect they will reach escape velocity."

column11: Nasa and Noaa data all confirm record global temperatures for second year running";"2015 smashed the record for the hottest year since reporting began in 1850

column1: Data released on Wednesday by the UK Met Office shows the average global temperature in 2015 was 0.75C higher than the long-term average between 1961 and 1990
column2: much higher than the 0.57C in 2014
column3: which itself was a record. The Met Office also expects 2016 to set a new record
column4: meaning the global temperature records will have been broken for three years running.

column1: Temperature data released in the US on Wednesday by Nasa and by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (Noaa) also showed 2015 shattered previous records.

Experts warned that the record-breaking heat shows global warming is driving the world’s climate into “uncharted territory” and that it showed the urgency of implementing the carbon-cutting pledges made by the world’s governments in Paris in December.
Heatwaves have scorched China
column2: Russia
column3: Australia
column4: the Middle East and parts of South America in the last two years
column5: while climate change made the UK’s record December rainfall

column1: The Paris agreement commits the world’s nations to limit warming to below 2C compared to pre-industrial times
column2: or 1.5C if possible
column3: to avoid widespread and dangerous impacts. But the Met Office data
column4: when compared to global temperatures before fossil fuel burning took off
column5: shows that 2015 was already 1C higher.

column1: A strong El Niño event is peaking at the moment
column2: putting the “icing on the cake” of high global temperatures. El Niño is a natural cycle of warming in the Pacific Ocean which has a global impact on weather. But scientists are clear that the vast majority of the warming seen in 2015 was due to the emissions from human activity.

column1: “Even without an El Niño
column2: this would have been the warmest year on record
column3: ” said Prof Gavin Schmidt
column4: director at Nasa’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies. He said he expected the long trend of rising global temperatures to continue because its principal cause – fossil fuel burning – was also continuing.

column1: “It is clear that human influence is driving our climate into uncharted territory
column2: ” said Prof Phil Jones
column3: from the University of East Anglia’s Climatic Research Unit
column4: which produces the temperature record – called HadCRUT4 – with the Met Office. Peter Stott
column5: at the Met Office’s Hadley Centre
column6: said 2015 was the first year global average temperature was more than 1C above pre-industrial levels.

column1: Noaa’s global temperature records stretch back to 1880 and it also found 2015 was the hottest year yet
column2: beating the previous high by a record margin. The agency also found December was warmer than any other month in the record
column3: when compared to long-term averages. Ten of the 12 months in 2015 had record high temperatures for their respective months
column4: according to Noaa.

column1: Nasa’s new data for 2015 also shattered its previous record and showed 15 of the 16 warmest years on record have occurred since 2001.
“Climate change is the challenge of our generation
column2: ” said Nasa head Charles Bolden. “Today’s announcement is a key data point that should make policymakers stand up and take notice - now is the time to act.”

column1: The Nasa
column2: Noaa and HadCRUT4 temperature records all use independent methods to calculate the global average. They use many thousands of temperature measurements taken across the globe
column3: on land and at sea
column4: each day.

column1: There are uncertainties in the measurements
column2: partly due to fewer measurements in the polar regions
column3: and these are included in the calculations. Stott said: “Remaining uncertainties are clearly much smaller than the overall warming seen since pre-industrial times.” Another independent temperature record
column4: from the Japan Meteorological Agency
column5: indicates 2015 was by far the hottest year on record.

column1: Bob Ward
column2: at the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change at the London School of Economics
column3: said: “This [record heat] should put pressure on governments to urgently implement their commitments to act against climate change
column4: and to increase their planned cuts of greenhouse gases. The warming is already affecting the climate around the world
column5: including dangerous shifts in extreme weather events. Those who claim that climate change is either not happening
column7: have been conclusively proven wrong by the meteorological evidence around the world.”

column1: Despite constantly rising greenhouse gas emissions trapping ever more heat on Earth
column2: the last decade has seen relatively slow warming of air temperatures
column3: dubbed a “pause” in climate change by some. In fact
column4: global warming had not paused at all.

column1: Instead
column2: natural climate cycles led to more of the trapped heat being stored in the oceans (which already absorbed most the heat)
column3: some of which El Niño is now releasing. Scientists usually assess changes in climate over decades
column4: rather than years
column5: and the each of the last four decades has been warmer than any decade on record before.

column1: “It’s the long term warming trend we need to worry about rather than one hot year
column2: ” said Prof Piers Forster
column3: at the University of Leeds in the UK. “So we shouldn’t get too excited - but it is certainly a sign of things to come.”"

column4: which means that not supporting wind means higher bills for consumers.

column2: the committee on climate change
column3: says onshore wind is cost competitive with new gas and subsidy-free
column4: and that offshore wind will become cheaper than gas during the next decade.”"

column1: 5cc18e5ca2c3615169989ecb;"article";"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jan/21/uber-lyft-helping-hurting-environment-climate-change";"Kate Galbraith";"1";"Environment";"Climate change

column6: US news";"6";"1453377608000";"1518629249000";"0";"9";"Are Uber and Lyft helping or hurting the environment?";"Berkeley researchers will get unprecedented access to data from both companies and riders to analyze if on-demand ride services are climate friends or foes";"Are on-demand ride services like Uber and Lyft good or bad for the environment? It’s an increasingly urgent question as the services proliferate
column7: but the answer is currently unclear .

column1: The companies have held their data close and are only now beginning to share
column2: making it hard to assess critical questions like how people would have gotten to their destinations if Uber and Lyft did not exist.

column1: A few researchers are making headway. A team at the University of California
column2: Berkeley
column3: is looking into the climate impacts of Uber and Lyft
column4: with results due out in the fall. Unusually
column5: the researchers will get access to data from both companies and

column1: Susan Shaheen
column2: a Berkeley adjunct professor whose team is working on the project in partnership with the Natural Resources Defense Council
column3: says: “With the companies
column4: one of the most important things is to gain access to those members.”

column1: Key questions for the Berkeley study include how long the trips are (as well as the time driving to pick up a passenger); whether the rider would otherwise have driven alone
column2: taken public transportation or not have taken the trip at all; and the fuel efficiency of the vehicles involved.

column1: The researchers will not look at congestion or at conventional air pollutants (such as nitrogen oxides or fine particles) generated by the vehicles. “There’s a lot of different angles that we could be studying here
column2: ” Shaheen says.

column1: Everyone has an opinion on Uber and Lyft
column2: but research results can be surprising. In New York City
column3: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration feared that Uber was worsening traffic congestion in New York. But a report released by the city this month found that on-demand ride services like Uber and Lyft “did not drive the recent increase in congestion” in parts of Manhattan. The displacement of taxis was an important effect of the services.

column1: In terms of the environment
column2: early research suggests that companies like Lyft and Uber may have a positive impact
column3: according to Juan Matute
column4: a transportation expert at the University of California
column5: Los Angeles. That’s partly because people may take public transit more often if they are certain they can later use a ride service. For example
column6: someone might take a commuter train to work rather than drive because they know they can get home even if they miss the last train.

column1: Some people also use Uber and Lyft to get to or from public transportation. “In some cases 25% of trips in a region (or more) start or end near transit
column2: including such places as New York City
column3: Connecticut
column4: New Jersey
column5: and Philadelphia
column6: ” an Uber spokesperson said in an emailed comment.

column1: However
column2: some people take trips with Uber or Lyft when they might have stayed home
column3: which is bad for the environment. In 2014
column4: Shaheen and other Berkeley researchers found that 8% of 380 passengers surveyed in San Francisco used on-demand ride services to take trips they would not have taken otherwise. On the other hand
column5: half of all ride-service trips in the survey carried more than one passenger – that’s a far higher rate than for taxis. (However
column6: the 2014 Berkeley survey was carried out before carpooling services like UberPool and Lyft Line launched in San Francisco. Those services
column7: which bring together strangers in a shared ride
column8: may be the services’ most effective tool for cutting emissions.)

column1: The environmental calculus could change in the future
column2: according to Matute. Currently
column3: he said
column4: it’s more expensive to use Uber or Lyft than to drive one’s own car. If the ride services became dramatically cheaper – which could happen if the vehicles contained advertising or eventually became self-driving – trips with the ride companies would become even more popular than they otherwise would have been.

column1: Right now
column2: “it’s still very expensive for somebody to exclusively rely on these services in any market”
column3: Matute said.

column1: Another factor is the type of car used by Uber and Lyft drivers. Some people hypothesize that since Lyft and Uber require cars to be relatively new – with the oldest models being from 2004 or 2005 – they may be less polluting than the vehicles owned by the general population
column2: since cars in the United States are more than 11 years old on average. (The owners of Uber and Lyft cars also have an incentive for fuel-efficiency
column3: since they must pay for gas.)

column1: The car companies
column2: unsurprisingly
column3: are bullish on their environmental impact. “By using Lyft to share rides
column4: passengers are helping to reduce the carbon footprint left by our country’s dominant mode of transportation – driving alone
column5: ” said Tommy Hayes
column6: the transportation policy manager at Lyft
column7: in an emailed statement. Lyft will also help accelerate the uptake of green technologies like electrification and vehicle automation

column1: Uber emphasizes that it is helping to reduce the need for personal car ownership. “Uber helps use today’s existing infrastructure more efficiently at no extra cost by getting more butts into the backseats of fewer cars
column2: ” a company spokesperson says.

column1: What is clear is that the on-demand ride market is evolving so rapidly that studies will become outdated almost as soon as they are produced. When Uber or Lyft first comes to a city
column2: riders use those services differently from how they use them in the second or third year
column3: says Shaheen of Berkeley. With the advent of UberPool and Lyft Line
column4: as well as the eventual potential of self-driving cars
column5: the future is anyone’s guess.

column16: Partnership";"16";"1453391471000";"1518629248000";"";"10";"Ban Ki-moon gathers heads of state for political response to water scarcity";"A high-level panel announced at the World Economic Forum in Davos is expected to develop a practical plan for tackling water scarcity";"The UN secretary general Ban Ki-moon has convened an emergency panel of heads of state to prompt a political response to the world’s increasing scarcity of water.

column1: The high level panel on water will find ways to coordinate the often piecemeal political decisions made by the plethora of regulators
column2: governments
column3: companies and individuals who draw from dwindling water reserves. It will also raise a widely-neglected problem to the highest level of political discourse.

column1: “Water is a precious resource
column2: crucial to realising the sustainable development goals
column3: which at their heart aim to eradicate poverty
column4: ” said Ban
column5: who announced the formation of the panel alongside the president of the World Bank
column7: at a special session of the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting in Davos this morning.

column1: “The new panel can help motivate the action we need to turn ideas into reality
column2: ” he said
column3: adding that countries needed to take the lead on tackling the problem.

column1: The panel will meet regularly between now and 2018 and will be chaired by the presidents of Mexico and Mauritius
column2: Enrique Peña Nieto and Ameenah Gurib-Fakim. The two presidents were chosen for their countries’ diverse and representative water challenges. Mexico faces large scale water shortages associated with its booming developing economy
column3: and as a small island state
column4: Mauritius is especially vulnerable to climate change and the many water issues that come with a warming world and rising sea levels.

column1: A further eight heads of state from the developed and developing world will be invited by Ban to join the panel. It is intended they will develop an agenda focused on tangible changes. One example given was the sway the heads of state will have over the operations of the World Bank. As shareholders and clients
column2: heads of state are in a unique position to advise the bank on problems with the way water projects are funded.

column1: “Achieving the water global goal would have multiple benefits
column2: including laying the foundations for food and energy security
column3: sustainable urbanisation
column4: and ultimately climate security
column5: ” said Kim. “My hope is that this panel accelerates action in many countries so that we can make water more accessible to all.”

column1: The politics of water can be divisive
column2: and competition for the resource has become a serious threat to stability in water-scarce regions in parts of Africa
column3: the Middle East and south Asia.

column1: “We are already seeing elements of water scarcity coming through - not just because of climate change
column2: but [because of] over-abstraction. We are seeing stress points - social tensions or conflicts over a lack of access to water
column3: ” said Dominic Waughray
column4: head of public-private partnerships at the World Economic Forum.

column1: According to the UN
column2: 90% of all disasters are water related and by 2050 the world will have just 60% of the water it needs. At last year’s announcement of the SDGs
column3: the UN set its sights on delivering “water and sanitation for all” by 2030
column4: but the issue is rarely discussed by those with the power to address it
column5: said Waughray.

column1: “There has never been a coordinated political momentum. Even when it gets to water ministers
column2: they are sometimes not the most influential ministers in a cabinet. The water community might have done a very good job of analysing the problem and coming up with solutions
column3: but it has never broken through politically at the highest level
column4: at scale
column5: in developed and developing countries

column1: The session in Davos was chaired by the former prime minister of Australia
column2: Kevin Rudd. Rudd told the Guardian that water had not reached the top level of political discourse because there were “too many other pressing challenges”.

column1: “But time is now right
column2: ” he said. “Climate change has now focused on the unfolding water crisis. As well as its impact on national security arising from water scarcity. We are now seeking to translate the sustainable development goals on water into reality.”

column1: Rudd said the heads of state could build partnerships with the private sector and ensure investment in infrastructure could be found.
Attending the session
column2: Peter Brabeck-Letmathe
column3: chairman of Nestlé and chair of the 2030 Water Resources Group
column4: said: “The mark of success for the panel will be practical action and tangible impact. Let this be an opportunity to break down silos at the highest level and collaborate with private sector and others.”

column2: and have your say on issues around water in development using #H2Oideas."

column10: New York";"10";"1453400777000";"1518628759000";"0";"93";"David Koch steps down from board of New York science museum";"The oil billionaire’s departure was cheered by climate scientists who have campaigned for the natural history museum to cut ties with fossil fuel companies";"The oil billionaire David Koch has stepped down from the board at the American Museum of Natural History
column11: after 23 years and more than $20m in donations to the New York museum.

column1: The conservative magnate’s departure from one of the US’s pre-eminent science museums was cheered by climate scientists and activists who have campaigned for the museum to cut ties with fossil fuel companies and those who head them.
A spokesperson for the museum
column2: Roberto Lebron
column3: told the Guardian that Koch’s term on the board ended on 9 December
column4: at the trustees’ annual meeting.

column1: “This change was one of several that took effect at the meeting as part of the normal course of business
column2: ” Lebron said.

column1: Cristyne Nicholas
column2: a spokeswoman for Koch
column3: said the billionaire was “honored to have served on the board” and to have helped make possible the museum’s dinosaur halls
column4: which bear his name. She added that Koch plans to prioritize contributions to cancer research
column5: and noted some $250m in donations to New York hospitals.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Nicholas denied that Koch was at all moved by calls for his resignation.

column1: Activists and some scientists nonetheless hailed a victory for their cause
column2: which won national attention last year when dozens of scientists signed an open letter that singled out Koch. The scientists – including climatologist James Hansen
column3: ecologist George Woodwell
column4: and three Nobel laureates – called for science institutions to sever relations with fossil-fuel interests.

column1: “I think his name is still associated with the dinosaur hall
column2: which with his political opinions is in some ways appropriate
column3: ” said Judith Weis
column4: a signatory and marine biologist at Rutgers University.

column1: “This is one little chink out” of the divestment campaign
column2: Weis said. “There’s a lot more still going on
column3: a lot more museums.”

column1: Beka Economopoulos
column2: a campaign organizer and director of the mobile and politically minded Natural History Museum
column3: said: “Regardless of the reason for his decision
column4: it’s a step in the right direction.”

column1: “We think the letter provoked some sector-wide soul searching
column2: so we’re kind of happy that the American Museum of Natural History no longer has this figure there.”

column1: Citing a petition that has received more than 200
column2: 000 signatures
column3: Economopoulos added: “I’m not attributing the decision to [activists]
column4: but I think it’s safe to say he stepped down in the context of a lot of public pressure.”

column1: A 2013 Drexel University study found that Charles and David Koch
column2: along with ExxonMobil and a network of donor foundations
column3: poured hundreds of millions into efforts to deny the reality of climate change
column4: which the overwhelming majority of American and international scientists agree threatens life around the planet.

column1: The brothers also back a conservative group that recently declared its only climate change “hero” to be senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column2: an opponent of environmental regulation who recently asked whether climate science was based on “data or dogma”.

column1: The Kochs’s conservative contributions
column2: including $122m for Republican campaigns in the 2012 election and an $889m budget for 2016
column3: have largely overshadowed their support for reforming immigration and the criminal justice system.

column1: David Koch remains on the advisory board of the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History
column2: where his name adorns the Hall of Human Origins.

column1: In response to scientists’ calls to cut ties with its rightwing donor last year
column2: the Smithsonian released a statement that said: “Donors and supporters have no influence on the content or presentation of Smithsonian exhibitions
column3: regardless of their private interests.”

column1: The institution also repeated its official statement on climate change
column2: that says “many decades of scientific research [point] to human activities as a cause of global warming”.

column1: Koch is also a major funder for the Metropolitan Museum of Art
column2: where his donations have occasionally provoked protests."

column8: World news";"8";"1453428654000";"1518628759000";"0";"200";"Bolivia's second-largest lake dries up and may be gone forever
column9: lost to climate change";"As Andean glaciers disappear
column10: so do the sources of Lake Poopó’s water
column11: say scientists who blame a warming environment
column12: El Niño and mining";"Overturned fishing skiffs lie abandoned on the shores of what was Bolivia’s second-largest lake. Beetles dine on bird carcasses and gulls fight for scraps under a glaring sun in what marshes remain.

column1: Lake Poopó was officially declared evaporated in December. Hundreds
column2: if not thousands
column3: of people have lost their livelihoods and gone.

column1: High on Bolivia’s semi-arid Andean plains at 3
column2: 700 metres (more than 12
column3: 000 feet) and long subject to climatic whims
column4: the shallow saline lake has essentially dried up before only to rebound to twice the area of Los Angeles.

column1: But recovery may no longer be possible
column2: scientists say.

column1: “This is a picture of the future of climate change
column2: ” says Dirk Hoffman
column3: a German glaciologist who studies how rising temperatures from the burning of fossil fuels has accelerated glacial melting in Bolivia.

column1: As Andean glaciers disappear
column2: so do the sources of Poopó’s water. But other factors are in play in the demise of Bolivia’s second-largest body of water behind Lake Titicaca.

column1: Drought caused by the recurrent El Niño meteorological phenomenon is considered the main driver. Authorities say another factor is the diversion of water from Poopó’s tributaries
column2: mostly for mining but also for agriculture.

column1: More than 100 families have sold their sheep
column2: llamas and alpaca
column3: set aside their fishing nets and quit the former lakeside village of Untavi over the past three years
column4: draining it of well over half its population. Only the elderly remain.

column1: “There’s no future here
column2: ” says 29-year-old Juvenal Gutierrez
column3: who moved to a nearby town where he has taken a job as a motorcycle taxi driver.

column1: Record-keeping on the lake’s history goes back only a century
column2: and there is no good tally of the people displaced by its disappearance. At least 3
column3: 250 people have received humanitarian aid
column4: the governor’s office says.

column1: Poopó is now down to 2% of its former water level
column2: regional governor Victor Hugo Vasquez calculates. Its maximum depth once reached five metres (16ft). Field biologists say 75 species of birds are gone from the lake.

column1: While Poopó has suffered El Niño-fuelled droughts for millennia
column2: its fragile ecosystem has experienced unprecedented stress in the past three decades. Temperatures have risen by about 1 degree Celsius while mining activity has pinched the flow of tributaries
column3: increasing sediment.

column1: Florida Institute of Technology biologist Mark B. Bush says the long-term trend of warming and drying threatens the entire Andean highlands.
A 2010 study he co-wrote for the journal Global Change Biology said Bolivia’s capital
column2: La Paz
column3: could face catastrophic drought this century. It predicted “inhospitable arid climates” would lessen available food and water this century for the more than 3 million inhabitants of Bolivia’s highlands.

column1: A study by the German consortium Gitec-Cobodes determined that Poopó received 161bn fewer litres of water in 2013 than required to maintain equilibrium.
“Irreversible changes in ecosystems could occur
column2: causing massive emigration and greater conflicts
column3: ” said the study commissioned by Bolivia’s government.

column1: The head of a local citizens’ group that tried to save Poopó
column2: Angel Flores
column3: says authorities ignored warnings. “Something could have been done to prevent the disaster. Mining companies have been diverting water since 1982
column4: ” he says.

column1: President Evo Morales has sought to deflect criticism he bears some responsibility
column2: suggesting Poopó could come back.

column1: “My father told me about crossing the lake on a bicycle once when it dried up
column2: ” he said in December after returning from the UN-sponsored climate conference in Paris.

column1: Environmentalists and local activists say the government mismanaged fragile water resources and ignored rampant pollution from mining
column2: Bolivia’s second export earner after natural gas. More than 100 mines are upstream and Huanuni
column3: Bolivia’s biggest state-owned tin mine
column4: was among those dumping untreated tailings into Poopó’s tributaries.

column1: After thousands of fish died in late 2014
column2: the Universidad Tecnica in the nearby state capital of Oruro found Poopó had unsafe levels of heavy metals
column3: including cadmium and lead.

column1: The president of Bolivia’s National Chamber of Mining
column2: Saturnino Ramos
column3: said any blame by the industry was “insignificant compared to climate change.” He said most of the sediment shallowing Poopo’s tributaries was natural
column4: not from mining.

column1: In hopes of bringing it back
column2: Morales’ government has asked the European Union for $140m for water treatment plants for the Poopó watershed and to dredge tributaries led by the Desaguadero
column3: which flows from Lake Titicaca.

column1: But critics say it may be too late.
“I don’t think we’ll be seeing the azure mirror of Poopó again
column2: ” said Milton Perez
column3: a Universidad Tecnica researcher. “I think we’ve lost it.”"

column11: even into Yorkshire";"The county awakes to its first snow textured landscape of the winter. A scant covering
column13: but enough for the children to tumble out into snowballs
column14: snowman building and careering down north facing slopes on a variety of contraptions; that is until they rub the snow away.

column1: Harper’s Brook is a significant tributary of the Nene
column2: winding south-east from Corby
column3: down a shallow valley
column4: past Brigstock
column5: Sudborough and Lowick
column6: before jagging north and joining the Nene at Aldwincle. Between Sudborough and Lowick the valley floor is mostly still grazing land. One field contains a couple of dozen young Suffolk rams
column9: and characteristically long and droopy black ears. They loaf about in little squads

column1: At Lowick the valley is dominated by the pale yellow stone of the substantial and elegant St Peter’s church tower. It has an octagonal “lantern” top storey
column2: like the better known Fotheringhay church

column4: pencil sharp turrets
column5: one on each corner of the penultimate tower storey.

column1: A new agricultural enterprise nestles next to Lowick – row upon row of straight
column2: tensioned wires
column3: over which are draped the crooked and curled brown stems of grape vines. This is perhaps not as unusual as it at first feels; vine pollen has been found in Roman deposits at Wollaston
column4: a site just a few miles upstream on the Nene. While wine production in the UK more or less ceased in the first half of the 20th century
column5: there is now a scatter of midland vineyards that stretches north

column7: including one just three miles away from the Roman vineyard site at Wollaston.

column1: Humans will adapt to a climate change by replacing crops that get harder to grow with others that are better adapted to the new conditions. Time will tell if vines and wines become a major part of Northamptonshire agriculture

column9: Paris climate agreement";"9";"1453442403000";"1518628758000";"0";"198";"France calls on world leaders to give Paris climate deal 'new push'";"Ratifying the agreement at a meeting in New York to enshrine it in international law is the next step
column10: says France’s foreign minister Laurent Fabius";"World leaders should give international efforts to fight global warming a new push by ratifying the historic Paris climate deal in person
column11: according to France’s foreign minister.

column1: Laurent Fabius
column2: who steered December’s UN talks
column3: wants heads of state to ratify the accord at a meeting in April in New York
column4: so that it can be enshrined in international law. Nations accounting for more than 55% of global emissions must formally sign up before the Paris agreement can be made official.

column1: He told the Guardian he had discussed the plans with UN secretary general Ban Ki-moon a few days ago
column2: gaining his support
column3: and was “pretty confident” that heads of government would attend what would be the third leaders’ climate summit in a little over six months.  “We should have the leaders there
column4: to give a new impulse [to the implementation of the accord]
column5: ” he said of the New York meeting
column6: which he will preside over. “At the first day of Paris [which leaders attended] there was a tremendous push. It’s time for a new push in April.”  Fabius is acutely aware that
column7: despite the success of the Paris negotiations
column8: much more needs to be done before the future of the accord is secure. “There are many things which can go wrong
column9: ” he told the Guardian. “We have to avoid being lazy. We have to be calm
column10: and to be hopeful. We have to talk to developing countries.” He pointed to the need to tackle emissions from aviation and maritime transport
column11: which were omitted from the UN talks
column12: and which he said are urgent.

column1: More work is needed on setting out clear rules on how to monitor emissions in a “transparent” fashion
column2: he said. African countries must be assured that they are receiving the support that was promised to them at Paris. Businesses must also receive cooperation from governments to develop new clean technologies that will be “decisive” in bringing down emissions.  Fabius also called for a renewed focus on the possibility of putting a price on carbon
column3: pointing to a Chinese plan to institute a national system of carbon trading from next year. This would be a major step forward
column4: he said. At Paris
column5: 196 countries agreed to limit greenhouse gases in line with scientific advice
column6: to avoid temperature rises of more than 2C
column7: and to review their commitments and progress on meeting them every five years. This framework is legally binding
column8: and most countries - including all the biggest emitters - also set out national targets for emissions
column9: to 2025 or 2030.  Fabius addressed the European parliament in Strasbourg on Wednesday
column10: asking MEPs for their continued support for plans for the EU to meet its obligations on greenhouse gas emissions. He set out “four Ps” which he said are needed to implement the Paris agreement: the process of ratification of the accord
column11: including the April meeting; clarifying the principles underlying the agreement
column12: such as a precise definition of climate change financing
column13: rules on the conduct of the five-year reviews and the transparency of monitoring emissions; the pre-2020 period
column14: during which countries must make progress on their existing emissions goals; and preparing for this November’s UN climate conference
column15: ‘COP22’. The success of the Paris conference was a rare bright moment in a dark end to 2015 for France
column16: scarred by the terrorist attacks in November that left 130 people dead and scores more wounded. Fabius hailed the agreement as a triumph for international cooperation. “This is about security and peace
column17: ” he said. “There are massive risks to global warming
column18: which could lead to widespread conflict. We have to stop that risk from becoming reality. That means this agreement was actually about peace for future generations
column19: and current generations. This is a chaotic world
column20: and a dangerous one. The Paris agreement is making the world safer.” Relaxed in a fashionably high-collared brown leather jacket as he travelled by French government plane to a snow-covered Strasbourg
column21: Fabius reflected that the signing of the Paris accord had been just a beginning

column1: “We need to look for concrete measures now
column2: ” he said. “I think that will arrive. The shift [to tackling climate change] has been made now
column3: and there will be no turning back.”  For the year ahead
column4: Fabius has a punishing schedule of climate meetings as part of his role as president of the COP
column5: which under UN convention continues until COP22 in November. After the summit in April there will be a meeting in Germany in May to discuss some of the details of the accord
column6: then a further conference in Washington DC in May or June hosted by the US
column7: followed by a meeting of local authorities from around the world in Nantes
column10: as well as meetings held with the IMF and World Bank
column11: and the UN general assembly in September. During that time
column12: it is widely expected that Fabius will leave his post as foreign minister
column13: perhaps to be succeeded by his long-time rival Ségolène Royal. He has been tipped in France as a potential future candidate for UN secretary-general
column14: with his steering of the Paris conference having burnished his credentials.

column1: Though he declined to speculate on his future
column2: Fabius noted that he could remain COP president without being French foreign minister."

column12: sent a memo to staff about the appropriate way to refer to Donald Trump in stories or on social media.

column1: He said that because Trump was operating so “far outside” the political campaigns to which the company’s guidelines usually applied
column2: and because he was saying things so obviously false
column3: or overtly anti-Muslim
column4: it was quite factual for reporters to call him
column5: for example
column6: a “mendacious racist” even though they wouldn’t normally use those kinds of terms about a candidate.

column1: Using the same logic
column2: it seems quite reasonable to say Clive Palmer – our own allegedly mega-rich and megalomaniac anti-politician – has taken the entire political system for a ride.

column1: The latest example of how we are all being played for fools is the fact that his Palmer United Party sucked $21m in political donations from his 100% owned Queensland Yabulu nickel refinery before going into administration. The federal government has offered $500
column2: 000 to help 237 workers have been sacked but if the company cannot trade out of its problems and goes into liquidation then the rest of the workforce would almost certainly be able to access the federal government’s fair entitlements guarantee program and cost the government millions more. Oh
column3: and he didn’t have to provide a bond for rehabilitating the polluted tailing dams and that could cost the Queensland government many more millions. This equation really doesn’t work out so well for us taxpayers.

column1: Which shouldn’t be surprisingly really since the whole Palmer juggernaut has always been about Clive.
He effectively bought the balance of power in the Senate
column2: spending $28.9m on the 2013 election and the Western Australian Senate rerun
column3: most of which went on saturation advertising which in some cases promised things he would never have had the power to deliver
column4: like getting WA voters more revenue from the GST. And despite poor polling though the campaign
column5: those ads
column7: made the difference. He won his lower house seat and three spots in the Senate.

column1: As well as promising things he couldn’t do
column2: he didn’t do some of the few things he had coherently promised. His election platform
column3: for example
column4: said he opposed offshore processing of asylum seekers. But he (and the two senators he had at a time) provided the deciding votes to pass a bill that dramatically increased the powers of the government to implement its offshore processing policy while avoiding the reach of the UN convention on refugees.

column1: He was the anti-politician who would protect the “little guy”. Which is hard to reconcile with his party’s support for things like axing the government contribution of $500 a year to the superannuation accounts of the lowest income earners
column2: from 2017.

column1: And his position and rationale on other things changed according to political convenience.
His senators provided the necessary votes for the abolition of the carbon and mining taxes
column2: an obvious conflict of interest for a would-be miner and owner of a high-emitting nickel refinery that for a long time had an outstanding $8m carbon tax debt. He also provided the votes to pass the Coalition’s alternative Direct Action scheme
column3: which as it stands is demonstrably inadequate to meet Australia’s greenhouse gas reduction promises while imposing no restrictions or costs on polluting industries
column4: like
column5: say

column1: At the time
column2: he also claimed he was some kind of born-again climate crusader – memorably appearing beside Al Gore – by “forcing” the government to ask the Climate Change Authority (a body it wanted to abolish) to prepare a report on alternative emissions reductions schemes
column3: which it will deliver this year. To be fair
column4: he did make tangible contributions
column5: from an environmental point of view
column6: by refusing to abolish the CCA and the Clean Energy Finance Corporation
column7: which did at least preserve some institutional common sense.

column1: But for the most part
column2: in those days before his Senate voting bloc fell apart and all but one of the senators he had bankrolled went their own way
column3: he engaged in last minute
column4: high drama
column5: chaotic negotiations
column6: which maximised his publicity but mostly delivered “concessions” that were bad public policy or contradictory to the message he had given voters. I called it the Palmer pattern.

column1: And as for representing the voters of his Queensland seat of Fairfax
column2: for his own part in the lower house he hardly voted at all. He cast a vote in just 6.8% of divisions according to the OpenAustralia Foundation.

column1: His whole tactic was to play the media
column2: and the system
column3: in a similar but slightly less spectacular way to Trump – luring journalists with all manner of publicity seeking stunts and then attacking them as part of the biased Canberra elite when they tried to hold him to account or point out the many things about his campaign that made no sense. And then
column4: holding the Senate votes that could make or break legislation
column5: the government and the opposition were also forced to pay due deference to the will of the electorate
column6: as expressed through Palmer’s semi-coherent positions.

column1: And – as well as many reports of his publicity seeking antics – there were also many attempts to hold him to account. Hedley Thomas in the Australian
column2: in particular wrote numerous articles about his business interests and other questionable claims. Many journalists
column3: myself included
column4: called out his conflicts of interest
column5: his inconsistent behaviour and his confused policy pronouncements

column1: And while he never quite stooped to Trump’s treatment of the media
column2: Palmer used the same tactics of attacking critics in order to ignore them. In the case of the Australian
column3: he alleged a campaign motivated by things he had said about Rupert Murdoch’s former wife Wendy Deng. In the case of other interviewers he famously stormed out when the questioning got too hard
column4: including from a 7.30 interview with Sarah Ferguson and another with Lateline’s Emma Alberici. In my own case he became belligerent and declared that I was a “naive girl” when I pressed him on a policy.

column1: Palmer is by no means Australia’s first populist politician. And he didn’t go nearly as far as Trump in mocking the idea of accountability and truthfulness and threatening and abusing critics
column2: which is forcing media and politicians in the US into the kind of assessments in the Buzzfeed memo.

column1: US academic Jay Rosen
column2: in this thought provoking blog on the topic
column3: argues part of the answer is for political journalism to reconsider its sense of purpose and focus
column4: which could reduce the coverage of the entertainingly outrageous that kickstarts the populist politician.

column1: David Roberts in Vox argues that Trump is causing such consternation because he has broken the “accepted rules of lying” which have for a while condoned
column2: or reported as a he said/she said story the really big policy lies
column3: while calling out smaller
column4: personal or trivial untruths.

column1: That would fit with the Australian experience of the Coalition’s anti-carbon tax campaign or its reasoning that its 2014 budget broke no election promises – both arguments replete with obvious falsehoods.
Australia now has a prime minister who says he wants to respect the electorate’s intelligence and Palmer’s influence is on the wane
column2: so maybe our election year won’t be like the US primary season.

column1: But if we don’t give some thought to the consequences of allowing political discourse to drift away even from the expectation that it is grounded in fact
column2: and the reasons that might be happening
column3: we really are mugs."

column6: Science";"6";"1453497948000";"1520960829000";"0";"200";"Tony Abbott's climate claims debunked: researcher dissects 2013 statement";"Sophie Lewis was so annoyed about the way science was ignored in the political debate about climate change she went to work to disprove the myths";"Climate scientists are regularly infuriated by the things politicians say. But it’s not often they publish a scientific paper tearing a politician’s comments to shreds.

column1: Sophie Lewis
column2: from the Australian Research Council’s centre for excellence in climate science
column3: has done exactly that
column4: dissecting statements about climate records made by the former prime minister Tony Abbott in 2013.

column1: Last week
column2: temperature figures showed 2015 was officially the hottest year on record. Before that
column3: 2014 was the hottest year on record. And scientists are expecting 2016 to once again win the dubious honour.

column1: Heat records are being broken with wild abandon. Last year
column2: 10 months broke temperature records.

column1: Climate scientists say a rise in the average temperature caused by greenhouse gas emissions makes extreme heat records more likely.

column2: the UN’s top climate official
column3: Christiana Figueres
column4: linked bushfires in Australia to climate change. Abbott called such claims “complete hogwash” and said drawing links between broken records and climate change was a sign of desperation.

column1: It drives me mental that these sorts of statements go unaddressed
He went on: “The thing is that at some point in the future
column2: every record will be broken
column3: but that doesn’t prove anything about climate change. It just proves that the longer the period of time
column4: the more possibility of extreme events.”

column1: Superficially it seems to make sense: if you wait long enough
column2: you’re bound to see records fall. Lewis suspected many people shared Abbott’s interpretation
column3: and set out to show it was wrong.

column1: Lewis says she was frustrated by the gap she saw between what the science showed and what some politicians said was happening.
In a peer-reviewed paper published in the journal Weather and Climate Extremes
column2: Lewis pulls Abbot’s comments apart
column3: shred by shred.

column1: The first way to understand Abbott’s claim is that in any system
column2: the longer you wait
column3: the more often you will see records fall. But Lewis points out that the exact opposite is true. In a system without any sort of trend
column4: such as a random string of temperatures
column5: the first one will be a record-breaker
column6: by default. The second one will have a 50% chance of being a record-breaker. The third has a one in three chance of being a record breaker … and so on. In a very long temperature series
column7: you should see very few records being broken
column8: and they will break less often over time.

column1: Unless
column2: of course
column3: there is a warming or cooling trend.

column1: Alternatively
column2: Abbott might simply have meant there was no connection between extreme heat records and climate change. Instead
column3: natural variability might be to blame: natural variability includes things such as the El Niño phenomenon
column4: which push temperature around year-to-year.

column1: To test if that might be the case
column2: Lewis ran a series of climate models in which the greenhouse effect was removed – so all that was left was natural variability. Unsurprisingly
column3: in those models
column4: high temperature records were less common than they are in reality. In other words
column5: the record-breaking that we have seen cannot be explained by natural variation.

column1: “It drives me mental that these sorts of statements go unaddressed
column2: ” Lewis says. She says scientific literature generally tries to simply explain what is happening
column3: ignoring misunderstandings in the public sphere.

column1: “This was an attempt to bridge that gap.”"
