column10: UK news";"10";"1453627804000";"1521677204000";"0";"200";"Piers Corbyn: the other rebel in the family";"Like his brother
column11: physicist and meteorologist Piers Corbyn is a man of revolutionary zeal. His own battle
column13: is against all this ‘climate-change nonsense’…";"When Jeremy Corbyn won the leadership of the Labour party in September he celebrated in a pub up the road from the Houses of Parliament with a thank you to supporters and a rousing rendition of the Red Flag. On the edge of the impromptu stage that day
column14: beside Len McCluskey of Unite and John McDonnell the future shadow chancellor
column15: was a singular figure singing with particular pride: Piers Corbyn
column16: the new leader’s elder brother
column19: led a parallel career of stubborn principle to his younger sibling. I was in the euphoric crowd that day
column20: and since then I’ve wondered a bit about the relationship between the brothers
column21: what they have learned from each other. With some of this in mind I called Piers recently and asked if he might like to talk about some of that. He agreed
column22: but typically on the basis that he would happily talk about any subject under the sun – apart from his relationship with Jeremy and the vexed question of how his leadership is going. He shares much of his brother’s mistrust of the press; recently
column24: the Independent published an account of an exchange that had taken place over a family Christmas dinner. That wasn’t on. What he will talk about
column26: is the thing he has talked about for just about as long as he can remember: the weather.

column1: On this very British basis we met last week in a cafe over the road from his office on Borough High Street in south London. You don’t have to speak to Piers for very long to realise that at least a couple of Corbyn family traits are indelible: the first is that intransigent rasp of a voice with faint traces of west country burr; the second is the sense that life
column2: like politics
column3: is best played as a long game.

column1: Piers Corbyn has a faith
column2: even at 68
column3: that if he states his beliefs often enough – though it might seem no one is listening – his day will surely come. He takes comfort in this not only from the recent elevation of his brother
column4: but also from the example of Galileo
column5: and of John Harrison and his measurement of longitude. “It is unfortunately not the case that the truth always prevails in the short term
column8: “there are often vested interests to prevent it.”

column1: The particular “truth” that Corbyn has in mind is perhaps the least fashionable proposal currently available in enlightened debate: it is the belief that changes in the Earth’s climate and its weather are dictated primarily by cyclical activity on the surface of the sun (and not
column2: pointedly
column3: by the effects of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere). It is a cause even more thankless than the return of 1980s socialism to British parliamentary politics seemed (until very recently). Corbyns have little fear of pariah status
column4: though. What of the “settled opinion” of climate scientists and governments around the world
column5: sealed in the recent Paris accord? “For one thing science doesn’t do settled opinions
column6: ” Corbyn says. “And for another they are all wrong.”

column1: Thatcher probably knew climate change was nonsense. She was a scientist. But she was also a politician
This contrarian spirit began in Piers Corbyn at the age of five when his father
column2: an electrical engineer
column3: encouraged him to investigate the efficacy of a Victorian dew pond (he found it to be limited); it continued with his construction of all manner of meteorological equipment in the family garden in Shropshire; then through the study of tiny anomalies in the true orbit of the Earth (based
column4: aged 17
column5: on weekly measurements of the elevation of the sun
column6: with findings published in the journal of the Royal Geographical Society) and into academic degrees in solid state physics and astrophysics at Imperial College London. The culmination of this obsession was a personal epiphany: “I was thinking of using the weather to discover what the sun had been doing in the past
column8: that’s just stupid: why not use the sun to predict what the weather will do in the future?” In his mind
column9: the only thing that has got in the way of him making his fortune from that ambition

column1: To begin with
column2: he says
column3: his solar-based forecasts and calculations were way off
column4: and he had as good as given up
column5: but in 1984 a singular event changed the course of his working life. At the time
column7: of the year after his brother had first been elected a Labour MP
column8: his own political loyalties were in a certain state of flux. He had been a radical student union president in London and sometime revolutionary socialist (a past that he believes would have prevented him working at the Met Office
column9: still part of the Ministry of Defence
column10: even had he wanted to). In the early 1980s he had been affiliated to the International Marxist Group
column11: after a brief flirtation with the “quasi-Trotsky anarchist group
column13: for the 11 days it existed”. At the beginning of 1984
column14: knowing his meteorological background
column15: the IMG asked him to forecast what the winter was going to be like at the end of that year. The miners were planning a strike and “they wanted to know whether it was going to be cold enough for the strike to be effective
column16: to bring Britain to its knees

column1: He said no
column2: but under pressure from his comrades he went back to the data
column3: “looked at a lot of new relationships and correlations” and came to the conclusion that
column4: yes
column5: it was going to be a very cold winter. He presented his evidence to the Miners’ Educational Support Committee (“I think it was called that. We had a lot of committees…”) And it was passed on up to the NUM. As the strike unfolded Corbyn’s prediction proved correct
column6: the winter of 1984-85 was unusually cold.

column1: Was the NUM grateful?
“Very
column2: ” he says. He had phone calls from head office
column3: “not [Arthur] Scargill personally but one of his senior assistants”
column4: asking how long the cold weather would last. He told him he thought it could possibly last long enough to bring down the Thatcher government
column5: but by March the strike had collapsed and he never got the chance to be proved right.

column1: All the while Corbyn was assessing the proximity of revolution by monitoring the electricity output at Goldsmith’s college where he was a lecturer in the physics department. “The voltages were below the legal minimum all that winter
column2: ” he says. “It is supposed to be 240v
column3: it was below 210v and for safety they are legally bound to turn it off. The government were desperately doing everything they could to conserve power. I called to say I had measured the voltages at the University of London and they were below that minimum. They said
column4: ‘Well
column5: Mr Corbyn you must have faulty equipment

column1: It was in those weeks and months
column2: Corbyn suggests
column3: that Margaret Thatcher came up with her most devious plan to deindustrialise Britain and defeat the miners once and for all: she would popularise and endorse the science of man-made climate change
column4: as a way of converting Britain from coal to nuclear power. The Hadley Centre
column5: the world’s first dedicated research institution became her pet project. Thatcher
column9: “she was a scientist. But she was also a politician. The rest is history.”

column1: Corbyn sees that moment as the one in which politicians first saw the political capital to be made from prophesying the coming apocalypse. Worse though
column2: in his mind
column3: the most vehement expression of that prophesy was not on the right but on the left. Climate change became a progressive cause.

column1: For Corbyn
column2: it answered the crisis on the left created by the fall of the Berlin Wall. “The left needed a new totem pole. Something for the young to dance around and feel good about
column3: ” he says
column4: somewhat bitterly. “Revolutions had failed. Russia had failed. Socialism wasn’t dead but it needed a cause. The Red-Green alliance became that cause. It needed massive state spending
column5: which they equated with socialism. In my view the left stopped thinking in 1989. It is only my brother who has started to change the agenda of privatisation and so on.”

column1: It is hard to imagine that Piers has not bent his brother’s ear with elements of this analysis at family gatherings for about 25 years. Does he show signs of wavering?
“I don’t speak for my brother on any of this
column2: ” he says. “I don’t give advice to him where it is not appropriate.”

column1: Did Jeremy share his obsession with the weather as a kid?
“Not really
column2: ” he says. “We were all different. Our eldest brother was into cars. He became a flight test engineer for Concorde. The next brother is a mining engineer
column3: went to Imperial college. Then there is me
column4: scientist. Then Jeremy
column5: who was always politics. I think we all took after different aspects of our dad; while my mother encouraged us to make things all the time. The house was rundown and we boys had to do repairs. Jeremy and I learned how to repoint brickwork and so on. We became pretty good builders.”

column1: The left stopped thinking in 1989. It is only my brother who has started to change the agenda

Piers has had perhaps less convincing success with the construction project that has occupied most of his adult life. After the relative triumph of his forecast for the miners he worked pretty much full-time on his long-range models. By 1989
column2: the first year he heard of the idea of man-made climate change
column3: he was ready to sell his formula to the world.

column1: Ignoring the traditional model of publication and peer review
column2: ostensibly to prevent others stealing his ideas
column3: he engaged the bookmaker William Hill to construct some weather bets for him with the help of the Met Office. “That went on for 12 years
column4: ” he says. “I had 30 bets at £20 each on long-range aspects of the weather each month; betting the average temperature would be below normal
column5: that kind of thing. We made a lot of money that way.”

column1: How much is a lot of money?
“I made about 40% profits on stake
column2: overall
column3: ” he claims. “I would bet £600; I would get an extra £200 back. It would pay the rent basically.” He and his girlfriend at the time no doubt spent a lot of time looking anxiously at the sky.

column1: After this marginal success
column2: a little better than putting a wet finger in the wind
column3: some commercial clients came calling. For a while
column4: Corbyn exclusively told the clothes store Etam the optimum time to sell its T-shirts or its hats and scarves. Some farmers were seduced by his predictions of storm and drought. And then the scientific consensus around carbon dioxide as principal climate-changer hardened
column5: and Corbyn’s company
column7: which floated on the stock exchange in 1997
column8: went back into private ownership after two years.

column1: Adversity has only stiffened Corbyn’s resolve
column2: however. Despite his marginal status he is fighting global opinion on all fronts. These days he does the odd presentation for Texan oil companies
column3: or Russian climate sceptics. And he has not given up on a shift of opinion closer to home.

column1: “Whatever you think of it all
column2: the net result of these beliefs has been a deindustrialising of the west and the shift of carbon dioxide production from Britain to India and China
column3: ” he says. “Labour under Jeremy are now saying we have got to make a special case for steel and various industries that have to pay all these significant taxations on energy costs
column4: which is the reason a lot of them are closing down.”

column1: Piers is whispering in the ear of any MP who will listen: “Graham Stringer
column2: of Labour
column3: is sympathetic
column4: ” he says
column5: “Sammy Wilson DUP
column7: Boris is very sympathetic [Johnson tends to use Corbyn
column9: as his climate guru]. Now I think we have George Galloway which is significant
column10: because he can be very persuasive…”

column1: Inevitably
column2: Corbyn has arrived for coffee armed with graphs and charts; so before I go I try to get him to explain how his calculations work. He talks 10 to the dozen about solar magnetic fields and lunar modulation and stratospheric winds. He outlines his database of 200-year-old German weather maps and solar observation from American satellites. “The principle is that all weather that happens has happened before
column3: all storm systems
column4: the question is finding the closest match…”

column1: If the results are as good as he claims
column2: I suggest
column3: why haven’t other people picked up on his system?

column1: “We haven’t told them how it’s done!” he says. “We had the Solar Weather Technique
column2: ‘SWT zero’. We now have now got the Solar Lunar Action Technique
column3: ‘SLAT’
column4: and we are on version 12CS – s is for special. We have gone through 20 improvements and understandings on this…”

column1: As he talks I have the impression of an army of researchers tracking and calculating
column2: poring over maps in order to compete with the Met Office’s supercomputer.

column1: When you say “we…” I ask.
“I mean me
column2: ” he says.

column1: “OK” I say. “And what does the system suggest we can look forward to?
“It will get much
column2: much colder
column3: ” Corbyn asserts (he has lately suggested that in the longer term we are on the verge of a great cooling cycle
column4: which will vindicate him once and for all). “Next month we have a displaced polar vortex situation. Plenty of snow coming.”

column1: We both glance out at the spring-like day on Borough High Street.
“It’s got a chance
column2: I guess
column3: ” I say. Corbyn grins. As he knows only too well
column4: stranger things have happened."

column12: even though the governments of more than 190 countries - including the UK - agreed in Paris last month that urgent action is required to avoid dangerous impacts from rising greenhouse gas levels?  While the overall coverage in the Guardian
column13: Independent and Mirror titles tends to reflect the mainstream scientific
column14: economic and political consensus about climate change
column15: the Mail
column16: Express
column18: Sun and Telegraph titles all continue to use their opinion columns and leaders to try to cast doubt on the risks. This was plainly shown by the contrasting reports last month of the link between climate change and this winter’s flooding.  However
column19: not all of the naysayers are the same

column21: it appears that some of these newspapers are now carrying out a cull of writers who choose not to reflect the uninformed prejudices of their editors and proprietors. Last summer
column22: the environment editor of the Sun
column24: left the newspaper and was not replaced. This was the culmination of a slow slide in the newspaper’s coverage of climate change and other environmental problems since James Murdoch left its parent company

column1: Murdoch junior
column2: unlike his father
column3: is acquainted with the scientific evidence for climate change
column4: and had persuaded his stable of newspapers to recognise the importance to their readers of being better informed about environmental issues.  Since his departure
column5: however

column7: the Sun published an article from “climate expert”
column9: a notorious rightwing polemicist whose lack of scientific knowledge was cruelly exposed on national television by the president of the Royal Society. And the Times has been providing Viscount Ridley
column10: the former chair of Northern Rock bank
column11: with a regular column to downplay the risks of climate change.  Meanwhile
column12: the Daily Telegraph also decided last summer to make redundant Geoffrey Lean
column13: one of the UK media’s most experienced voices on the environment. Lean wrote on his blog: “In the British press... there [are]
column14: in my estimation
column15: some 10 columnists who reject or underplay the dangers of global warming
column16: with precious few columnar voices on the other side”.  Fortunately

column1: Thirteen of the 15 hottest years in the 150-year-long record occurred between 2000-14 and the researchers found there is a just a 0.01% chance that this happened due to natural variations in the planet’s climate.
2015 was revealed to have smashed all earlier records on Wednesday

column1: “Natural climate variations just can’t explain the observed recent global heat records

column1: He said the record heat brought substantial impacts: “It has led to unprecedented local heatwaves across the world
column2: sadly resulting in loss of life and aggravating droughts and wildfires. The risk of heat extremes has been multiplied due to our interference with the Earth system
column3: as our analysis shows.”

column1: The UN World Meteorological Organization (WMO) confirmed on Monday that the global average surface temperature in 2015 shattered all previous records and said 15 of the 16 hottest years on record have all occurred since 2000. “We have reached for the first time the threshold of 1C above pre-industrial temperatures. It is a sobering moment in the history of our planet
column2: ” said WMO secretary-general Petteri Taalas.

column1: The new research by Rahmstorf and colleagues
column2: published in the journal Scientific Reports
column3: is based on a statistical analysis that combines real-world measurements with comprehensive computer simulations of the climate system. This allowed natural climate variability to be better separated from human-caused climate change. The results did not vary significantly when UK Met Office temperature data was used instead of Nasa data.

column1: The research was prompted by earlier claims that the run of record-breaking years was vanishing unlikely
column2: a one in 650m shot
column3: according to one report.

column1: However
column2: the average global surface temperature of the planet each year is influenced by the warmth of the previous year
column3: meaning that a record broken one year is not independent of the year before. The UK Met Office expects 2016 to break the record set in 2015
column4: partly because of the continuing El Niño weather phenomenon.

column1: “Natural climate variability causes temperatures to wax and wane over a period of several years
column2: rather than varying erratically from one year to the next
column3: ” said Prof Michael Mann at Penn State university in the US
column4: who led the new study. “That makes it more challenging to accurately assess the likelihood of temperature records. Given the press interest
column5: it seemed important to do this right
column6: and address the interesting and worthwhile question of how unlikely it is that the recent run of record temperatures might have arisen by chance alone.”

column1: The study concludes: “While considerably greater than cited in some media reports
column2: the odds are low enough to suggest that recent observed runs of record temperatures are extremely unlikely to have occurred in the absence of human-caused global warming.”
the UN’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change concluded with 95% certainty that humans are the main cause of global warming."

column3: World news";"3";"1.453725e+12";"1518629246000";"0";"200";"The Zika virus foreshadows our dystopian climate future | Bill McKibben";"The mosquito-borne disease shows that pushing the limits of the planet’s ecology has become dangerous in novel ways";"I’ve spent much of my life chronicling the ongoing tragedies stemming from global warming: the floods and droughts and storms
column4: the failed harvests and forced migrations. But no single item on the list seems any more horrible than the emerging news from South America about the newly prominent Zika disease.

column1: Spread by mosquitoes whose range inexorably expands as the climate warms
column2: Zika causes mild flu-like symptoms. But pregnant women bitten by the wrong mosquito are liable to give birth to babies with shrunken heads. Brazil last year recorded 4
column3: 000 cases of this “microcephaly”. As of today
column4: authorities in Brazil
column5: Colombia
column7: El Salvador and Venezuela were urging women to avoid getting pregnant.

column1: Think about that. Women should avoid the most essential and beautiful of human tasks. It is unthinkable. Or rather
column2: it is something out of a science fiction story
column3: the absolute core of a dystopian future. “It is recommended that women postpone – to the extent possible – the decision to become pregnant until the country can move out of the epidemic phase of the Zika virus
column4: ” the Colombian health authorities said
column5: adding that those living in low altitude areas should move higher if possible
column6: out of the easy range of mosquitoes.

column1: Now think about the women who are already pregnant
column2: and who will spend the next months in a quiet panic about whether their lives will be turned upside down. Try to imagine what that feels like – the anger
column3: the guilt
column4: the pervasive anxiety at the moment when you most want to be calm and serene.

column1: And now think about the larger
column2: less intimate consequences: this is one more step in the division of the world into relative safe and dangerous zones
column3: an emerging epidemiological apartheid. The CDC has already told those Americans thinking of becoming pregnant to avoid travel to 20 Latin American and Caribbean nations.

column1: Eventually
column2: of course
column3: the disease will reach these shores – at least 10 Americans have come back from overseas with the infection
column4: and one microcephalic baby has already been born in Hawaii to a mother exposed in Brazil early in her pregnancy. But America is rich enough to avoid the worst of the mess its fossil fuel habits have helped create.

column1: As usual
column2: it’s the most poor and most vulnerable who bear the brunt. In Brazil army troops are going door to door draining puddles and flowerpots of stagnant water where mosquitoes might breed; in Jamaica the minister of health said plaintively “I’m going to be very frank
column3: we don’t have enough fogging machines to fog every single community in Jamaica” with the pesticides that might help control the outbreak.

column1: And so the residents of the rich world will
column2: inevitably
column3: travel less frequently to the places just beginning to emerge from poverty. The links that speed development will start to wither; even the Olympics
column4: theoretically our showcase of international solidarity
column5: is likely to be a fearful fortnight in Rio this August.

column1: Zika’s not the only force tending in that direction
column2: of course. It’s hard to imagine who’s going to visit Burkina Faso or Mali any time soon
column3: after al-Qaida and Isis have blown up the major western hotels. Expats are starting to desert Beijing and New Delhi because who wants to raise their kids in smog so bad that a facemask is a fashion accessory.

column1: Obviously we need to extend every possible aid to people across the Americas – we need to make sure they have fogging machines and testing equipment and teams of doctors who can help. But even more obviously we need to face up to the fact that pushing the limits of the planet’s ecology has become dangerous in novel ways. The Paris climate accords already seem dated and timid in the face of this news. We’re in an emergency
column2: one whose face morphs each week into some new and hideous calamity.

column1: A civilization where one can’t safely have a baby is barely a civilization. "

column1: “Actually
column2: that is one of the key issues in the world right now – the lack of global governance in a world that has become far more interdependent

column1: “Some countries have played their role historically

column3: claiming developing market status. But increasingly the issues that we are facing – climate change
column4: unemployment

column1: “Many of the institutions that were designed have served us very well

column1: Since Polman took charge of Unilever in January 2009 he has tried to back his words with actions. Unilever has stopped updating the stock market on its performance every quarter to encourage a long-term perspective
column2: and it has launched a sustainable living plan that includes a commitment to cut calories in its ice-cream products. The company has pledged to eliminate coal from its energy usage within five years

column1: Polman insists that the dividend is part of “balancing the choices to multiple stakeholders” and that the financial markets are increasingly coming round to his way of thinking.
“Businesses are also discovering that the costs of not doing things are becoming higher than doing things
column2: ” he says.

column1: “The age of transparency should also not be underestimated. There are many people now that don’t want to invest in companies that create a worse future for their grandchildren. They are able to see it by going to the internet and they vote increasingly with their wallet.”

column2: noting that nearly half of Volkswagen’s market capitalisation has been wiped out in the wake of the emissions scandal.

column1: Polman accepts that there are also still significant numbers of investors looking for the biggest possible short-term returns who do not care too much how companies achieve their dividends. But he is optimistic that a growing number are taking a longer-term view.

“Companies in the US now spend more money on share buybacks or special dividends than they do reinvesting in their companies and protecting their futures. Many in the financial community are starting to be concerned about that
column2: ” he says.

column1: “We are fortunate in Unilever that we have about 70% of our shareholder base that has now been with us as long as I have been here. We have deliberately sought longer-term shareholders.”
However

column2: ” he says. “The fundamental issues of how to make Europe more competitive
column3: how to grow Europe for the longer term
column4: are not being addressed. That is why you don’t see any growth in Europe
column5: there is still deflation in many markets. The real issues that started the euro crisis have not been addressed

column1: As for Unilever itself
column2: Polman wants to continue to show that its personal and homecare products

column1: Even though he is moving into his 60s and his tenure as chief executive is longer than average
column2: Polman has no plans to retire: “I am 100% concentrated as if it is my first day. I still have that same energy.”

column1: “For us

column13: Climate change";"13";"1453801309000";"1518631874000";"0";"20";"World's largest palm oil trader criticised for lack of progress on deforestation";"Wilmar claims it has made ‘significant progress’ but campaigners and experts say more is needed to prevent forest clearance or human rights abuses";"The world’s largest palm oil processor and trader used the Davos gathering of business leaders as an opportunity to talk up progress on its efforts to tackle deforestation in the palm oil sector.

column1: Singapore-headquartered Wilmar says it has made “significant progress” on a commitment it made two years ago to eliminate deforestation
column2: exploitation and peatland development from its supply chain. This includes publishing a list of crude palm oil mill sources that supply its refineries
column3: enabling greater transparency along the company’s supply chain.

column1: However
column2: campaigners and industry experts say the company is yet to prove that its suppliers are not responsible for clearing forests or abusing human rights.

column1: Glenn Hurowitz
column2: senior fellow at the Centre for International Policy
column3: who wrote an introductory commentary for Wilmar’s progress report
column4: told the Guardian that being able to measure progress is key: “Among the large agribusiness companies
column5: Wilmar is leading the way in many areas
column6: from supplier engagement to transparency to rapidly responding to grievances filed by civil society ... But no company is providing comprehensive information about whether [its suppliers] are clearing forests or abusing human rights – the metrics that really matter.”

column1: Even Wilmar’s chief sustainability officer Jeremy Goon points out that “much remains to be done
column2: including the development of a clear means to measure and track the progress of sustainability commitments to assess its effectiveness in reducing actual deforestation”.

column1: The key sticking point according to NGOs such as Greenpeace and the Forest Peoples Programme is that Wilmar
column2: which controls 45% of global palm oil trade
column3: cannot prove that its suppliers are not responsible for ongoing deforestation. The palm oil supply chain is notoriously complex and lacking in transparency
column4: but Greenpeace Indonesia campaigner Annisa Rahmawati believes the company should be making better progress on its commitments.

column1: “Wilmar promised that by the end of 2015 it would be able to show its palm oil suppliers were not destroying forests
column2: developing on peatlands and were respecting human rights of communities and workers. This was the cornerstone of its policy
column3: but now the company talks only of ‘aspirations’. That is simply not good enough
column4: ” says Rahmawati.

column1: Wilmar’s 2013 commitment was a bold move but it didn’t happen without considerable pressure from what environment author and journalist Fred Pearce describes as “strenuous NGO campaigns” and an announcement by Unilever – one of Wilmar’s customers and the world’s largest purchaser of palm oil in 2012 – that it would be tracking its entire supply chain to ensure it met its promise to end its role in deforestation.

It’s this same pressure that environmental non-profit CDP believes will help companies realise their no deforestation pledges. In its latest report CDP points out that suppliers and buyers of key agricultural forest-risk commodities
column2: including palm oil and soy
column3: are coming under growing pressure to ensure their supply chains do not destroy forests. “That pressure is building from their consumers and their investors
column4: ” says CDP. In 2015
column5: 298 investors with $19tn (£13.3tn) in assets under management requested that companies report data about forest risks through CDP
column6: a 24% jump from the previous year.

column1: Hurowitz adds that Wilmar and other companies need to be absolutely clear to their suppliers that if they engage in deforestation or human rights abuses
column2: they will lose access to global markets. “There’s been altogether too much ambiguity about consequences
column3: which has only encouraged some rogue actors to think they can deforest first and apologise later
column4: ” he says.

column1: So what will help end the ongoing land grab claims and forest fires that engulfed south-east Asia towards the end of last year? Hurowitz believes that governments must step up and take deforestation seriously
column2: although this doesn’t give companies carte blanche to carry on business as usual.

column1: “For the sake of their own commercial interests
column2: the leading companies need to do more to make clear to governments that effective law enforcement is essential if the palm oil industry is to restore its damaged reputation. To accelerate progress and prevent another haze crisis
column3: companies should join with civil society to support government efforts to hold anyone who destroys forests and peatlands legally accountable.”

column1: Both Hurowitz and Rahmawati cite the example of the soy moratorium in Brazil
column2: which brought companies
column3: government and NGOs together to prevent deforestation of the Amazon. “By working together
column4: traders like Wilmar were able to help eradicate forest destruction for soya in the Brazilian Amazon
column5: ” says Rahmawati. "

column17: the symbolic countdown to humanity’s end
column18: remained stuck on the brink of the apocalypse for a second year on Tuesday
column19: because of the continued existential threats posed by nuclear war and climate change.

column1: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists
column2: the group which created the clock in 1947
column3: said it was keeping the clock hands set at three minutes to midnight – the closest the clock has come to destruction since the throes of the cold war in 1984.

column1: “The clock ticks now at just three minutes to midnight because international leaders are failing to perform their most important duty
column2: ” the scientists said.

column1: The ominous forecast was imposed despite two major diplomatic accomplishments last year: the Iranian nuclear deal and the historic Paris agreement to fight climate change.
“The decision not to move the hands of the clock in 2016 is not good news
column2: ” Lawrence Krauss
column3: who chairs the Bulletin’s board of sponsors
column4: said in announcing the new clock setting.

column1: The scientists
column2: reinforced by former US cabinet secretaries William Perry and George Shultz
column3: based their dire symbolic forecast on challenges of a global scale such as nuclear war and climate change.

column1: They also acknowledged the gathering threats posed to world order over the last year by Islamic State and cyberwarfare.
The scientists noted that the 11.57pm setting was one of the worst since the clock’s inception. In 1991
column2: when the threat of nuclear annihilation receded with the end of the cold war
column3: the clock stood at 17 minutes to midnight.

column1: Barack Obama’s election was another occasion for the scientists to lower the danger setting
column2: based on his campaign promise to abolish nuclear weapons.

column1: With the Iranian nuclear agreement reached last year
column2: the Obama administration made important progress in lowering tensions. But the Bulletin said US domestic political constraints had blocked Obama from doing more.

column1: In addition
column2: the scientists said such progress was undermined by high tensions between the US and Russia that are reminiscent of the cold war. The US
column3: India
column4: China and Russia were spending $350bn modernising their nuclear arsenals
column5: and North Korea remained a nuclear risk.

column1: In many ways
column2: the world was a more dangerous place since the end of the cold war
column3: said Shultz
column4: who served as Ronald Reagan’s secretary of state in the 1980s during the height of the superpower rivalry between the US and former Soviet Union.

column1: “We have a world awash in change. There is nowhere you can look and say it’s a world of stable prosperity
column2: ” Shultz said in a webcast from Stanford University. “It’s a terrible mess.”

column1: Regarding the other great global challenge
column2: climate change
column3: the scientists and political leaders noted that 2015 was the hottest year on record – smashing through the previous record
column4: set just one year before.

column1: The Paris climate agreement – though supported by more than 190 countries – on its own was not enough to limit warming below 2C
column2: the goal for preventing a climate catastrophe.

column1: Leaders needed to focus on the big challenges of the age
column2: said Jerry Brown

column1: “Climate change is moving slowly but tipping points are around the corner and you don’t know when you are going to reach one
column2: ” he said."

column6: using the “Doomsday Clock” as an indicator

column1: The SSBBAS was started in 1945 by scientists involved with the Manhattan Project with the express intent of gauging

column4: climate change and emerging technologies
column5: ” to its list of concerns). Midnight on the Doomsday Clock

column8: when the US and Russia were both testing Hydrogen bombs – but certainly too close for comfort.

column1: There’s a big part of me
column2: though
column3: that says
column4: Who cares? (Likely a reaction that many of you are having to reading this very article!)

column1: All those years after taking a first philosophy class and reading Nietzsche and having it blow your mind and then finding out that he really wasn’t so terrific after all
column2: and all that listening to the Doors and later learning the same about them
column3: the nihilist argument carries. So what if the world is ending? Is that really so bad?

column1: The world disappoints us in so many ways. People are stupid and cruel and life is full of pain and misery. We kill each other and we’re killing the planet we live on. Would it really be a net negative for everything to come to a full
column2: abrupt stop?

column1: This week I stepped into a puddle of slush that was deeper than it looked
column2: and I felt the icy slush-water crest the top of my boot and thought
column3: No
column4: that wouldn’t be bad at all. In fact
column5: it would preferable to the alternative. As the cold
column6: wet liquid seeped down and soaked my sock
column7: it occurred to me that it might even be something to celebrate. But other days
column8: I focus on how good it feels to put a nice warm new sock after peeling off a wet
column10: and sometimes for the better. What else is there to do with our time except to try our best to enjoy it?

column1: That points towards hedonism when you’re young: have a second helping of pie and a third refill of your drink. But then when you get older
column2: when you have a kid or kids
column3: if you do that
column4: it becomes something different. I did that and it became different for me
column5: at least. Now the end of the world seems a little sadder. And my attitude about it is more one of
column6: Let me not let this life-sustaining environment end on my watch.

column1: Did you ever read Cormac McCarthy’s novel The Road? It’s really good. I often think it’s the best novel written this century. (It came out in 2006.) If you have not read it
column2: and you still plan to do so
column3: click this silly article off your screen now and go pick up the book instead
column4: because I’m about to talk about the end. (Of the book
column5: I mean. I realize we’re already talking about the end of everything else.)

column1: The Road is a post-apocalyptic novel that tells the story of a father wandering the remains of the American east coast
column2: trying to keep his son alive while most of society has descended into rape and cannibalism and human farming. The language is extremely terse in describing an ash-blanketed black-and-white world. I don’t think there’s any mention of color at all through the first 286 pages of the book. (Someone can surely check me and correct me on that
column3: but I’ve looked and not found any.) The dad dies in the end
column4: but the kid is found by another family of survivors and then the story zooms backwards in time
column5: centuries
column7: who knows how far back? And we find this:

column1: Once there were brook trout in the streams in the mountains. You could see them standing in the amber current where the white edges of their fins wimpled softly in the flow. They smelled of moss in your hand. Polished and muscular and torsional. On their backs were vermiculate patterns that were maps of the world in its becoming. Maps and mazes. Of a thing which could not be put back. Not be made right again. In the deep glens were they lived all things were older than man and they hummed of mystery.
Those are the last words in the book. People often say The Road is super-depressing
column2: but I find great joy in it. I’m flooded with a sense of peace when I read those last words. Because to me it doesn’t seem like we’re zooming backwards in time; we may well be zooming forward.

column1: Who knows what will come as we come closer and closer to destroying ourselves and rendering our planet uninhabitable? Who knows what will happen after the clock ticks midnight? Maybe time will go on. Maybe people will have moved on to space stations by then. Or Mars. Who knows what they’ll grow there? Who knows what they’ll find. Maybe brook trout. That would be a treat."

column6: but not as slim as reported | John Abraham";"John Abraham: Statistically
column7: it’s crystal clear that we keep setting temperature records due to human-caused global warming";"No
column8: this isn’t another article about how damn hot 2015 was. Although just between us
column9: I may have lost a bet to climate seer Joe Romm because he correctly predicted 2015 would blow 2014 out of the water. Instead
column10: this is a post about the probability that temperature records keep getting broken if climate change is natural.

column1: A paper just published in Nature Scientific Reports by Michael Mann and Stefan Rahmstorf and their colleagues considered this question. In particular
column2: they wanted to know how likely recent temperature records and the string of records would be if the climate was completely driven by natural variations. Not even including the crazy-hot 2015
column3: what did the authors find?

column1: Well it depended on the “record” they looked at. For instance
column2: the likelihood that 13 of the hottest 15 years would be in the past 15 years is 1 in 10
column3: 000. The likelihood that 9 of the 10 hottest years occur in the past decade is 1 in 770. The results are similar regardless of whose temperature dataset is used.

column1: Some media stories reported that the temperature records were even more unlikely. The reason this study arrived at different results is that they took into consideration the fact that temperature records are not like coin-flips. Each year is not independent of another year or the prevailing situation.
For instance
column2: there are natural events that alter the temperature such as volcanoes
column3: variations in the solar output
column4: or even internal variability such as the La Niña/El Niño cycle. If climate change were all natural
column5: you could get these natural events to align just by chance
column6: and this could give a naturally-occurring record. So
column7: while it’s very unlikely that this could occur
column8: it is much more likely than if we just treated each year as a coin flip.

column1: The authors then asked how likely it would be to have a string of records given the reality of human-caused warming. They found that it’s 83% likely that 9 of the last 10 years would be the hottest on record and 76% likely that 13 of the past 15 years were hottest on record. They also found that the odds of 2014 being the hottest year on record was 40%. Without human influences
column2: that chances 2014 would have been the hottest year is approximately 1 in a million. Mann said:

column1: The press reports last year about the unlikely nature of recent global temperature records raised some very interesting questions
column2: but the scientists quoted hadn’t done a rigorous calculation. As a result
column3: the probabilities reported for observing the recent runs of record temperature by chance alone were far lower than what we suspected the true probabilities are.

column1: Although the new odds of producing recent runs of record temperatures by chance are greater than the odds previously reported in the news (between 1 in 27 million and 1 in 650 million)
column2: they’re still incredibly slim at between 1 in 5
column3: 000 and 1 in 170
column4: 000. Including the data for 2015
column5: which came in after the study was completed

column1: In calculating the odds
column2: the previous reports did not take into account that the data did not end simply because December 31 occurred
column3: but that trends overlap into previous and subsequent years. This needs to be taken into account to determine the real probabilities of chance causing the warming events. As Mann noted

column1: We provided a method for doing this based on combining information from state-of-the-art climate model simulations with the observational temperature record
column2: and we used this method to estimate the probabilities correctly.

column1: Rahmstorf added:
2015 is again the warmest year on record
column2: which adds even more weight to our findings. What is more
column3: the anomalous warmth has led to unprecedented local heat waves across the world - sadly resulting in loss of life and aggravating droughts and wildfires. The risk of heat extremes has been multiplied due to human greenhouse-gas emissions
column4: as our data analysis shows."

column12: author Jonathan Emmett makes the case for avoiding the Emirates Airline festival of literature in Dubai – what do you think?";"Why would two book-lovers want to encourage authors and illustrators not to appear at a book festival?

column1: I love books and I love going to book festivals
column2: both as an author and a reader. So it might come as a surprise to learn that I’ve got together with book blogger Zoe Toft to organise the Think Twice Campaign that encourages authors and illustrators to think twice about appearing at a book festival.

column1: Before you think we’ve lost our minds
column2: I should say that we’re only asking authors and illustrators to think twice about going to a particular festival – the Emirates Airline Festival of Literature that is held every year in Dubai. Lots of authors and illustrators we admire and respect attend the festival each year and it seems to be well organised and very enjoyable for everyone involved. So why are we kicking up a fuss about it? Our objection is to the festival’s sponsor
column3: Emirates Airline
column4: part of an environmentally irresponsible industry and owned by a very oppressive government.

column1: Generally speaking
column2: we are in favour of companies sponsoring book festivals to help them cover their costs. However it’s important to recognise that both sides benefit from a sponsorship deal. By associating themselves with high-profile
column3: respectable authors and illustrators
column4: Emirates Airline are able to raise their own profile and make themselves appear more respectable. Zoe and I don’t think that a company like Emirates Airline should be regarded as respectable. We think they are quite the opposite. And we’ve given authors and illustrators three good reasons to think that too.

column1: One reason is climate change. While governments are making other industries reduce their CO2 emissions
column2: the aviation industry’s carbon footprint gets bigger and bigger every year. It looked like aviation was finally going to be brought under control at last year’s Climate Change summit in Paris
column3: but at the last minute
column4: they were let off the hook again. Environmental groups have said that the absence of both aviation and shipping from the Paris agreement will make it “close to impossible” to keep global warming beneath the 2ºC level needed to avert climate catastrophe. As the airline that flies the highest number of international kilometres
column5: Emirates Airline’s international flights already generate more CO2 than any other airline and instead of reducing their emissions they have just announced plans to double in size. Does that sound respectable?

column1: A second reason is free speech. The airline is owned by the family of Sheikh Mohammed
column2: the ruler of Dubai and the book festival’s patron. Dubai is part of a country called the United Arab Emirates or the UAE. Sheikh Mohammed is also the UAE’s Vice President and Prime Minister. The UAE government is very different from the UK’s and the Sheikh is more like a king than a UK prime minister. The UAE is not a democratic country
column3: so the Sheikh cannot be voted out in an election
column4: no matter how unpopular he is with his people. Many UAE citizens are very unhappy with the way the country is run. Unfortunately
column5: citizens that dare to criticise the country’s government are arrested and imprisoned for doing so (find out more in this link from Amnesty International). There are currently 67 prisoners serving long sentences just for speaking out in favour of democracy. Does that sound respectable?

column1: The third reason is human rights. If you’re not a rich heterosexual man
column2: you may be treated as a second class citizen – or
column3: worse still
column4: a criminal – by Sheikh Mohammed’s government. Attacks against women are not taken as seriously as they are in the UK and often the victim
column5: rather than the man attacking her
column6: ends up being arrested and imprisoned. Homosexuality is illegal and people can be imprisoned for up to 10 years simply for being gay. People of both sexes working in low paid jobs are not protected by the law in the same way that rich people are. Low paid women are especially badly treated
column7: with many being forced to work long hours with little to eat and no days off. Does that sound respectable?

column1: Zoe and I do have a lot of sympathy for children that might miss out on meeting an author or illustrator as a result of this campaign. However we have more sympathy for the people – children and adults – in the groups whose interests the Think Twice campaign are trying to champion: the women
column2: migrant workers and gay UAE citizens whose human rights are being abused
column3: or the future generations who will have to contend with the life-threatening consequences of climate change.

column1: If authors and illustrators are thinking of cancelling
column2: but are worried about disappointing a young audience
column3: they could offer to Skype with UAE schools. There are lots of tips for authors and illustrators who are new to Skype at virtualauthors.co.uk.

column1: Emirates Airline is an extremely rich company. They use their money to sponsor many other high-profile events and organisations
column2: from football clubs to symphony orchestras. This all helps to create a smokescreen of respectability around a company and a government that is anything but respectable. I hope that the Think Twice Campaign will help many authors and illustrators to see through that smokescreen and think twice about going to this particular book festival.

column1: You can find out more about the Think Twice Campaign at eafolthinktwice.org.uk. What do you think of these ideas? Share you ideas and opinions on Twitter @GdnChildrensBks or by emailing childrens.books@theguardian.com."

column1: The committee on climate change was set up under the Climate Change Act to advise governments on meeting targets on greenhouse gas emissions and adapting to the effects of global warming.

Flood plains are often more attractive to developers because they tend to be flat and therefore easy to build on and close to other amenities such as transport and utilities networks. The UK is facing an acute housing crisis with hundreds of thousands of new dwellings needed each year to keep pace with the nation’s housing needs.
But while previous reports by the committee have warned of the dangers of building on flood plains
column2: Krebs said that it should be possible to do so as long as property owners were made aware of the risks.

column1: It is not known the effect such a policy would have on insurance

column1: Flooding is likely to become more common in the UK

column3: even if efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions are effective
column4: because of the effects of climate change. The average national rainfall is no longer a good guide to the likely effects because instances of localised but more intense rainfall are becoming more common – an effect of climate change that has been predicted by researchers including the Met Office.

column1: On Wednesday MPs on the environmental audit committee also asked whether the Environment Agency’s responsibilities for overseeing flooding risk in the UK should be devolved to a new body. However

column10: UK news";"10";"1453981544000";"1518628749000";"0";"43";"The best thing a business could do for the environment is shut down";"... of course
column11: they’re not going to do that. So how do managers balance their climate change fears and the reality of the business world?";"Earlier this week Tim Sanderson
column12: a former executive of the fossil fuel giant BP
column13: wrote about the pride he felt for his daughter after her involvement in a climate change protest at Heathrow airport. With 12 others from climate activist group Plane Stupid
column14: Rebecca Sanderson had occupied a runway to highlight the conflict between airport expansion and escalating carbon emissions.

column1: Having spent most of his working life in oil exploration
column2: Sanderson said he was an “unlikely apologist” for his daughter’s actions. However
column3: climate change had become a galvanising issue for his family. When his daughter and her colleagues were convicted for aggravated trespass – and face a likely jail term – the former oil executive stood with other protesters loudly chanting: “No ifs
column4: no buts
column5: no new runways”. As with a growing number of business people
column6: Sanderson’s story demonstrates how climate change has become an increasingly personal business.

column1: In our book
column2: Climate Change
column3: Capitalism and Corporations
column4: Daniel Nyberg and I explore how businesses and the managers who run them are responding to the climate crisis. A key finding of our research is that climate change poses a fundamental challenge to business as usual. While corporations frame climate change through the optimistic prism of innovation
column5: technology and “green” products and services
column6: the unpleasant reality is that our existing economic system fundamentally undermines a habitable climate.

column1: For a number of managers
column2: awareness of the environmental destruction that our economic system is exacting poses deep moral and emotional questions. Some chief executives have spoken candidly about their concerns for the future of humanity and their desire to change our trajectory. Often such epiphanies are cast from the personal and emotional realisation of the world they are leaving to their children. As the Californian venture capitalist John Doerr confided in a tearful TED talk about climate change and his teenage daughter: “I’m scared. I don’t think we’re going to make it.”

column1: The emotional engagement with climate change is particularly relevant for those whose task is to make their companies more “sustainable”. Here
column2: personal concerns about the environment run directly up against the competing logic of short-term profitability and shareholder value. This was highlighted with stark candour early on in our research by a sustainability adviser in a large Australian consulting firm who told us:

column1: “I would say that most businesses’ efforts
column2: probably with a genuine intent
column3: are more about appearing to be environmental and reducing impact where possible where there’s a business case for doing so ... because the best thing a business could do for the environment would be to shut down … But that’s clearly not a viable option.”

column1: Many environmentally concerned managers thus operate in a conflicted space: they can advocate for greater corporate environmental sustainability but this must not threaten business growth.
Responding to the inevitable gap between corporate rhetoric and action requires significant emotional labour
column2: although ironically the outcome may be that emotions need to be deliberately left aside. For example
column3: a sustainability manager at a major Australian property developer explained how he often downplayed his environmental concerns and framed his appeals for renewable energy to the company’s chief financial officer around cost improvements: “There’s nothing [in the discussion] about climate change. You can’t talk about drought and floods. We looked at this stuff
column4: but they can’t get hold of it.”

column1: Many of those we spoke to also often compartmentalised their feelings about climate change between work and home. They might voice strong environmental values at home or among like-minded colleagues
column2: but would moderate their views in the presence of more senior colleagues. As the sustainability manager at a national insurer admitted: “That’s the other challenge: how do you have passion without being seen as too passionate?” Essentially
column3: fervour for the environment often needed to be tempered in the corporate space by fervour for the market.

column1: However
column2: many managers noted the need to sometimes stand strong and challenge business assumptions. Here the personal became the political by stepping outside convention and opposing proposals entailing environmental harm. As a manager in a major global food company told us: “We have to be the voice of the environment ... so sometimes decisions are made and those considerations aren’t there
column3: and we’ve got to be the ones who stand up and say no.” For some of the managers we interviewed
column4: these were pivotal events for them that involved putting their jobs on the line
column5: or even leaving their companies to pursue alternative careers.

column1: Of course personal responses are not sufficient to change an economic system hard-wired for environmental destruction. However
column2: they demonstrate the potential for an individual’s emotional engagement to begin the process of corporate and political change.

column1: Future visions of a climate-shocked world prompt strong emotional responses
column2: whether our concerns focus on the extinction of animal species
column3: humanitarian disasters
column4: or the wellbeing of our society or our children. Rather than denying our emotional responses to the climate crisis
column5: we need to use them to champion alternative narratives to business as usual.

column1: Scientists who take the long view on climate change see parallels between global warming today and mass extinctions in Earth’s past: “Apart from the stupid space rock hitting the Earth
column2: most mass extinctions were CO2-driven global warming things
column3: ” says Professor Andy Ridgwell of Bristol University in the UK.

column1: It has been a consistent pattern throughout geological time: “If you screw with the climate enough
column2: you have huge extinctions
column3: ” says Ridgwell.

column1: So much of what you read and hear about climate change is heavily based on instrument records that only go back 160 years or so. But Richard Zeebe and Andy Ridgwell are among a few scientists who look millions of years into Earth’s past to learn how the Earth responded to big additions of CO2 into the atmosphere before. I had the opportunity to chat with each of them about their work during the American Geophysical Union conference in San Francisco at the end of last year.
It’s true that scientists can learn about the ice age climate going back 800
column2: 000 years from bubbles of air trapped in ancient ice drilled from Greenland and Antarctica. They reveal many swings from warm to cold to warm again
column3: in a low-CO2 world mostly cooler than today. “We went from very cold and low sea level to a mild climate with normal sea level
column4: ” says Ridgwell. But it was a very different scenario than today - those cycles were mainly driven by Earth’s wobbles as it circles the Sun
column5: and those same orbital wobbles mean we should be cooling

column1: So both Ridgwell and Zeebe have been studying the best equivalent to modern climate change they have found so far
column2: a relatively rapid global warming event that occurred 56 million years ago
column3: called the “Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum
column4: ” mercifully shortened to “PETM.” For Ridgwell
column5: it’s a better analog for the future:

column1: This is why I like the PETM
column2: at least it’s a warming event. It had a peak global warming of about 5º or 6ºC
column3: which is a little bit beyond the end-of-the-century worst case scenario.

column1: For Zeebe it’s also about data quality:
We are focusing on the PETM is because we have relatively good sediment records. We are able to constrain timescales and ages relatively accurately. If you go further back in time
column2: these constrains become very
column3: very difficult.

column1: Scientists use a wide variety of data from rocks exposed and drilled at various locations around the globe. They look at geology
column2: fossils
column3: and the chemical makeup of sediments
column4: particularly chemical isotopes - different atoms of the same element that differ minutely in their mass. As Zeebe says

column1: We have two isotope systems that we can look at. One of those are oxygen isotopes and they are essentially a thermometer
column2: they tell us about climate change. And the other isotope system we’re looking at is carbon isotopes and they tell us something about carbon release.

column1: Zeebe and colleagues compared isotope samples with computer models of the climate system. They stretched the models’ carbon emission timescale until they got a match with the isotope measurements. This showed that the carbon emissions which caused the PETM took about 4
column2: 000 years - remarkably similar to an estimate of about 3
column3: 000 years just published by Ridgwell and his colleague Sandy Kirtland Turner. They used a completely different approach from Zeebe
column4: focusing on the differences in the carbon signal between marine and land sediments.

column1: Narrowing the PETM emissions timeframe to around 3
column3: 000 years shows that
column4: like today
column5: the global warming back then was caused by geologically-fast carbon emissions. But our emissions have taken just a couple of centuries so

column1: What we’re doing with our emissions is unprecedented in the past 66 million years!
Even if the PETM isn’t a perfect equivalent of today’s climate (it was slower
column2: and it happened in a world that was already warmer than today)
column3: it still tells us how the planet reacts to a sharp excess of carbon in the atmosphere. For example
column4: the 2013 Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report says we can expect a warming of between 1.5°C and 4.5°C if we double atmospheric CO2 levels
column5: but also acknowledges that the longer term warming (over centuries to millennia) “could be significantly higher” than that. The PETM tells us it is. Zeebe notes:

column1: If we just try to explain the PETM with a climate sensitivity of 4.5°C
column2: we only get maybe 60% of the warming. So my conclusion would be that long term sensitivity must be more than 4.5°C.

column1: Ridgwell has also investigated global warming events going back deeper in geological time
column2: including the big mass extinction events like the end-Permian and the end-Triassic
column3: as well as so-called “Ocean Anoxic Events” in the Cretaceous. These involved profound and long-lived environmental disruption
column4: with symptoms quite similar to today’s climate change
column5: such as global warming

column1: “Overall these are relatively slow events
column2: on timescales of tens to hundreds of thousands of years
column3: ” says Ridgwell. But recent advances in rock dating
column4: and in tracing Earth’s magnetic field frozen into ancient lava
column5: suggests that within those slow events there may well have been intense
column6: rapid episodes that came closer to today’s human emission rates.

column1: You might have very short pulses of CO2 release within them. Some of these pulses of CO2 could look like what we’re doing now in terms of amount and rate. That’s an area of active research
column2: because the estimates of individual pulses are getting better
column3: but the estimates of how much CO2 would be released associated with an individual pulse are still uncertain.

column1: Ridgwell is skeptical about ambitions to limit warming to 1.5°C:
We have 1.5°C already programmed in
column2: so even if we bring emissions right
column3: right down
column4: immediately
column5: now
column6: we already have 1.5 degrees! So how we’re keeping to a 1.5-degree threshold isn’t clear.

column1: So a fun thing we’re doing now with our very fast warming is the ocean surface warms up and the deep ocean is still cold
column2: which is partly why we have this programmed-in warming that we haven’t seen yet. The deep ocean hasn’t yet noticed that the planet at the surface is rather warmer. If we just sit here at current CO2 levels and let the system equilibrate
column3: it’s 1.5°C anyway. Which comes back to COP21 - what is this 1.5°C target? We’ve emitted the CO2 to reach 1.5°C already
column4: so I don’t know what they’re thinking of!

column1: It seems as if everyone is assuming
column2: without thinking about it
column3: that there is massive carbon geoengineering going on.

column1: Geoengineering is a word that covers a multitude of sins
column2: but in this case it refers to sucking CO2 out of the atmosphere and burying it. Even the 2ºC target aimed at (but not reached) in Paris assumes quite a lot of active CO2 burial. The feasibility – or not – of that endeavor is an active debate
column3: usefully summarized by Andy Skuce on SkepticalScience.com
column4: but it may be crucial if we are to avoid the more extreme long term environmental effects and sea level rises that scientists see in the geological record.

column1: Ridgewell again:
If the COP21 agreement works out even partly
column2: then we probably won’t see 5 or 6°C. But the PETM took several thousand years
column3: so marine and terrestrial ecosystems had thousands and thousands of generations to adapt and evolve
column4: whereas we’re doing this on a decade-to-century scale. It’s a very
column5: very different event in terms of rates
column6: although you at least have a total magnitude maybe like the future.

column1: For Zeebe the ability not only to reduce emissions
column2: but to reverse them
column3: is crucial.

column1: The timescale over which ice sheets disintegrate depends on the duration of a temperature anomaly. If you warm the planet by 3 degrees [Note: that’s effectively what the COP21 Paris Agreement adds up to] over a few decades
column2: and then you cool it down
column3: you can probably keep large portions of Greenland and West Antarctica. But if temperatures remain elevated
column4: this will melt big ice sheets. And then we’re not talking just of a sea level change of 1 meter by 2100

column1: But people tend to ignore this. The opinion seems to stop at 2100!
Howard Lee is a geologist and science writer who focuses on past climate changes."

column1: Assuming that the GCF does manage to obtain a sum close to the promised $100bn a year
column2: it is crucial that it receives the funding in the form of non-repayable grants. Only then will the GCF have the ability to make renewable energy and other projects attractive to private co-investors. If the only problem facing climate financing was a lack of credit
column3: it would have been solved a long time ago.

column1: A percentage of that spent to bail out private banks could pay for investments needed to stabilise the world’s climate
Since the beginning of the financial crisis
column2: central banks have created trillions to stabilise the global financial system. First they bailed out private sector banks
column3: and then they bailed out governments by buying up private and public bonds worth billions. The European Central Bank is currently buying assets with newly created money of €60bn a month to stimulate the economy in the eurozone and prevent deflation
column4: for example. All this is possible because central banks can never become insolvent in their own currency as they alone issue the legal tender.

column1: But an important side effect of these bailouts has been the realisation that central banks could play a more active role with their monetary policies; newly created money can be used to finance urgent global tasks that would otherwise not be undertaken. Just a percentage of that spent to bail out private banks could pay for investments needed to stabilise the world’s climate
To provide the necessary financial resources ( a big part of the $100bn promised to the GCF)
column2: central banks would carry on with what many of them are doing already: buying bonds with newly created money. But instead of buying existing private and public bonds
column3: central banks would buy our proposed green climate bonds
column4: which would be issued by the GCF
column5: to finance climate change mitigation and adaptation projects.

column1: Under our proposals
column2: these bonds would be for the long term (100 years or more) and would only bear small
column3: if any
column4: interest rates. They would become permanent assets of central banks and form the foundation of regular money creation
column5: ensuring that the GCF is at the receiving end of new and non-repayable money.

column1: For developing countries
column2: the advantages would be immediate access to the foreign exchange required for the construction of new sustainable infrastructure. If the central banks of developed countries purchased green climate bonds
column3: they would benefit from an increase in demand for their goods and services. The purchase of such bonds would also finance new exports
column4: which would revive domestic economies and lead to job creation.

column1: Climate protection investments and the transition to 100% renewable energy are not only a moral obligation to future generations
column2: but are also socially and economically beneficial today
column3: as has already been shown in hundreds of communities around the world.

column1: As the Austro-British economist Friedrich Hayek once said
column2: capitalism has one key advantage: the ability to respond to a sudden new demand with a spontaneous expansion of the relevant supply and – as long as there are idle economic resources – without risking inflation.

column1: If the GCF is given the financial power to expand demand for the renewable energy infrastructure required to reach the 1.5C goal
column2: capitalism will have shown that it can meet the climate challenge.

column1: In response to a rare question about climate change in Thursday night’s Republican debate

column3: as Ted Cruz and Donald Trump have been doing throughout the primary.

column10: Politics";"10";"1451905212000";"1518629277000";"0";"200";"95% consensus of expert economists: cut carbon pollution | Dana Nuccitelli";"Dana Nuccitelli: A survey of economists with climate expertise finds a consensus that climate change is expensive and carbon pollution cuts are needed";"The Institute for Policy Integrity at the New York University (NYU) School of Law recently published a report summarizing a survey of economists with climate expertise. The report was a follow-up and expansion of a similar survey conducted in 2009 by the same institute. The key finding: there’s a strong consensus among climate economics experts that we should put a price on carbon pollution to curb the expensive costs of climate change.

column1: The survey participants included economists who have published papers related to climate change “in a highly ranked
column2: peer-reviewed economics or environmental economics journal since 1994.” Overall
column3: 365 participants completed the survey
column4: which established the consensus of expert climate economists on a number of important questions.

column1: In the 2009 version of the survey
column2: the respondents were asked under what conditions the United States should commit to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. 57% answered that the US should cut its emissions no matter what actions other countries take
column3: while another 38% said that American emissions cuts would be warranted if many or all other countries commit to reducing theirs (as just happened in the Paris international negotiations).

column1: In the 2015 survey
column2: the number of expert economists saying that the US should cut its emissions no matter what rose to 77%. A further 18% said that if other countries agree to cut their emissions
column3: the US should follow suit. In other words
column4: there is a 95% consensus among expert climate economists that the US should follow through with its pledges to cut carbon pollution in the wake of the Paris international climate negotiations
column5: and more than three out of four agreed that the US should take action to curb global warming no matter what.

column1: This expert consensus is in stark contrast to conservative political opposition to the Paris accord. For example
column2: Republican presidential candidate Marco Rubio said of the agreement

column1: This kind of unilateral disarmament in our economy is reckless
column2: and it is hurting the American Dream

column1: Quite obviously an international agreement made by 195 nations around the world is the antithesis of unilateral action. However
column2: 77% of expert economists agree that unilateral action would be appropriate in any case
column3: directly contradicting Rubio’s comments. Additionally
column4: 82% of the experts agreed that by implementing climate policies
column5: the US could strategically induce other countries to cut their carbon pollution.

column1: When asked at what date climate change will have a net negative impact on the global economy
column2: the median survey response was 2025. In the recent past
column3: climate change likely had a net positive impact on the global economy
column4: due primarily to the effect of carbon fertilization on crops and other plant life. However
column5: even contrarian economists agree
column6: when accounting for the vulnerability of poorer countries to climate impacts
column7: global warming has been hurting the global economy since about 1980.

column1: The NYU survey asked when the economic benefits we experienced up to 1980 would be completely wiped out; 41% of respondents said that’s already happened. Another 25% answered that it would happen within a decade
column2: and 26% said we’d see net negative economic impacts by 2050. If we continue with business-as-usual pollution and warming
column3: on average the experts predicted a GDP loss of about 10% by the end of the century
column4: and that there would be a 20% chance of a “catastrophic” loss of one-quarter of global GDP.

column1: Of course
column2: ideally we would have stopped warming the planet in 1980 to preserve the economic benefits of global warming to that date. At this point it’s a question of just how much damage climate change will do to the global economy
column3: and the economic experts are worried that the results could be catastrophic.

column1: 78% of the survey participants said that it’s likely (36%) or extremely likely (42%) that climate change will have a long-term negative impact on the growth rate of the global economy. That’s an important point
column2: because most current integrated economic-climate assessment models assume that economic growth will continue regardless of climate change impacts. There’s been a growing body of research indicating that as you might expect
column3: that won’t be the case.

column1: The results of this survey question show that most expert economists agree
column2: climate change will hurt global economic growth. That also suggests that past model-based studies likely significantly underestimated the costs of climate change. Along the same lines
column3: 51% of the experts answered that the US government’s estimate for the “social cost of carbon” ($37 per metric ton)
column4: which is largely based on estimates from these models
column5: is too low. 18% of the experts said that value is about right
column6: and just 8% said it’s too high.

column1: The survey also asked the experts about the most economically efficient method of reducing carbon pollution. 81% said a market-based system (carbon tax or cap and trade system) would be most efficient
column2: while 13% answered that coordinated performance standards and programs that prioritize cleaner fuels and energy efficiency would be most efficient.

column1: In the US
column2: President Obama’s Clean Power Plan is closer to the latter system of performance standards
column3: although the president has said he would prefer the type of market-based system favored by 81% of economic experts. Implementing a carbon tax or cap and trade system would require bipartisan congressional action
column4: but over the past several years
column5: Republican Party leaders have shown scant interest in crafting the efficient climate policies favored by economic experts and by their own voters.

column1: The NYU survey reveals a clear economic consensus on global warming. The experts agree: climate change is hurting the global economy
column2: we should mitigate those costs by cutting carbon pollution
column3: and the most efficient way to do that is with a market-based system like a carbon tax or cap and trade system.

column1: This expert consensus clearly contradicts the arguments made by Republican Party leaders and other opponents of climate policies – that taking these actions will cripple the economy. In reality
column2: economists are worried that if we fail to cut carbon pollution and instead continue with business-as-usual
column3: it will badly stunt economic growth and may potentially lead to catastrophic economic consequences.

column1: However
column2: we can still solve the problem while creating jobs and growing the economy
column3: if our political leaders will listen to the economic experts and their voters. So far
column4: convincing Republican Party leaders to listen to an expert climate consensus has been a fruitless task
column5: but there are signs that the party is starting to move in the right direction."
