It's time to upgrade or be overtaken | Richard di Natale";"Businesses around the world are investing in low carbon technology. Political leaders can either seize the opportunity or get left behind";"2016 is promising to be a happy new year. The remarkable achievement of 196 nations signing up to the successor of the Kyoto protocol means the first ever year with a global agreement to end the old ways of pumping heat-trapping carbon pollution into our atmosphere and oceans.

column1: Now the hard and exciting work begins.
Transitioning the economy to ensure a pollution-free future throws up enormous opportunities. Commercialising new technologies
column2: improving our productivity by wasting less energy
column3: building mass-transit networks and providing farmers with new income streams from carbon markets are just a taste. Entrepreneurs can see these opportunities and are already working hard to make these prospects a reality.

column1: It became clear to me during the Paris climate talks that business
column2: local governments and civil society are leading the transition and politicians are playing catch up. This century will belong to those nations whose political leaders display the courage and vision to transition to zero carbon economies. They will do this because they can see that far from simply posing a cost to their economy
column3: it is a pathway to future prosperity.

column1: Political leaders will either deploy the policy settings that unleash these opportunities in the new economy
column2: or they will do nothing for fear of upsetting the dominant industries of today. Doing nothing is always the easiest political option
column3: but it means saying farewell to many of the brightest ideas
column4: jobs and investment that will leave our shores to more supportive commercial environments.

column1: My home state of Victoria is a prime example of how if we choose to do nothing
column2: we miss out on jobs and investment despite being perfectly placed to lead Australia’s transition to a clean economy.

column1: Right now
column2: 85% of Victoria’s homes and businesses are powered by brown coal
column3: the dirtiest form of energy on earth. These power stations are old (their average age is 42 years)
column4: inefficient and operating well past their expected life. They are the old polluting Datsun Sunny on a highway of 21st century electric cars.

column1: Victoria’s power stations are not just a drag on our environment
column2: they are holding back jobs in the clean economy. For years governments have been told by the independent energy market experts that there is too much electricity in the system. Despite the assurances made when the Liberals and Labor joined together to slash the renewable energy target
column3: clean energy construction is stagnant because the market is oversupplied with dirty power. Without a price on carbon pollution
column4: brown coal will be the last to exit the market.

column1: Through a staged timeline for Hazelwood’s closure we could remove a massive 13% of the state’s total pollution in one hit. This effect would be to open up space for new clean energy construction while injecting the skills and training that the new economy brings to Victoria’s workforce. If we set down a pipeline of clean tech projects and a detailed transition plan for workers in the coal industry
column2: then much of the hard work is done.

column1: The higher we set our clean energy and climate targets
column2: the more investment and entrepreneurs we attract to help us reach them. It’s just another example of how the environment and the economy are moving in the same direction. The old false dichotomy of “jobs versus the environment” is well and truly redundant.

column1: Attending the climate negotiations in Paris allowed me the opportunity to witness first-hand how this economic shift is unstoppable. The number of people
column2: institutions and investors is huge and growing so the only question left is whether Australia wants to ride this wave or whether we’ll watch from the carpark.

column1: There is a dawning realisation among Australians that responding to catastrophic global warming is no longer a brake on our economy. With the world acknowledging that there is no long-term future for coal and other fossil fuels a carefully planned transition that quarantines risk and protects workers will give us an unshakeable platform to build the jobs-rich clean economy that will define the 21st century. But we need to start now.
As the nation ponders the new year
column2: our political leaders are faced with a momentous choice. If we choose to keep the settings on auto pilot
column3: as we did with last month’s mid-year budget
column4: then Australia will find itself with a 19th century economy bumbling along in a 21st century world. Alternatively we can embrace the change and set Australia up for greater prosperity and wellbeing than ever before. "

column18: will the landmark Paris agreement do for thousands of species already under threat from global warming?";"The word “biodiversity” is employed once in the Paris agreement’s 32 pages. “Forests” appears a few times

column1: This is hardly surprising: the landmark agreement in Paris – the boldest yet to tackle climate change (which is saying something
column2: but not nearly enough) – was contrived by one species for the benefit of one species. It was never meant to directly address the undeniable impacts of global warming on the world’s eight million or so other species – most of them still unnamed. But many experts say this doesn’t mean biodiversity won’t benefit from the agreement – especially if the 196 participants actually follow through on their plegdes and up their ambition quickly.

column1: “[The agreement] is critical for people and it is critical for biodiversity
column2: ” said Edward Perry
column3: Birdlife’s climate change policy coordinator
column4: who dubbed the passage of the Paris agreement in December “monumental.”

column1: Most biodiversity experts concurred that the Paris agreement was an important step forward
column2: but none thought it would be enough to counter the vast risks posed to biodiversity by global warming. Indeed a recent study in Science found that more than 5% of the world’s species will likely go extinct even if we manage to keep temperatures from rising more than 2C
column3: the uppermost target outlined in Paris.

column1: “[The Paris agreement] doesn’t go far enough
column2: but that really misses the point
column3: ” said Nancy Knowlton
column4: a coral reef expert with the Smithsonian Institution. “It moves us in the right direction
column5: finally
column6: and future efforts can be even more ambitious. To paraphrase Voltaire
column7: we can’t let the perfect be the enemy of the good.”

column1: Scientists have identified thousands of species that have already been hit by global warming or will likely be in the near-future. For example
column2: Edward Perry pointed to a recent scientific review by his organisation that found a quarter of the world’s most-researched birds have already been negatively impacted by climate impacts.

column1: “According to climate projections
column2: there will be more than twice as many losers than winners under climate change [for birds]
column3: ” said Perry
column4: who noted that
column5: to date
column7: 300 birds with traits that makes them “highly vulnerable” to global warming.

column1: What is pushing them over the edge now
column2: I believe
column3: is a perfect storm of lethal conditions

column1: Already
column2: climate change has disrupted some bird’s food sources
column3: messed with the timing of fledgling and migrations
column4: and shrunk the range of cold-loving species.

column1: Birds are a good example of how climate change is already impacting wildlife because they are the best studied group on the planet. Yet
column2: they aren’t the only ones feeling the heat. Climate change is also likely playing a role in the current amphibian crisis
column3: which has seen around 200 amphibians vanish for good in recent decades.

column1: “Pathogens are always smaller than their hosts
column2: with faster metabolisms
column3: and should therefore be able to acclimate more quickly to temperature shifts
column4: ” explained Moore. “This is a phenomenon that will not just affect amphibians!”

column1: Currently
column2: habitat destruction remains the biggest threat to amphibians
column3: making species more vulnerable to even slight climatic changes
column4: according to Moore.

column1: “Amphibians have survived four mass extinctions associated with major climate disturbances. What is pushing them over the edge now
column2: I believe
column3: is a perfect storm of lethal conditions that we have created.”

column1: Still
column2: no one knows for certain how climate change will impact the majority of the world’s individual species
column3: just as we don’t even know how many species share our planet (pegged at anywhere from 3 to 100 million
column4: though a study in 2011 came up with an estimate of 8.7 million). But we can broaden our view. Just as there are some human communities living on the front lines of climate change – such as low-lying island states or drought-prone countries – there are also particular environments that scientists view as super vulnerable to climate change.

column1: Coral reefs are considered one of the most biodiverse ecosystems on the planet
column2: and the most species-rich in the oceans. Their counterpart on land may well be cloud forests
column3: which are high-altitude forests often blanketed in clouds – and also ridiculously rich in biodiversity. Similarly
column4: coral reefs and cloud forests occupy very small slices of the planet: cloud forests make up only around 1% of the world’s forests and coral reefs less than 1% of the ocean’s floor. And both are feeling the heat.

column1: Coral reef expert
column2: Joshua Cinner with James Cook University
column3: said that climate change is delivering three separate punches to coral reefs: hotter oceans lead to higher incidences of coral bleaching
column4: ocean acidification (which
column5: like global warming
column6: is caused by carbon dioxide emissions) makes it more difficult for corals to build and maintain their skeletons
column7: while more powerful storms fueled by climate change can wreck reefs.

column1: It is not like two degrees Celsius
column2: or even 1.5 degrees Celsius
column3: is a threshold whereby everything will be OK.

column1: For reefs
column2: Cinner said
column3: the climate crisis “isn’t something off in the far-flung future. It has already happened
column4: and will continue to happen.”

column1: This year
column2: record high temperatures driven by climate change – and exacerbated by El Niño – has led the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to declare only the third global coral reef bleaching event on record. The key here is global: usually bleaching events are regional or localised.

column1: When it comes to coral reefs
column2: Cinner called the Paris agreement “a step in the right direction
column3: ” but also pointed out that even keeping temperatures below rising 1.5C – an aspirational goal in the Paris agreement – would not be enough to avoid further damage to the world’s reefs.

column1: “It is important to understand that it is not like 2C
column2: or even 1.5C
column3: is a threshold whereby everything will be OK...The point is that even with a 1.5 degree rise
column4: we are looking at very serious problems for many coral reefs.”

column1: Amphibian-expert Moore agreed that there was significant uncertainty about biodiversity even with the 1.5 degrees goal in the Paris Agreement.

“It’s impossible to know what a world with temperatures 1.5C above pre-industrial levels will look like...but just talking about it ad nauseam is like debating who should call the fire department whilst watching your house burn down.”
Instead
column2: he said
column3: it’s time for action.

column1: Cloud forests
column2: like coral reefs
column3: have evolved to survive within certain temperature gradients. Already
column4: scientists have documented cloud forests literally migrating upslope to escape warming. But
column5: according to David Lutz
column7: cloud forest species “do not appear to be migrating as fast as they need to be to keep up” with steadily rising temperatures.

column1: “As the world grows warmer – or as periodic heat waves become more fierce – these species literally have nowhere to go but heaven
column2: ” said William Laurance
column3: a noted rainforest scientist with James Cook University. “I think we’ll lose more biodiversity from tropical mountains than anywhere else in the world.”

column1: The situation becomes even more complicated by the fact that many of these forests won’t even be able to migrate as far as possible. Instead
column2: as tree seedlings sprout upslope they will run into high-elevation cattle ranching
column3: at least in the Andes.

column1: “As trees attempt to migrate up into this grassland
column2: they will be either eaten by cows
column3: or burned when the pastures are intentionally burned to encourage grass growth
column4: ” said Lutz.

column1: If strategies to allow cloud forest to migrate as far as possible aren’t developed many of them are likely to vanish
column2: taking innumerable species found no-where else with them.

column1: The Paris agreement noted “the importance of ensuring the integrity of all ecosystems
column2: including oceans
column3: and the protection of biodiversity
column4: ” but went into few details about how individual countries should
column5: or even could
column6: go about safeguarding imperiled species in the face of rising temperatures.

column1: When social change happens it can happen very quickly – this is what gives me hope.
What the agreement did do
column2: however
column3: was acknowledge the importance of conservation in protecting carbon sinks
column4: often referring specifically to forests.

column1: Moore
column2: who called this inclusion “particularly significant
column3: ” said “we cannot talk about addressing climate change without stemming the rampant loss of the world’s forests.”

column1: Experts said they hoped the agreement would boost initiatives like REDD+ (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation)
column2: a UN programme that proposes to use funding from rich nations to pay developing countries to keep forests standing. Under negotiation for the better part of a decade
column3: REDD+ projects are just beginning to launch – and the initiative made a number of important appearances at the Paris talks.

column1: Prior to the meeting
column2: the UK
column3: Germany and Norway put down $5bn to reduce deforestation in the tropics
column4: while African nations pledged to restore 100 million hectares of forest across the continent over the next 15 years. If done correctly – and with involvement by locals and indigenous groups – such programmes could go a long way toward preserving biodiversity on land.

column1: But
column2: some experts have become concerned not just about direct impacts on biodiversity from climate change
column3: but how a warmer future could increasingly pit humans against wildlife.

column1: “We have anecdotal evidence that poaching increases when droughts or floods affect food production
column2: ” explained Nikhil Advani
column3: WWF’s senior program officer of climate change adaptation
column4: who also noted that when hydroelectric power plants fail during droughts people often turn to forests for fuel.

column1: He added that many of the big mammals that WWF focuses on “will be more affected by these indirect impacts from people than any direct impact of climate change.”
The international group is launching a crowdsource data campaign
column2: WWF Climate Crowd
column3: in order to better understand such threats.

column1: Climate change poses a unique difficulty to biologists as they have to cut through several layers of uncertainty to understand how biodiversity might respond in 10
column2: 20 or even 100 years. But given the rising observable impacts on species – from Arctic ice melt to worsening forest fires to record droughts in the Amazon – the risks are impossible to ignore.

column1: “I just can’t get past the nagging feeling that we’re putting off a lot of tough decisions
column2: ” said Laurance
column3: who attended the talks in Paris and pointed to plans by India and China to keep building new coal-fired power plants despite the countries’ climate commitments.

column1: “[We’re] essentially relying on our children and grandchildren to make even bigger sacrifices and bear heavier costs because we weren’t really willing to grapple with these issues ourselves.”
But Knowlton with the Smithsonian Institution is more optimistic.
“When social change happens it can happen very quickly – this is what gives me hope...Will climate change in ten years look like marriage equality today? I think so.”
The existence of thousands of species may well depend on it. "

column15: AGU allows the company to greenwash its climate science disinformation campaign";"“Thank You to Our Sponsors: ExxonMobil
column16: Chevron
column17: Shell...” This was the first message to greet us upon arrival at the 2015 American Geophysical Union (AGU) fall meeting - the world’s largest gathering of Earth and space scientists.

column1: As aspiring and early career environmental scientists
column2: this was a dismaying welcome
column3: for we are immensely disturbed and angered by the well-documented complicity of these companies in climate denial and disinformation. For example
column4: recent investigative journalism has shed light on the fact that ExxonMobil
column5: informed by their in-house scientists
column6: has known about the devastating global warming effects of fossil fuel burning since the late 1970s
column7: but spent the next decades funding disinformation campaigns to confuse the public
column9: and sabotage science - the very science conducted by thousands of AGU members. Even today
column10: ExxonMobil and Chevron continue to fund the American Legislative Exchange Council
column11: a lobbying group that routinely misrepresents climate science to US state legislators and attempts to block pro-renewable energy policies.

column1: The impacts of Exxon’s tactics have been devastating. Thanks in part to Exxon
column2: the American public remains confused and polarized about climate change. Thanks in part to Exxon
column3: climate science-denying Republicans in Congress and lobby groups operating at the state level remain a major obstacle to U.S. efforts to mitigate climate change.

column1: And thanks in no small part to Exxon
column2: climate action has been delayed at the global level; as the international community began to consider curbing greenhouse gas emissions with the Kyoto Protocol in 1997
column3: Exxon orchestrated and funded anti-Kyoto campaigns
column4: including participation in the Global Climate Coalition. The latter was so successful at shifting debate that the George W. Bush administration credited it with playing a key role in its rejection of the Kyoto Protocol.

column1: Yet throughout the week-long conference of Earth scientists
column2: Exxon was promoted as an excellent career option. The geoscience professionals showcase - an “opportunity to talk with featured employers” - proudly included Exxon. In a series of career advice workshops on transitioning beyond academia
column3: our speaker more than once named Exxon as a potential employer in her hypothetical case studies
column4: whereas cigarette company Benson & Hedges was derisively put forward as an example recruiter we’d never dream of accepting.

column1: As the week drew to an end
column2: we were left to wonder why it is that at the largest convergence of Earth and climate scientists
column3: the hosting organization would seemingly engage in a serious conflict of interest by enthusiastically accepting support from companies that actively undermine the work of many of its members. Or why
column4: if it’s now taboo to work for tobacco companies because they deceived the public about the dangers of smoking
column5: the next generation of Earth science scholars still finds encouragement in pursuing careers in the fossil fuel industry
column6: which continues to twist truths about climate change.

column1: Some may argue that Exxon atones for its wrongdoings in other ways
column2: but its actions are invariably in bad faith. For example
column3: the company has never put its weight behind a carbon tax despite claims of support for the concept. It is the very disingenuousness of Exxon’s ways that makes their greenwashing efforts - like sponsoring AGU - so crucial to their survival.

column1: AGU states that its mission and core values are to “promote discovery in Earth science for the benefit of humanity” and for “a sustainable future.” But by allowing Exxon to appropriate AGU’s institutional social license to help legitimize the company’s climate disinformation
column2: and by granting it the privilege to recruit from AGU’s own cohort of emerging scholars
column3: AGU is undermining the work of its own members.

column1: The issue of career paths also raises a deeper question that we as a community must address - however uncomfortable - as to why we are still promoting the training and recruitment of the next generation of scientists to develop future technologies and methods for discovering more oil and gas reserves
column2: when science has told us that no more than one third of existing reserves can be burned to avoid dangerous climate change.

column1: When it comes to Earth sciences
column2: AGU has established a long history of scientific excellence with its peer-reviewed publications and conferences
column3: and we’re proud to be included among its members. It is for this very reason we hope that
column4: instead of thanking Exxon
column5: AGU will now say
column8: Exxon.” This issue has been an elephant in the room for too long. It’s high time AGU protects the integrity of climate science and the message it sends to the public by cutting ties with a climate-denying corporation and by denouncing Exxon for its disinforming ways.

column1: Ploy Achakulwisut is a PhD candidate in atmospheric chemistry at Harvard University. Ben Scandella is a PhD candidate in environmental science at MIT. Britta Voss earned a PhD in Earth science from MIT and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution."

column8: 000 documents finds.";"Is organised climate science denial finished?

column1: After global heat records were continually broken over the last decade
column2: and as sea levels rose and scientists reported the accelerated melting of polar ice sheets
column3: you might be forgiven for thinking the debate over climate change had shifted.

column1: No more arguing over the science? It’s more about the policy now
column2: right?

column1: Well
column2: wrong. At least according to a new study that has looked at 15 years worth of output from 19 conservative “thinktanks” in the United States.

column1: “We find little support for the claim that ‘the era of science denial is over’ - instead
column2: discussion of climate science has generally increased over the sample period
column3: ” the study concludes.

column1: The conservative thinktanks under the microscope are the main cog in the machinery of climate science denial across the globe
column2: pushing a constant stream of material into the public domain.

column1: The study
column2: published in the journal Global Environmental Change
column3: analysed more than 16
column4: 000 documents published online between 1998 and 2013 by mainly US groups like the Heartland Institute
column5: the Cato Institute and the American Enterprise Institute.

column1: Contrary to some commentators
column2: the study found attacks on science had increased in later years. At the same time
column3: the thinktanks were focusing less on policy issues.

column1: To come to that conclusion authors Dr Travis Coan
column2: of the University of Exeter
column3: and Dr Constantine Boussalis
column4: of Trinity College Dublin
column5: analysed 8300 articles
column8: 680 open letters and press releases and 3400 “scientific” reviews.

column1: So did the result surprise them? Coan told me:
One the one hand
column2: we were aware that many in both the media and academia believed that science denial was on the decline.

column1: However
column2: this didn’t fit with our casual reading of the skeptical literature and thus a major impetus of the paper was to put this idea to the test.

column1: Though
column2: with that said
column3: we were a bit surprised by the ‘rise’: my prior expectation was that the denial of science and policy
column4: at least on average
column5: has remained relatively constant. This does not appear to be the case.

column1: Not only had the attacks on science increased but thinktanks had also ramped up their climate change output in recent years
column2: the study found.

column1: But was it possible the study’s clear declaration that “the era of climate science denial is not over” might no longer stand
column2: given that the study period ended in August 2013?

column1: After all
column2: since then we have seen the record for the hottest year on record broken twice and
column3: for the first time
column4: more than 190 nations agreeing in Paris to keep global warming to “well below 2C”.

column1: Coan agreed this was “certainly possible”
column2: but “there are also reasons to speculate that the trend has continued.” He said:

column1: We are currently working on a study with John Cook that looks at science and policy related themes (amongst other items) in the top 50 climate skeptic blogs through 2015. The topic structure (i.e. discourse) is very similar
column2: and sometimes identical
column3: to the conservative thinktanks and there is reason to think that these two time series move together. For the blogs
column4: we find that the increase in science-related skepticism continues right through 2015. Again
column5: these results are preliminary
column6: but suggest that the ‘end of science denial’ - at least among these actors - might be wishful thinking.

column1: The study explained these thinktanks “provide a multitude of services to the cause of climate change scepticism”. These included:
Many of the 19 thinktanks analysed in the study have in the past accepted funding from fossil fuel interests
column2: such as oil giant Exxon and the billionaire Koch brothers.

column1: In October 2015 a study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) found thinktanks that had taken corporate funding from the likes of Exxon and the Kochs were more likely to produce material designed to polarise the climate change issue.
Exxon is currently facing an investigation from the New York attorney general into whether it lied to the public and investors about the risks of human-caused climate change.
Dr Justin Farrell
column2: the author of the PNAS study
column3: told me he was pleased to see more research into conservative thinktanks.

column1: “We are still years away from fully understanding the extent of contrarian influence on climate change politics during the last 20 years
column2: ” he said.

column1: The latest study seems to show that thinktanks began to concentrate more on attacking the science in around 2003 but it took until about 2010 for science attacks to overtake policy discussions. But why did this happen?
One possible reason
column2: speculates Coan
column3: is the effect of the 2009 illegal hacking of climate scientist’s emails from a server at the University of East Anglia.

column1: While subsequent investigations found no wrongdoing
column2: conservative thinktanks and commentators ran hard with the “scandal” – and some still do – claiming scientists were part of a grand conspiracy to deceive the world.

column1: Dr Aaron McCright
column2: of Michigan State University
column3: who studies climate science denial
column4: said the rising attacks on science appeared to have coincided with the election of Democrat Barack Obama as US president in late 2008. He said:

column1: The Right no longer controlled the Executive Branch or Congress... at least for the first few years of the Obama Administration.. and thus no longer had as much power inside the government to block climate change policy as they did under George W. Bush. So
column2: they - and a considerable part of industry - ramped up denial activism after 2008 to the high levels we have seen since.

column1: McCright said the “denial machine” had since expanded from think tanks to include bloggers and fake grassroots campaigns and was now “more diverse and seemingly ubiquitous.”
He said conservative think tanks had influenced the public’s understanding of climate change and the way policymakers had reacted to it
column2: in two ways.

column1: First
column2: he said in recent decades US Republicans had used thinktank materials in committee meetings and hearings “to justify inaction on climate change”.

column1: Second
column2: thinktank materials had been taken up as the standard talking points for conservatives.

column1: “Indeed
column2: I would argue that anti-environmentalism - and climate change denial more specifically - has become a central tenet of the current conservative and Republican identity.”

column1: Dr Riley Dunlap
column2: of the Oklahoma State University
column3: and who has partnered with McCright on several influential studies
column4: told me:

column1: While conservative thinktanks were involved in denial from the outset - 1989 at least - we have argued they really moved to the forefront in the late 90s when BP and then other companies pulled out of the industry-led Global Climate Coalition that had arguably been the most powerful force in denial. In fact
column2: the conservative thinktanks were upset that oil companies were ‘caving in’ to the IPCC
column3: and decided to take the lead. This also really shifted the basis of denial from economic self-interest to ideological opposition – the commitment to neoliberalism’s distaste for all government regulations.

column1: McCright added that “knowing what is going on is one thing” but knowing what to do about it was more challenging. I’ll leave you with his thoughts.
Opposing policy is one thing. Undermining
column2: denying
column3: obfuscating
column4: etc. science is another. I wish I had a powerful
column5: simple solution to counter the climate change denial movement
column8: we can continue to drag them from the shadows and into the bright light of day
column10: and regularly call them out over what they are doing.

column5: science serves numerous vital roles
column6: and scientists are making our lives better. From natural hazards to natural resources
column7: and from climate change to planetary science
column8: Earth and space scientists serve especially crucial roles. Providing them with the tools they need to effectively communicate the facts of their research so that policymakers
column10: and the public can make informed decisions is crucial.

column1: Despite the important role science plays
column2: we scientists are often stereotyped as uninterested or incapable of translating our work into something the public can understand. To the contrary
column3: many of us who would otherwise be interested in communicating our science to broad audiences often find ourselves lacking the necessary training.

column1: The absence of formal training opportunities is perplexing problem
column2: as scientists have much to offer society as a whole. Where departments and institutions fall short in providing training
column3: for Earth and space scientists at least
column4: the American Geophysical Union’s (AGU) Sharing Science Program fills that gap.

column1: AGU is a society with nearly 60
column2: 000 members worldwide
column3: devoted to promoting discovery in Earth and space science for the benefit of society. It hosts the world’s largest Earth science meeting
column4: held each December in the USA. In addition to its core mission
column5: AGU is dedicated to the promotion of science to a larger audience. To fill that role
column6: AGU created the Sharing Science program.

column1: The Sharing Science network is composed of scientists from around the world who are passionate about sharing their science with broad audiences. Members range from undergraduates who are looking for advice on how fit science communication into their career path
column2: to researchers who want to express the value of their work to lawmakers and legislators
column3: to tenured professors who never received formal training in science communication but are now realizing the value of translating their work into plain English.

column1: The program encompasses all of the resources and opportunities needed to help scientists effectively communicate with broader audiences — including journalists
column2: educators and students
column3: policymakers
column4: and the public — about Earth and space science and its importance. It includes interactive workshops
column5: webinars
column6: toolkits and more to help scientists understand their audience’s needs and to improve their communications skills.

column1: AGU also creates and facilitates opportunities for scientists to share their knowledge with a variety of audiences through social media
column2: op-eds
column3: connections with local community groups or legislators
column4: public talks
column5: and media interviews. And scientists are offered the opportunity to network with other science communicators
column6: volunteer to serve as experts and resources to reporters
column7: and have their voices heard through our blogging and social media platforms.

column1: I asked Dr. Shane M. Hanlon with the Sharing Science Program at AGU how they help scientists become better communicators. He told me
AGU wants to help scientists convey the value of their work to diverse audiences by empowering them to be visible
column2: authoritative
column3: and accessible voices in their community and the world.

column1: Sharing Science seeks to break down barriers
column2: whether it’s a barrier of not knowing how to find opportunities to engage their audiences
column3: or a barrier imposed by the formalness of scientific training. One small example of such a barrier is the use of jargon. Because it acts as a barrier when communicating science
column4: the program aims to teach scientists how to avoid jargon when speaking with diverse audiences. Non-scientist audience members shut down at the first mention of “geomorphology” or “hydrostatic equilibrium
column5: ” but when scientists talk about the origins of landscapes and fluids at rest
column6: the picture is clearer. While jargon is a necessary part of science
column7: reducing its usage is a core part of being a successful science communicator.

column1: It’s important for scientists to be clear
column2: but also concise. Explaining research in plain English is one thing; not boring the audience to death in the process is another. That’s why AGU provides scientists with the tools to explain years of work in 30 seconds or less. If a scientist can sum up their work in 30 seconds
column3: then giving a 5-minute radio interview
column4: 10-minute talk at a conference
column5: or 1-hour presentation to community group becomes less intimidating.

column1: These are just a few examples of how the program works to eliminate those barriers to successful communication. Scientists don’t have to “dumb down” their research or lesson the intellectual merit or seriousness of their work
column2: they just have to speak in ways that engage their audience’s attention and values.

column1: So
column2: what’s next for this endeavor? Illustrating the importance of science communication is getting easier but there is still a lot of work to do. “It feels like things are different now – that we’re past the point of having to convince people that there’s a need for better science communication
column3: so now we can just get right to helping scientists hone their skills
column4: ” said Aaron Huertas
column5: multi-year leader of a “Communicating Climate Science” workshop at the AGU annual meeting and Senior Washington Director with Cater Communications

column1: The Sharing Science program is only in its third year
column2: but AGU has seen an increase
column3: not only in membership
column4: but also in interest about the program and science communication as a whole. Every year at its annual meeting
column5: AGU runs numerous workshops on science communication
column6: and Sharing Science staff members travel all over the country to train eager scientists in communication techniques. AGU is also partnering with other organizations and societies to provide scientists with communication tools.

column1: What scientists are also learning is that the value of communicating is now becoming acknowledged by their peers. And it isn’t just AGU that’s involved. Other organizations like the Union of Concerned Scientists
column2: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
column3: and the American Meteorological Society either acknowledge excellence in communication or support communication efforts of their members.

column1: There are also groups whose sole focus is on climate communication (Climate Communication and Climate Nexus are perhaps the best). Five years ago
column2: my colleagues and I even set up a website whose goal is to connect reporters and elected officials with scientists to talk about current climate events (the Climate Science Rapid Response Team).

column1: Perhaps the most prestigious communication honor is the annual Climate Communication Prize. The past five winners are really the who’s-who among our community. I asked the most recent winner
column2: Dr. Richard Somerville
column3: about the importance of communication
column4: particularly for young scientists. He told me

column1: I encourage all scientists
column2: including young scientists
column3: to explore the opportunities for communicating their science and to seek help from professionals. Nobody is born a great communicator
column4: but it involves skills that can be learned. Many universities and research institutions have helpful experts on staff whose job is to translate the science into everyday English for the media and other outlets. I have benefited by working for more than 20 years with a superb communications professional
column5: Susan Joy Hassol. On the website climatecommunication.org
column6: she and I and our colleagues have assembled many valuable resources for communicating climate science.

column1: Young scientists also need to be mentored skillfully in the art of combining communications work with the other aspects of their job
column2: such as research and teaching and service. A word of caution: Different employers will have different expectations
column3: and it may be prudent for a young scientist to establish a strong record in research
column4: for example
column5: before spending much time on communication. I advise young scientists to learn from the senior colleagues who will assess them for promotions and tenure. Keep in mind that these people may judge quality by looking in a mirror.

column1: At the end of the day
column2: the goal is get science out there
column3: from scientists to any audience. "

column9: Renewable energy";"9";"1452263675000";"1518631784000";"0";"8";"Wonder of the aquatic world under threat from plans for Mekong dams";"Scientists warn that plans to build dams across Tonlé Sap
column11: could be an ecological timebomb threatening the food security of millions";"In a few months’ time
column12: monsoon rains will more than quadruple the size of Cambodia’s Tonlé Sap
column13: south-east Asia’s greatest lake and one of the wonders of the aquatic world. The huge flood will reverse the seaward flow of the river that feeds into the lake
column14: submerge forests
column15: make a perfect wetland for spawning fish and will replenish soils for a rich rice harvest.

column1: Tonlé Sap is the most intensely-fished inland body of water in the world and as the annual flood subsides
column2: many millions of fish will flow from it and back into the massive Mekong river where they will become the staple food of thousands of villages.

column1: But this extraordinary annual cycle which has fed Cambodia’s 23 million people for centuries is fracturing as first China
column2: and now neighbouring Laos and Thailand
column3: prepare to build a series of great dams across the mighty Mekong and its tributaries to provide electricity for the region’s burgeoning cities. Eleven dams are planned to span the main river and nearly 100 more on its tributaries.

column1: The dam builders and governments cite the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but what they don’t tell people is that the dams will slow the flow of the Mekong basin rivers and affect food supplies.
The Tonlé Sap
column2: known as the beating heart of Cambodia
column3: is liable not to flood
column4: says Mark Goichot
column5: a hydro-geologist working with WWF. “Most of Cambodia’s fish spawn is in Tonlé Sap lake
column6: that is fed by the Mekong river. If less water comes downstream because of the dams
column7: the lake will not flood as usual and the fish will not be able to migrate upstream
column8: affecting the food supplies of millions of people. It is an ecological timebomb that threatens the food security of millions.”

column1: Now a paper in the journal Science  from 39 leading aquatic ecologists warns that the Mekong
column2: Amazon and Congo – the world’s three greatest and most biodiverse tropical rivers – all stand to be heavily dammed
column3: possibly resulting in the loss of up to one third of all the freshwater fish in the world.

column1: Tropical rivers are traditionally less dammed than those in temperate regions partly because they are mostly far from large human populations and are in places hard to access. But now
column2: as demand for electricity soars across Africa
column3: Latin America and the south-east Asia
column4: it is increasingly attractive to develop hydropower.

column1: In total
column2: say the authors
column3: over 450 large dams are planned for the three river basins. The consequences for food production is unknown
column4: but it has been calculated that if 11 of the 12 mainstream dams are constructed on the Mekong
column5: the total loss in fish could be between 550
column7: 000 tons a year. According to International Rivers
column9: more than 100 species of fish in the region could face extinction.

column1: The paper takes as an example of the gap between official promises and reality the Three Gorges dam across the Yangtze river in China. This was finished in 2012 at a cost of around $20bn and was justified by the government as providing 10% of all China’s electricity. In fact it generates under 2%.
On the plus side
column2: the biggest dam in the world has provided flood control
column3: masses of electricity for cities like Shanghai and better river navigation. But on the debit side
column4: it has had a devastating effect on fish populations
column5: and led to increased erosion and landslides
column6: and poorer water quality downstream. Moreover
column7: it has forced over 1 million people to move and has spread disease. Now the Chinese authorities are having to spend up to $26bn over 10 years to mitigate some of the adverse environmental effects.

column1: So are big dams worth it? The unprecedented building boom is widely justified as good for people because dams provide cheap electricity for development
column2: and good for the environment because they are said to provide clean electricity and lower carbon emissions in a warming world. As such
column3: they are likely to become more popular as countries try to meet the targets they set for themselves at the Paris climate summit in December.

column1: The reality is that they are anything but climate-neutral and are responsible for large volumes of CO2 emissions from the concrete needed to build them
column2: and for vast quantities of powerful methane gas emissions from the rotting of vegetation and soils flooded by their large reservoirs. By some calculations
column3: the world’s 33
column4: 071 registered large dams may even produce 4% of all climate emissions.

column1: The world is right to seek clean energy
column2: but the unintended consequences of a rush to tropical hydropower may be as dangerous as climate change itself.

column1: More than 169

column1: Just eight of 22 departments met the target

column3: however

column1: On water use

column1: “While the headline achievements may fall slightly short of the targets set for 2014-15

column11: the nutrient-rich plumes that trail melting giant icebergs are in fact sinking carbon deep into the ocean";"Giant melting icebergs may be a symbol of climate change but new research has revealed that the plumes of nutrient-rich waters they leave in their wake lead to millions of tonnes of carbon being trapped each year.

column1: Researchers examined 175 satellite photos of giant icebergs in the Southern Ocean which surrounds Antarctica and discovered green plumes stretching up to 1
column2: 000km behind them. The greener colour of the plumes is due to blooms of phytoplankton
column3: which thrive on the iron and other nutrients shed by the icebergs.

column1: When these tiny algae - or the many creatures that eat them - die
column2: they fall to the bottom of the ocean. This takes the carbon dioxide they have absorbed from the ocean surface and buries it deep below
column3: thereby curbing the CO2 in the atmosphere and the global warming it causes.

column1: “If giant iceberg calving increases this century as expected
column2: this negative feedback on the carbon cycle may become more important than we previously thought
column3: ” said Professor Grant Bigg at the University of Sheffield
column4: who led the study published in the journal Nature Geoscience.

column1: Giant icebergs
column2: defined as greater than 18km in length
column3: make up half the ice floating in the Southern Ocean
column4: with dozens present at any one time. The researchers calculated that the fertilisation effect of the icebergs in the normally iron-poor waters contributes up to 20% of all the carbon buried in the Southern Ocean
column5: which itself contributes about 10% of the global total.

column1: “We detected substantially enhanced chlorophyll levels
column2: typically over a radius of at least four to 10 times the iceberg’s length
column3: ” said Bigg. The chlorophyll levels remained 10 times higher than in the surrounding ocean for at least a month and up to 200km behind the iceberg. Some increase in phytoplankton was seen as much as 1
column4: 000km behind the iceberg in a few cases.

column1: The discovery was a surprise as previous studies of small icebergs
column2: or using ship-based measurements
column3: has suggested a much smaller fertilisation effect. The largest iceberg analysed in the new study was more than 50km long.

column1: The impact of global warming on melting ice in Antarctica
column2: much of which is far below 0C
column3: has been widely studied. Biggs and his colleagues note that satellite gravity data show a 5% increase in ice discharge from the continent over the past two decades.

column2: two separate teams of scientists found that the collapse of the Western Antarctic ice sheet is already under way and is unstoppable. The loss of this entire ice sheet would cause up to 4m of sea-level rise in coming centuries. In 2015
column3: researchers found the melting of floating ice shelves around Antarctica was faster than thought
column4: potentially unlocking extra sea level rise from larger ice sheets jammed behind them.

column1: Professor Andrew Shepherd
column2: director of the Centre for Polar Observation and Modelling at the University of Leeds
column3: said in 2015 that the rates of ice shelf loss were unsustainable and could cause a major collapse. This is already occurring at the massive Pine Island glacier
column4: where ice loss has doubled in speed over the last 20 years as its blocking ice shelf has melted."

column5: Barack Obama";"5";"1452547085000";"1518629260000";"0";"124";"Billionaire activist urges Obama to focus State of the Union on climate change";"Tom Steyer calls on president to seize opportunity to explain his actions on the environment and convince Americans that they must be irrevocable";"Billionaire climate activist Tom Steyer pressed Barack Obama on Monday to go out with a bang and make global warming central to the message of his last State of the Union address.

column1: In a conference call with reporters
column2: Steyer said the speech on Tuesday offered one of the last high-visibility moments for Obama to make his case to the American public for a transformation of the US energy and climate system.

column1: The last year was a banner year for climate change – with the Paris climate agreement
column2: the rejection of the Keystone XL pipeline
column3: an effective ban on Arctic drilling
column4: and the finalisation of rules cutting carbon pollution from power plants
column5: Steyer told the call.

column1: “This is a great opportunity to make that case and make sure that the moves we made are decisive and irrevocable
column2: ” Steyer said. “He is obviously not going to get specific climate legislation through by the end of his administration … This is a chance for him to really address Americans and explain to them what he has been doing
column3: why it still needs to be done
column4: and why it is so important.”

column1: On Monday
column2: Steyer’s NextGen Climate teamed up with fellow activists Van Jones
column3: founder of Green for All and briefly green jobs adviser for Obama; Mona Mangat
column4: board chair of Doctors for America; and Michael Breen

column1: “To truly address poverty
column2: we must address climate change once and for all. The economic burden of climate change will not be shouldered by all families equally
column3: ” the report Threat Multiplier: Climate Change and the State of Our Union
column4: said.

column1: The report extends the idea first embraced by the Pentagon nearly a decade ago that global warming deepened existing risks to the international order. (By 2014
column2: the Pentagon had elevated climate change as an “immediate risk” to national security and its infrastructure).

column1: It points out the public health risks posed by air pollution
column2: water shortages and drought – all of which will be exacerbated by climate change
column3: and notes the Pentagon’s concerns about national security.

column1: “It is in America’s best national security interest to take action on climate change
column2: ” the report said
column3: noting that the Syrian conflict and refugee crisis were fueled in part by drought and climate change.

column1: Steyer has spent millions from his own fortune backing candidates with strong environmental records in an attempt to elevate the issue of climate change in elections – with mixed results.

The billionaire’s NextGen Climate group is pressing candidates to back his call for powering the country with more than 50% clean energy by 2030 – a far more ambitious target than Obama’s – and 100% clean energy by 2050.
Among potential presidential candidates in 2016

column7: Science";"7";"1452594974000";"1518628793000";"0";"54";"Could artificial trees be part of the climate change solution?";"Real trees are forced to work harder as more carbon is released into the atmosphere. Technology could share the load";"In the fight against climate change
column8: trees are an ally. They suck in carbon dioxide
column9: reducing the harmful greenhouse gases. But there’s a problem: we’re asking them to work overtime.

column1: Trees can’t absorb enough of the carbon dioxide humanity is throwing at them unless we turn every inch of available land into a dense forest
column2: according to Christophe Jospe
column3: chief strategist at Arizona State’s Center for Negative Carbon Emissions.

column1: But what if trees – or machines modelled after them – had superpowers? Artificial trees with otherworldly abilities are a great hope against climate change
column2: since environmental experts say it’s not realistic to expect humanity to release significantly less carbon into the atmosphere. Our best bet might be to capture the excess carbon and store it or convert it into something useful
column3: such as fuel.

column1: Five years ago
column2: a Boston group recruited two designers to develop artificial city trees. The trees they envisioned offered shade and would absorb carbon dioxide. The thinking was to place the trees where soil was too shallow to host traditional trees.

column1: The group delivered great mock-ups
column2: but little else has come from it so far. Finding funding is a challenge.

column1: “You don’t want to be the first person to pay
column2: ” said Kimberly Poliquin
column3: the director of ShiftBoston. “Scientists have figures
column4: but you don’t know if that’s going to be the reality.”

column1: Capturing and storing carbon isn’t yet the type of expense local governments and organisations can slide into their budgets. The cost of the technology is dropping
column2: but not to a point where it’s affordable to install “forests” of these systems. Poliquin estimates an upfront cost of $350
column3: 000 for an artificial tree
column4: but she expects prices to come down considerably. She hopes to develop a prototype of such a tree in one or two years.

column1: There’s plenty of interest in removing carbon from the air. One method is to capture carbon directly from the smokestacks of power plants. Another method – which the Boston project targeted – is pulling carbon out of the open air
column2: where it isn’t present in as much density. In theory
column3: one square kilometre of artificial trees could remove 4m tons of carbon a year
column4: according to the Center for Negative Carbon Emissions
column5: which is developing a technology to work in open spaces.

column1: Find me $100m
column2: and I’ll tell you how to put it to a very aggressive research and development agenda

column1: Seven large-scale projects to capture and store carbon at power plants will arrive in 2016 and 20-17. Most are in the US and Canada. But more growth is needed before carbon capture and storage makes an impact on climate change. According to the Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute
column2: the 15 large-scale projects operating around the world can capture 28m tonnes of carbon dioxide per year. To keep climate change in check
column3: we’ll need to process 4bn tonnes in 2040 and 6bn in 2050.

column1: The Center for Negative Carbon Emissions is developing technology that it says is 1
column2: 000 times as effective as trees
column3: per unit of biomass. The group is located in the desert because its technology responds well to warm
column4: dry air and requires less energy in that environment.

column1: Operating in cooler climates
column2: such as Boston
column3: would add expenses.

column1: Once the technology is fully built out
column2: the group estimates it will be removing carbon dioxide for about $100 a tonne. As is
column3: there’s no resemblance to a tree as scientists – including those at Arizona State – focus on making the carbon-removal process effective and affordable rather than beautiful to look at.

column1: More developments are needed for it to be cost-effective and spread around the world. Since 2007
column2: the Global CCS Institute says
column3: the global investment in carbon capture and storage has been less than $20bn
column4: about one-hundredth of the investment into renewable technologies.

column1: “It needs the likes of Mike Bloomberg
column2: Bill Gates
column3: Mark Zuckerberg and Tom Steyer to champion early technology efforts to bring the cost down
column4: ” Jospe said. “Find me $100m
column5: and I’ll tell you how to put it to a very aggressive research and development agenda
column6: and five years later you can see some exciting technologies that start to show on the market.”

column1: Gates is one of the investors in Carbon Engineering
column2: a Calgary
column3: Alberta
column4: company that is developing industrial-grade technology to capture carbon and make fuels. It’s a promising case
column5: but not yet something ready to substitute for a tree in a city park.

column8: the climate movement has seen a dramatic increase of civil disobedience. The threat of jail is real to activists who use these tactics – as I learned first hand. But now activists now have a powerful form of defense: necessity.

column1: For the very first time
column2: US climate activists have been able to argue the necessity defense – which argues that so-called criminal acts were committed out of necessity – to a jury. The Delta 5
column3: who blockaded an oil train at the Delta rail yard near Seattle in September of 2014
column4: have been been allowed to use the defense in a historic climate change civil disobedience trial being heard this week. They said they acted to prevent the greater harm of climate change and oil train explosions.

column1: Like all civil disobedience
column2: this new wave of climate disobedience is an inherent critique of the moral authority of government. The necessity defense is an opportunity to elaborate that implicit critique into a fully developed legal argument for the responsibility of citizen action in the face of governmental failure.

column1: In addition to gaining the permission to openly argue the necessity defense
column2: the Delta 5 defendants have so far been winning the crucial legal maneuvers in the courtroom. The trial started with several motions from the prosecution to limit how the defense could present “sympathetic” evidence or anything related to their backgrounds. These motions were denied.

column1: The judge has shown himself to be committed to a fully open trial of all the factors that would drive people to risk their bodies to stop fossil fuel expansion. This kind of openness is distressingly rare for civil disobedience cases in American courts. Why this particular judge
column2: Anthony Howard
column3: is breaking ranks in this climate trial is unknown
column4: but I suspect it may have something to do with the fact that he is young enough that he will still be alive in 2050.

column1: This willingness to weigh deep questions of justice in the courtroom is already paying off with a thought-provoking trial. The jury selection developed into an insightful conversation about civic engagement
column2: protest and how to express one’s disagreement with the government.

column1: This work of arousing consciences is an essential feature of good civil disobedience. Just by participating in the selection process
column2: 60 potential jurors were pushed into a thoughtful discussion about the role of protest and challenging unjust power.

column1: One of the critical dynamics that emerged in the jurors’ discussion on the first day was the difference between protest that uses force to intimidate compared to protest that uses one’s own vulnerability to awaken a community. The Delta 5 clearly fall into the latter category
column2: but the prosecution used references to the Ku Klux Klan and abortion clinic bombers to suggest that the activists were relying on intimidation. This crucial dynamic will probably continue to be developed as the trial progresses.

column1: But even as the state tries to paint the defendants as nefarious
column2: the activists are establishing their moral advantage. The prosecution can tell by the media attention and standing-room-only crowd that these activists have power
column3: but like most government officials
column4: this prosecutor seems to only understand coercive power.

column1: As he tries to put them in a box into which they don’t fit
column2: the principled position of the activists demonstrates the potential of power rooted in love rather than force. The activists bring a vision of justice that shames the mere legalism of the state.

column1: Around the globe climate movements are trying to build power. Some of those are trying to build power based on an old model from a dying empire. Here
column2: in the trial of the Delta 5
column3: the climate movement is building a new kind of power
column4: grounded in interdependency and wielded through vulnerability. Our rapidly evolving and unstable world demands no less. "

column10: according to new research identifying Earth’s deep-freeze tipping point";"Humanity’s burning of fossil fuels is postponing the next global ice age for at least 100
column11: 000 years
column12: according to new research that has discovered the tipping point which plunges the planet into deep freezes.

column1: Showing that human activity
column2: via climate change
column3: can alter global processes like ice ages is compelling evidence that the planet has entered a new geological epoch
column4: dubbed the Anthropocene
column5: according to the scientists.

column1: Other recent research listed evidence from plastic pollution to the mass extinction of wildlife to show that the Earth has entered the Anthropocene.
The new research also shows that a major ice age was narrowly missed just before the industrial revolution
column2: probably because the development of agriculture had nudged the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere just above the tipping point.

column1: “The bottom line is we are basically skipping a whole glacial cycle
column2: which is unprecedented
column3: ” said Andrey Ganopolski
column4: at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research (PIK) in Germany and who led the research. “It is mind-boggling that humankind is able to interfere with a mechanism that shaped the world as we know it.”

column1: The cycle of ice ages created today’s landscapes and much of the world’s fertile soils.
The new research
column2: published in the journal Nature
column3: examined the eight global ice ages over the past 800
column4: 000 years and used complex climate models to determine the critical factors that kickstarted the big freezes.

column1: The result was surprisingly simple. A particular combination of lower sunlight at a latitude of 65 deg N
column2: where snow surviving through the summer leads to ice sheets
column3: and low carbon dioxide in the atmosphere was the signal for a new ice age to dawn. The level of sunlight is very predictable as it varies with cyclical changes in the shape of the Earth’s orbit around the Sun and in the tilt of the Earth’s axis
column4: called Milankovitch cycles.

column1: But the level of CO2 has been drastically altered by human activity
column2: rising from 280ppm at the start of the industrial revolution to 400ppm today. The researchers showed that even if carbon emissions are limited to the amount consistent with a 2C rise in temperatures - the internationally agreed goal - there will be enough CO2 in the atmosphere to avoid future ice ages that could have started 50
column4: 000 years from now.

column1: “This is in principle good news
column2: as ice ages are a great challenge
column3: ” said Prof John Schellnhuber
column4: PIK director and part of the research team. Sea levels rise and fall by more than 100 metres during global ice ages
column5: and runaway global warming could add another 70m to that.

column1: “Like no other force on the planet
column2: ice ages have shaped the global environment and thereby determined the development of human civilisation
column3: ” Schellnhuber said. “Now human interference is acting as a huge geological force
column4: so this is a defining paper for the Anthropocene idea.” If carbon emissions are not restricted
column5: he said
column6: they could end the million-year-long period of ice age cycles altogether.

column1: Michel Crucifix
column2: at the Université catholique de Louvain in Belgium and not involved in the new research
column3: said: “It reinforces previous assessments asserting that humanity’s collective footprint on Earth already extends beyond any imaginable future of our society.”

column1: “Such long-term consequences may seem surprising
column2: given that the emissions will occur over a few centuries at most
column3: ” he said. “In fact
column4: the mean half-life of CO2 in the atmosphere is of the order of 35
column5: 000 years. Consequently
column6: anthropogenic CO2 will still be in the atmosphere in 50
column10: which is enough to prevent any glaciation.”

column1: “The significance of the study is the definition of a tipping point for glaciation
column2: ” said Prof Tim Lenton
column3: at the University of Exeter
column4: UK
column5: who was also not involved in the new study. “This elaborates the classical Milankovitch theory by adding the CO2 component.”

column1: “It is convincing in showing the start of the next ice age will be delayed
column2: ” said Lenton. “But I was already expecting this result based on previous studies. What is interesting is how little anthropogenic CO2 is needed to prevent the next [ice age] – 500 gigatonnes of carbon – and we have already emitted that.”

column1: Prof Eric Wolff
column2: at the University of Cambridge
column3: said the research goes much further than earlier work in quantifying the tipping point. “It conforms to what many of us would expect
column4: but it’s always a big step forward when someone shows that one’s intuition is actually backed by solid calculations
column5: ” he said.

column1: “Humans now effectively control the climate of the planet
column2: ” said Prof Andrew Watson
column3: at the University of Exeter. “If only we were wise enough to be able to use that power responsibly. Unfortunately
column4: I don’t think we’ve reached that level of wisdom yet.”"

The next mayor needs specialist advice";"One of the priorities for the next mayor of London should be to appoint a chief scientific adviser. The current mayor has a range of advisers
column7: but has clearly lacked expert guidance on the scientific aspects of key issues such as local air pollution and climate change. The time has come to seek specialist advice to help deal with the wide variety of risks and opportunities facing those living and working in the capital.

column2: for instance
column3: struggled to come to terms with the findings of researchers at King’s College London
column4: who have estimated that more than 9
column5: 000 people die in London each year from dust and nitrogen dioxide in the air.

column2: Mr Johnson invited Matt Ridley
column3: the former chairman of Northern Rock bank
column4: rather than an expert
column5: to deliver a lecture on the environment. Ridley dismissed the risks to lives and livelihoods from climate change that have been highlighted by scientists.

column1: And in one of his columns for the Daily Telegraph last month
column2: Johnson claimed that the mild weather in December had nothing to do with global warming
column3: based
column4: it seems
column5: on a phone conversation with a friend
column7: a climate change sceptic who runs a tiny weather forecasting company. Johnson has written about global warming in his Telegraph column four times over the past few years

column1: In fact
column2: Met Office data show unarguably that London
column3: along with the rest of the UK and world
column4: is warming. Seven of the ten warmest years in south-east England since records began in 1910 have occurred since 2000
column5: and only one winter
column7: from the last 30 years ranks among the ten coldest on record. And the capital is facing higher risks of extreme weather events

column1: Although the mayor does not have complete control over all of the laws and policies for managing the risks to Londoners posed by local air pollution and climate change
column2: it is troubling that he apparently ignores inputs about these issues from scientists
column3: including world-class researchers based in the capital.

column1: And while Mr Johnson energetically promotes the abundance of talent in London and its importance as an economic and cultural centre
column2: he rarely mentions the city’s outstanding array of scientific minds and its unique place in the history of science.

column1: The mayor is not alone in neglecting our capital city’s hugely important scientific heritage. It is difficult
column2: for instance
column3: to find statues or other commemorations of the achievements of Isaac Newton
column4: Charles Darwin or any of the other scientific giants who have connections with the city.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: London now hosts some of the world’s most scientifically accomplished universities
column3: including Imperial College and University College
column4: as well as internationally renowned research centres
column5: such as the new Francis Crick Institute.

column1: It seems logical to propose that whoever is elected in May should appoint a chief scientific adviser to devise a strategy for London to retain its leadership as a global centre for science
column2: at a time when many other cities around the world are already aiming to overtake it.

column1: Most importantly
column2: the holder of such a role should help ensure that decisions across a range of key economic
column3: social and cultural issues affecting London are informed by the best knowledge and understanding
column4: including from the city’s own wealth of bright minds.

column1: Of course
column2: an adviser could not guarantee that the new mayor would always take full account of the evidence
column3: but it would undoubtedly be more difficult to ignore.

column1: It’s why the national government and each of its departments have chief scientific advisers. It is surely an anomaly that the mayor of London
column2: who is responsible for a wide range of issues affecting lives and livelihoods in the capital and who oversees an annual budget exceeding that of every national department apart from health
column3: education and defence
column4: does not directly receive expert
column5: independent advice on scientific issues.

column1: Whoever emerges victorious in May must show that the role of London’s mayor is important enough to require expert scientific advice.
Bob Ward is policy and communications director at the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment at the London School of Economics and Political Science
column2: and sits on the London Climate Change Partnership."

column16: Transport";"16";"1452229212000";"1518629263000";"0";"123";"Electric cars won't save our cities";"These ‘green’ vehicles may cut pollution but still rely on fossil fuels and do not end the inactivity causing our obesity crisis";"You could be forgiven for thinking that electric cars are a magic bullet for transforming the streets of the UK. London mayoral candidate Zac Goldsmith has claimed they will soon make buses in the capital redundant
column17: and the city has launched a £100m project to encourage more people to use electric cars. There is
column19: a clear case for saying London would be transformed for the better by electric vehicles.

column1: Alas
column2: we struggled to find this case written down anywhere. So we sat down with a blank spreadsheet and tried to work it out from first principles. We began by listing the problems that motor vehicles currently bring to cities. Then
column3: we asked what electricity could do to address each of these.

column1: Perhaps the most obvious reason people get excited about electric vehicles is pollution. Conventional vehicles spew some very noxious stuff into our streets
column2: killing many thousands each year (pdf)
column3: including several thousand in London alone. Electric vehicles offer a real advantage in reducing the dangerous nitrogen oxide and particulate matter in urban areas.

column1: But as well as being cleaner
column2: are electric vehicles also greener? That’s a different question – one to which the answer is entirely dependent on how the nation generates its electricity. In 2014
column3: 19.1% of the UK’s electricity (pdf) was generated from renewables compared with 30% for gas and 30% for coal.

column1: This heavy use of fossil fuels means the electric car is not as eco-friendly as it might initially appear. Electric vehicles basically move the fossil-fuel combustion from inside the car to another part of the country (safely outside the purview of any elected mayors). They don’t do much about how we’ll stop our nation emitting greenhouse gases.
The problems of today’s vehicles
column2: however
column3: go far beyond emissions. The hypermobility (pdf) they provide permits suburban sprawl (and thus extra greenhouse gas emissions) as it becomes possible for people to live
column4: work and shop at places distant from one another. And there is another big space problem: a car used for 50 minutes a day is unused 96.5% of the time. Frequently cars are stored on roads and pavements
column5: to the detriment of traffic flow
column7: councils’ finances and the needs of vulnerable road users.

column1: Simply swapping one engine for another does nothing to solve a raft of other problems. The UK has a billion-pound health crisis (pdf) arising from physical inactivity. Shifting shorter journeys – for example
column2: those under two miles – from cars to active travel modes such as walking or cycling is one of the best things (pdf) any developed nation can do to tackle its health problems. Electric vehicles
column3: at best
column4: leave this problem untouched.

column1: Perhaps what electric vehicle champions are really thinking of – especially when they suggest they will replace buses – is self-driving electric cars. Taking the driver out of the picture overcomes some issues
column2: most obviously the problem of collisions – there is a high global and UK death toll from people crashing their vehicles.

column1: A switch to driverless vehicles gives us an opportunity to rethink our relationship with cars. We could move away from the old idea that everybody should own their own car and have a much smaller number of automated cars
column2: each in frequent use and summoned when people need them.

column1: Self-driving cars might overcome some genuine problems
column2: such as the number of cars on the road and where we store all the unused cars. But this future requires car makers to sell few cars rather than many. This makes it unlikely any real change will happen – especially given the cosy relationship car manufacturers have enjoyed with governments. There is a lack of ambition and vision from the motoring industry which
column3: for all its innovation
column4: avoids addressing underlying issues.

column1: And even if we did shift to fewer shared vehicles
column2: we are still left with the issues of urban sprawl
column3: and questions about health and wellbeing. Even driverless cars do not address these fundamental problems. We need to stop building towns and cities on the self-fulfilling assumption people will travel by car. There is no future in which humans can sit down all day without paying an enormous health price. If driverless cars appear in streets anything like today’s
column4: we risk falling into the most pathetic of robot uprisings
column5: where they transport us helpfully from place to place while we remain inactive
column6: growing fat and increasing our risk of cancer and diabetes.

column1: Electric vehicles should not be considered a panacea for sustainable transport but rather a possible part of the puzzle. We need to rethink the journeys we make. Many of our urban journeys are short and we should plan cities with that in mind. Perhaps in the future we will continue to drive to the city
column2: but we won’t drive through the city. Let’s turn cities back into a place for human beings to make their short journeys in a physically active way."

column1: Opponents of carbon taxes argue they would impose costs on consumers and undermine the competitiveness of carbon intensive industries. Last year the government moved to ease these concerns
column2: exempting a raft of energy intensive industries such as steel and concrete manufacturing from existing carbon taxes and ‘green levies’.

column1: However
column2: the new paper argues only a handful of industries that together account for around two per cent of UK GDP would face production cost increases that could result in their international competitive position being compromised.

column1: “Carbon policies will provide incentives to increase energy efficiency and resource productivity which could afford UK producers a competitive advantage in the long term
column2: in a world where fossil fuel prices could rise and carbon reduction policies are likely to become more widespread and ambitious
column3: ” the paper said.

column1: It added that industries that are disproportionately impacted by carbon taxes should be provided with policy support to help them adapt to carbon pricing measures. “The correct policy response is not to resist this change but to identify vulnerable sectors and buffer labour market participants against its sharpest effects
