column1: And yet one immediate
column2: effective way to fight climate change and save polar ice caps is half a world away
column3: in the tropics. Tropical forest conservation and restoration could constitute half of the global warming solution
column4: according to a recent peer reviewed commentary in Nature Climate Change.

column1: Reducing carbon emissions
column2: as the nations of the world promised to do in Paris last month
column3: is essential
column4: but simultaneously pulling carbon out of the atmosphere (which is what rainforests do) would immediately and significantly reduce atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) at a surprisingly low cost
column5: providing a crucial bridge to a post-fossil fuel era.

column1: The potential of rainforest conservation to address global warming should be enough to galvanize massive worldwide rainforest conservation efforts. The natural regrowth and subsequent protection of hundreds of millions of acres of degraded rainforest would result in massive absorption of carbon as the trees grow. While it is crucial that we transition away from the use of fossil fuels
column2: the reality is that rainforest protection can happen much more quickly.

column1: But that is only part of the story.
Rainforest conservation is also incredibly economical. One acre of Amazon rainforest in Peru
column2: which stores up to 180 metric tonnes of CO2
column3: can be protected for just a few dollars; the same is true elsewhere in Latin America and Africa. The implications here are astounding and should give us pause: for the cost of a meal – or even a coffee – each of us could save an area of forest about the size of four football pitches and safely store about 725 metric tonnes of CO2. To put this in perspective
column4: the annual emissions of a typical passenger vehicle in the United States is less than 4.5 metric tonnes of CO2.

column1: Carbon storage
column2: however
column3: is only one benefit of rainforest conservation. Not only do rainforests protect animals such as elephants
column4: tigers and orangutans
column5: they provide a refuge for hundreds and thousands of other lesser-known species. Among other benefits
column6: the medicinal properties of undiscovered and unstudied plants may hold the key to successfully treating cancer and other deadly diseases.

column1: And rainforests provide the world with a disproportionately high percentage of its oxygen and fresh water – the Amazon River alone contains 20% of the world’s freshwater– and act as natural engines that keep the planet’s tropical ecosystems running smoothly.
Although wholesale clear-cutting and selective logging have destroyed massive areas of rainforest
column2: vast areas remain intact. And degraded rainforest
column3: if allowed to regenerate
column4: is amazingly resilient. In 10 years
column5: seedlings can grow into 50-foot [15-meter] trees. Diverse wildlife can return and rebound within two to three years.

column1: Both the remaining pristine rainforest and degraded forest require the world’s attention: a vigorous
column2: concerted effort is needed if we are going to react appropriately to the staggering demands being placed on our planet’s rainforest.

column1: Deforestation in the name of economic development has occurred routinely over many decades without regard to its devastating consequences. It is completely unsustainable for governments to continue to provide concessions
column2: subsidies and tax breaks to business when logging
column3: oil extraction
column4: mining for minerals
column5: fires
column8: cattle ranching and road construction continue to diminish the earth’s finite

column1: The case for rainforest preservation – already overwhelmingly strong – can no longer be cast as a niche effort of conservationists and scientists; it needs to be everyone’s concern. For those wishing to tackle our planet’s greatest environmental challenge
column2: there is no better place to begin than saving our tropical rainforests. "

column9: Carol Ann Duffy";"9";"1452529597000";"1519310004000";"0";"4";"Rachel McCarthy: the climate change scientist and poet unlocking elemental forces";"Inspired by ‘hardcore’ chemistry
column10: the poetry of Met Office scientist Rachel McCarthy has been called mesmerising by British laureate Carol Ann Duffy";"It’s not every poet who manages to work a demanding day job as a Met Office climate scientist. But when Rachel McCarthy isn’t walking the corridors of Whitehall
column11: on secondment to the Department of Energy and Climate Change
column12: she is to be found polishing her poems.

column1: Despite achieving a double first in physics and chemistry
column2: McCarthy always wanted to write. As the founder of Excite Poetry
column3: the Devon wing of the Poetry Society
column4: and the director of the sell-out Exeter poetry festival
column5: her verse-writing skills are matched only by her ability to draw crowds to big events.

column1: Strolling through Exeter’s arty West Quarter
column2: blinded by a low winter sun
column3: McCarthy ducks into her favourite junk shop
column4: Otto Retro. “I used to run this open-mic night here
column5: ” she says
column6: eyeing up the curiosities that include an Austrian zoological chart and some Czech apothecary jars. “It was such a warm environment. We’d have poetry readings – and people could shop during the break.”

column2: the British poet laureate Carol Ann Duffy named McCarthy one of the country’s most exciting new voices
column3: describing her work as bold and mesmerising. Last year also saw the publication of Element
column4: under the Laureate’s Choice imprint
column5: curated by Duffy.

column1: Each of the 19 poems in the volume was inspired by elements from the periodic table
column2: which McCarthy is adamant shouldn’t be dismissed as “a thing stuck on the wall in your GCSE class that you had to memorise”. Everything is made of elements
column3: she says. “You and I. This table. It’s an alphabet of our existence.”

column1: The collection spans history and tackles subjects from bees (chromium) and butterflies (iridium) to love (yttrium)
column2: disaster (osmium) and art history (zinc)
column3: via unsung aircraft fitters such as her own father (titanium). Short notes at the end of the booklet explain the significance of each poem’s element. Copper in octopus blood
column4: for example
column5: carries oxygen more efficiently than iron in haemoglobin
column6: helping the octopus survive deep under water. The poet Alice Oswald says of McCarthy’s writing: “strong interesting poems
column7: full of tension and symmetry. They are alive.”

column1: As you might expect of a scientist
column2: McCarthy did a great deal of research
column3: not only reading “hardcore” chemistry books
column4: but also biographies of Dmitri Mendeleev
column5: who first published the periodic table in 1869
column6: and histories of Russia from the same period. “I became fascinated
column7: not with melting points and boiling points
column8: but with the lives behind the elements. Why they were named as they were – after brothers
column10: stuff in the night sky – and what did they do?” There have even been fraudulent discoveries of fabricated elements.

column1: This week
column2: McCarthy will share this knowledge in Alphabet of Our Universe
column3: part social history lecture
column4: part poetry reading
column5: at Oxford University’s Museum of the History of Science. She says her dual career is often met with surprise
column6: but the two jobs have much in common. “They’re both searching for insight into laws and ideas through particulars. They’re focused on the minutiae.”

column1: In poetry
column2: those particulars are “words
column3: emotions
column4: ideas and metaphors”
column5: but the best poetry is universal
column6: McCarthy says. “Artistic expression is a search for a truth that looks different on the outside. It’s more concerned with human emotions or experience
column7: but they’re still searching.” Unlike poetry
column10: since “that sort of protects science from us as human beings”.

column1: At school in Leyland
column2: near Preston in Lancashire
column3: McCarthy took six A-levels
column4: including all the sciences
column5: maths and English literature. “I had a fantastic English teacher and there was a point when I wondered
column6: ‘Which road do I go down?’ Because that’s the choice you’re presented with now. We’ve lost the renaissance person.” In the end
column7: she decided she could write in her own time
column8: whereas moonlighting as a scientist was less realistic.

column1: McCarthy feels strongly that art
column2: when tackling scientific subjects
column3: should respect the facts. “If you are influencing the public about a scientific issue
column4: there has to be some responsibility taken by the artist.” Equally
column5: science has a responsibility to artists to properly communicate its findings. Scientific knowledge
column7: needn’t dampen one’s wonder at the universe. If anything

column1: As an example
column2: she riffs on a quote by the American scientist Richard P Feynman printed in the opening pages of Element: “Jupiter
column3: as a mythological figure
column4: to my mind is equally as important as Jupiter the planet. We must engage with both of them.”

column8: Science";"8";"1452596403000";"1518628791000";"0";"200";"NASA study fixes error in low contrarian climate sensitivity estimates | Dana Nuccitelli";"Dana Nuccitelli: Some previous studies claiming that the climate is insensitive to carbon pollution missed a key factor";"Climate sensitivity – the amount of global surface warming we’ll see as a result of rising atmospheric carbon dioxide levels – has become contrarians’ favorite basis to argue against cutting carbon pollution. If the Earth’s climate is relatively insensitive to rising carbon levels
column9: then it’s somewhat less urgent that we stop burning massive quantities of fossil fuels. However
column10: a new NASA study indicates that’s not the case.

column1: There are a few different ways that climate scientists estimate the Earth’s sensitivity to rising carbon. When they look at climate changes in the distant past (paleoclimate)
column2: and at simulations from complex climate models
column3: they get about the same result: if the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere doubles
column4: temperatures will rise between 2°C and 4.5°C
column5: most likely 3°C.

column1: However
column2: a few studies in recent years using a third method have yielded somewhat lower results. This method uses recent measurements of temperature and heat changes
column3: combined with estimates of how “forcings” like the increased greenhouse effect have caused the Earth’s energy balance to change
column4: all input into somewhat simpler climate models.

column1: These results caused the latest IPCC report to drop its lower estimate of the likely climate sensitivity to double carbon dioxide from 2°C to 1.5°C. Climate scientists were faced with the question
column2: why did this third approach (known as the “energy budget approach”) yield somewhat lower results than others
column3: and which estimate is right?

column1: A new study by Kate Marvel
column2: Gavin Schmidt
column3: Ron Miller
column4: and Larissa Nazarenko at the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies appears to have found the answer. They drew upon previous research by Drew Shindell and Kummer & Dessler
column5: who identified a flaw in studies taking the energy budget approach. Those studies had assumed that the Earth’s climate is equally sensitive to all forcings.

column1: In reality
column2: as world-renowned climate scientist James Hansen noted in a 1997 paper
column3: some forcings are more efficient at causing the Earth’s surface temperature to change than others. Those in which the effects are focused in the northern hemisphere tend to be more efficient
column4: for example. Andrew Dessler explains in the video below.

column1: Drew Shindell first identified this deficiency with these low sensitivity studies in a 2014 paper. Shortly thereafter
column2: Kummer & Dessler published a paper noting that this issue could potentially bring the climate sensitivity estimates from the energy budget method in line with estimates from climate models and paleoclimate studies. This new NASA paper builds upon those previous studies by better quantifying the efficiencies of different forcings over the historical period and the effect this has on energy budget approach climate sensitivity estimates.

column1: The NASA scientists ran climate models using just one forcing at a time – changes in greenhouse gases
column2: aerosol pollution
column3: land use changes
column4: etc. – to see how efficient each is at changing the global surface temperature. As it turns out
column5: forcings that have tended to cause cooling

column1: The scientists then repeated the energy budget study approaches incorporating what they learned about the various forcing efficiencies
column2: and found that the previous climate sensitivity estimates were indeed biased low. As the NASA study authors wrote

column1: Climate sensitivities estimated from recent observations will therefore be biased low in comparison with CO2-only simulations owing to an accident of history
The “accident of history” is that the more efficient forcings happen to be those that have had a cooling effect on temperatures in recent decades
column2: while the less efficient forcings happen to be those that have caused warming. By assuming they were all equally efficient
column3: the previous energy budget studies
column4: for example by Nic Lewis and Judith Curry
column5: biased their climate sensitivity estimates low. The new best estimate puts climate sensitivity right around 3°C warming in response to doubled carbon dioxide levels
column6: in line with estimates from climate models and paleoclimate studies.

column1: Gavin Schmidt provides more detail at RealClimate. He also notes that conservative media outlets like the Daily Express and Daily Mail
column2: and science denial blogs badly misrepresented their study results
column3: as happens all too often.

column1: It’s also important to note that relying solely on the previous energy budget model results is a clear-cut case of cherry picking. That method was the outlier
column2: yielding lower climate sensitivity estimates than other approaches. In fact
column3: there have been a number of recent studies using observed changes in cloud cover
column4: finding that the climate models with the higher sensitivities are those that reproduce the cloud changes most accurately.

column1: Moreover
column2: it’s worth pointing out that even ‘low’ estimates are not that low. As climate scientist Chris Forest noted
column3: if they were correct
column4: “It might buy us five or ten years” to solve the problem. We’re so far behind the carbon pollution cuts needed to avoid dangerous climate change
column5: that extra decade wouldn’t even be enough. Even if the contrarians were right
column6: we would still need to cut carbon pollution rapidly.

column1: However
column2: the NASA study shows that the previous estimates were indeed biased low
column3: and correcting for that bias brings them into agreement with estimates using other approaches. This result makes it all the more urgent that we ratchet down carbon pollution emissions as quickly as possible to curb the risks associated with rapid climate change."
